PETITION.TITLE: French Nuclear Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned, wish to lodge our protest in the strongest possible terms against the resumption of Nuclear Testing. Therefore we request:
1. the immediate and permanent cessation of mining and the export of Uranium as a signal to all nations that we will not accept nuclear weapons in any form,
2. the use of all means possible to dissuade France and any other nation from Nuclear Weapons Testing,
3. that the Minister for Foreign Affairs make a submission arguing the illegality of Nuclear Weapons to the International Court of Justice.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate Indonesia's continued denial of human rights to the people of East Timor.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. actively support all United Nations resolutions and initiatives on East Timor;
2. actively support the right to self-determination of the people of East Timor;
3. work for the immediate release of all Timorese political prisoners;
4. repeal the Timor Gap Treaty; and
5. stop all military cooperation and commercial military activity with Indonesia.
To the Honourable the President of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned expresses widespread community concern about the Federal Labor Government's decision to pay Dr Carmen Lawrence's legal expenses in her legal challenges to stop the Marks' Royal Commission.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate:
(a) note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition; and
(b) call on the Government:
(i)to publish full details of the basis of the decision by Cabinet, including copies of official advice; and
(ii)to immediately reverse the decision and cease public funding of attempts to stop Commissioner Marks finding the truth about the Penny Easton petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: This Petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully points out that: there is an urgent demand from the majority of Australians for immediate federal government intervention, to comply with the United Nations biodiversity convention to which Australia is a signatory, and protect the remaining high conservation value forest areas which support flora and fauna unique to Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to:
immediately implement the moratorium clause in the 1992 national forest policy statement, and cease all logging activities in high conservation value forests;

permanently protect in reserves, all old growth, wilderness, and other high conservation value forest areas, under the custodianship of Australian indigenous peoples, in co-operation with local communities, conservation and scientific organisations;
reap only what is sown by utilising readily available plantation timbers for industry needs;
rapidly implement timber industry transition from native forests to plantations, with provision for retraining, redeployment, and compensation if necessary for affected workers and contractors;
restructure the paper and fibre board industries to use annual fibre crops such as kenaf, hemp, cane etc;

create employment incentives to collect seeds, propagate, establish and manage sustainable permaculture-style mixed species timber plantations, on existing cleared and degraded lands, and encourage investment in the growing and marketing of indigenous forest products, such as native fruits, nuts, berries, seeds, oils, and other nutritional and medicinal resources;
develop educational environmental tourism as a sensitively managed industry, in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for Aboriginal cultural heritage and sacred sites; and
further support the above initiatives by the progressive utilisation of defence personnel, resources and funding, to assist rural communities to implement sustainable plantation forestry practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Choice
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That we:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex;
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations.
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray:

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned Amateur Radio Operators and members of the Public respectfully showeth that:

(1) Amateur Radio is a world wide hobby. Radio Amateurs are required by law to pass a test of proficiency in radio communications theory and practice. Radio Amateurs spend many hours and many dollars training themselves and others to pass that exam and get a licence. Continuous learning to keep pace with technological developments is part of the interest and enjoyment.
(2) The Spectrum Management Agency (SMA) licences radio amateurs who have passed the required examination.
(3) That licence used to cost $36.00 and the SMA now proposes to increase that cost to around $70. The fee increase contains a new tax to be imposed under the Radio-communications Act.
(4) This is a hobby open to all. The only other places in the World that impose such a tax are those countries, usually Third-World, which try and restrict free speech and personal development.

(5) Australian Radio Amateurs are required by law to provide a service to the community at NO CHARGE in times of emergency and does so willingly. There are countless examples, Darwin's cyclone Tracy, the Newcastle earthquake, Bush fires, Floods, sea rescues, etc.
In many cases Amateur Radio was the ONLY means of communication.

(6) The Government's action will affect the many Amateur Operators in Australia who are on limited income, and those approaching retirement in our aging population. It will discourage school children from learning the skills required to get a licence, which is often the first step to a career in science or technology.
(7) Radio Amateurs will shortly have to pay the Government up to $70.00 a year for the privilege of pursuing their hobby—a long way from the $36.00 they've been paying until now.
Your petitioners request that the Australian Government takes steps immediately to stop the increase in fees for the Australian Amateur Radio Service.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray

Dear Senator Colston

I refer to your letter of 22 June 1995 requesting my advice in relation to amendments effected to the Petroleum Products Freight Subsidy Scheme under the States Grants (Petroleum Products) Act 1965 (the Act).

The amendments to the Scheme in question were made by me via instrument dated 16 May 1995 (pursuant to section 4 of the Act), to take effect on 18 May 1995. The changes were gazetted on 31 May 1995, pursuant to the Gazettal requirement in section 7 of the Act.
Your Committee raised two matters of concern with the instrument for which I offer the following in response.
Numbering of the instrument

It was noted that while the Explanatory Statement for the instrument gave it an unique number (ie Amendment No.95/03), the instrument itself was not numbered. I certainly agree that an amending instrument itself should carry an unique identifier, and I am advised this is in train for future instruments under the Scheme.
Retrospectivity

Your Committee's concern about detrimental retrospectivity in subsidiary legislation is also well taken. In this case, there was retrospectivity for the period of a fortnight, as your Committee noted.

The amendment itself had the effect of excluding bulk delivery of eligible fuel from subsidy, which at first instance might be said to be prejudicial to a group of persons. However, detrimental retrospectivity is not prohibited in this particular Scheme (subsection 7A(2) of the Act refers, by specifically excluding the operation of subsection 48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901), essentially because eligible claimants under the Scheme are not in fact the ultimate beneficiaries of the subsidies paid under it.

The Scheme in short subsidises the cost of transporting eligible petroleum products (namely motor spirit, automotive distillate, aviation gasoline, and aviation turbine fuel) to remote areas of Australia and acts to benefit the consumer/purchaser in those areas by reducing the purchase price of the fuel. The subsidy is payable to claimant oil companies or distributors (paragraph 5(3)(b) of the Act refers), on condition that such claimants pass on the subsidy to the consumer/purchaser in the price that the consumer/purchaser pays for the particular fuel required (paragraph 5(4)(a) of the Act refers). Thus, the person who has the right to claim under the Scheme (ie an oil company or distributor) is really only acting as an intermediary, and does not feel the effect of changes in the subsidy, one way or the other.

I am advised the standard practice of the Australian Customs Service in processing Scheme amendments is to notify registered claimants of proposed changes in advance of the date of commencement, though in not all such situations does the formal Gazettal of the change occur prior to that commencement, as indeed was the case in the amendment the subject of this correspondence.

While retrospectivity is not precluded for the purposes of this Scheme, for the reasons set out earlier, I accept the general presumption against proceeding that way. I am advised that in the processing of future amendments, every endeavour will be made to Gazette the change (for which notice is given in advance to the oil companies and distributors) prior to the date of its actual commencement. I would mention however that on 21 June 1995 I approved a further amendment to the Scheme, for commencement on 1 July 1995, which was advised to registered claimants prior to that date, but which was not in accordance with the Gazettal procedures which are to be introduced.
I trust that the above comments are of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely,
(signed) Chris Schacht

Dear Senator Colston

Thank you for your letter of 8 June 1995, drawing to my attention the apparent retrospectivity of `Determination of Technical Standard Notice TN2 Of 1995 being TS-024-1995 "Broadcasting Interface" made under Section 246 of the Telecommunications Act 1991'.

I am advised that, while the discrepancy between the date of determination of TS-024-1995 and its later gazettal does render it, prima facie, retrospective, the standard does not `prejudicially affect the rights or liabilities of a person other than the Commonwealth', thereby saving it from invalidity under subsection 48(2) of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901. This is because the standard has in practical terms been inoperative since its determination and will remain so for some months to come.

The standard was developed to define, in advance, the level of isolation that a broadcaster would have to provide, at the interface between a telecommunications carrier's network and the broadcaster's own equipment and cabling, to obtain formal exemption from the normal technical regulation of customer equipment and cabling requirements of the Telecommunications Act 1991. AUSTEL technical regulation would otherwise apply to such equipment and cabling on an individual basis.

Provision of the level of isolation specified by TS-024-1995 is to be achieved by the filling at the interface of a device, yet to be manufactured, incorporating the specifications set out in the standard. The device is currently on order by the broadcasters, with its delivery scheduled to take place 12 months beyond the date of order.

The broadcasters had requested that AUSTEL formally determine TS 024 to provide them with a formal and binding specification to which the device would have to be built, before they placed their orders.

AUSTEL has developed a standard which will only become operative in practical terms when a broadcaster formally seeks exemption from technical regulation for their equipment connected to a telecommunications carrier's network. Such an exemption would be based on the broadcaster having the requisite isolation device effecting the TS-024-1995 required level of isolation in place at the interface between the carrier's telecommunications network and the broadcaster's customer equipment and cabling. I am advised that this will not occur until some 12 months after 5 April 1995
Thank you for bringing this problem to my attention.
Yours sincerely
(signed) Michael Lee

Dear Mal
re: possible retrospectivity associated
with a number of Civil Aviation Orders

Thank you for your recent correspondence to my Minister concerning possible retrospectivity associated with a number of Civil Aviation Orders (CAOs) prepared by the Civil Aviation Authority for the purpose of amending the schedule of Airworthiness Directives. This correspondence is identified below by date and subject:

1 June 1995CAO Part 105 AD/PA-11/2 Amdt 5, CAO Part 105 AD/PA-18/4 Amdt 6, CAO Part 105 AD/PA-20/3 Amdt 6, CAO Part 105 AD/PA-22/9 Amdt 5, CAO Part 105 AD/B747/53 Amdt 3 and CAO Part 105 AD/DC3/29 Amdt 2.
8 June 1995CAO Part 105 AD/AB3/65 Amdt 1
29 June 1995CAO Part 105 AD/BAe 146/16 Amdt 3, CAO Part 105 AD/JETSTREAM/16 Amdt 2 and CAO Part 107 AD/PHZL/64 Amendment 2

I trust that you will understand the delay in replying. The Minister has received a large volume of correspondence in recent months on a range of transport matters and it is taking us more than the usual time to work through replies to everyone.

You have asked whether these amendments create the possibility of prejudicial retrospectivity in relation to their respective compliance dates. Since the reasons for perceived retrospectivity are similar in each case, I am responding to the three letters at the one time.

I have been advised by the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) that in none of the above cases was it intended that the amendments were to have retrospective effect. I understand that the perceived retrospectivity in each case is the result of the style used by CASA to notify amendments of Airworthiness Directives.

In my letter to the Committee dated 19 June 1995, I proposed that all future AD amendments would be presented to Parliament as textual amendments with the date of effect clearly shown. I am advised that this new format of AD amendment should remove the present confusion over the dates of compliance.

In relation to AD/AB3/65 Amdt 1, the two dates given in the Compliance section are numbered 1 and 2 with the intention that the dates correspond to Requirements 1 and 2 respectively. Amendment 1 of the Directive added Requirement 2 to the Directive. Requirement 1 was the subject of the original issue of the Directive which took effect on 11 January 1995.
Under the proposed system of textual amendments, each amendment will have a single date of effect thereby removing any confusion associated with multiple compliance dates.
As you would be aware, officers of the Authority met with the Committee Secretary on the 17 August 1995 to discuss the future format of ADs and their amendment and the Committee's requirements.
Kindest regard
(signed) Neil O'Keefe
Parliamentary Secretary

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports: Report No. 18 of 1995 relating to development of facilities for 10 Terminal Regiment and the Army Maritime School, Townsville and Report No. 19 of 1995 relating to Air traffic control facilities for Darwin International Airport. I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the reports.

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Works Committee's 18th report for 1995—the committee has been quite busy this year—relates to the proposed relocation of the 10 Terminal Regiment and the Army Maritime School from Sydney to Townsville to meet operational and training requirements. The 10 Terminal Regiment provides the army's terminal capability and most of its water transport capability. The Army Maritime School conducts individual training in maritime and terminal subjects, including maritime maintenance, and most of its effort supports the capability provided by the 10 Terminal Regiment.

PARA.TAB: This proposal will place the 10 Terminal Regiment close to its primary user, 3rd Brigade, which is located in Townsville, and will also allow for the vacation of current locations on Sydney Harbour. The proposal will provide office accommodation, instructional facilities, marine facilities, repair facilities and storage facilities. The estimated outturn cost of the proposal is $25.914 million. It will provide quite a significant boost to the construction industry in Townsville. I know my colleague Senator Ian Macdonald showed a very strong interest in this matter. In fact, he contacted the committee during our hearings. This particular project is only part of the in excess of $100 million that is going to be spent in the Townsville region over the next year or so.

Vacation of the Sydney sites will allow Defence to rationalise its property holdings on the Sydney Harbour foreshore. The committee notes that in relation to the land to be vacated by 10 Terminal Regiment and the Army Maritime School the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) has given a commitment that any existing bushland will be retained in its natural state and incorporated in the Sydney Harbour National Park. The Chowder Bay site, occupied by the Army Maritime school, will not be developed for commercial purposes and a study is under way to determine what might happen to the land that is not bushland. This particular site is a rather unique site on Sydney Harbour with outstanding views across the heads. The committee was adamant that it be protected. The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Senator Faulkner) would also be aware of this fantastic site.

Activities of 10 Terminal Regiment involve terminal and watercraft operations which can be conducted anywhere within an area of operations. The 10 Terminal Regiment provides the army's terminal capability and most of its water transport capability. Terminal operations include the operation of road and rail terminals, military ports and assistance in the operation of air terminals. In essence, terminal operations primarily involve the transhipment of cargo from one mode of transport to another. This includes the receipt, storage and in-transit handling of cargo as well as the transit of troops.

The 10 Terminal Regiment has been substantially downsized and restructured under the recent force structure review and is currently dispersed over three sites in Sydney. The unit must now concentrate to remain viable. The Army Maritime School has also been downsized as a consequence of the force structure review. Sharing of administrative support, maintenance and facilities with 10 Terminal Regiment on one site will provide additional manpower and administrative savings. Some $3 million in salaries—representing 59 positions—and administrative overheads can be saved annually if 10 Terminal Regiment and the Army Maritime School can be concentrated on the one site.

The preferred location and level of capability for 10 Terminal Regiment have been the subject of considerable review within Defence over the last five years. These reviews have supported the retention of the capability, albeit at a reduced level, and have recommended that the unit be located at Townsville. Additionally, in the course of project development the issue of location was further investigated and the alternative locations of Brisbane, Cairns, Mackay, other Sydney sites and Darwin were analysed.

Townsville is the preferred location as it would allow the unit to concentrate, maximise operational and training opportunities, allow one embarkation point for navy support and reduce training and administrative overheads. Townsville is also a key defence base with a military infrastructure which can easily cater for the additional needs of 10 Terminal Regiment and the Army Maritime School.

In recommending that the project proceed, the committee has acknowledged the efforts made by the Department of Defence to ensure that the proposal to locate the 10 Terminal Regiment and the Army Maritime School on the Ross Island site at Townsville has minimal environmental impact. Having inspected the site, as Senator Macdonald would know, anything that goes on that site would be an improvement to what is there now.

The committee's 19th report for 1995 recommends the development of air traffic control facilities for Darwin International Airport. I am pleased to see my colleague Senator Tambling is here. I think he may be going to say something about this also. The proposal includes construction of an air traffic control tower, construction of an approach control building and provision of engineering services and site works. The estimated cost of the project is $8.4 million at May 1995 prices, with an outturn cost of $8.8 million.

Defence advised the committee that the need for a new air traffic control facility at RAAF base Darwin stems from several considerations: firstly, the existing control tower is in urgent need of repair and refurbishment; secondly, the location of the existing tower is incompatible with the future development of military facilities on the base; and, thirdly, the existing control tower is of insufficient height to provide full visibility to all aircraft movement areas and vital features. The structural damage caused to the control tower by Cyclone Tracy in 1974 was never fully repaired and the likelihood of it surviving another major cyclone is debatable, although we hope that never arises. Also, it lacks the post disaster capability required for such a vital installation.

The RAAF has conducted a safety audit of air traffic control services at RAAF Base Darwin. That safety audit revealed that safety features require improvement, and that replacement of the air traffic surveillance radar and air communications equipment was crucial for continuing safe air traffic control operations at Darwin. The safety audit concluded that the timing for the construction of a new air traffic control facility should be advanced to ensure that no disruption occurred to air traffic services whilst allowing the efficient introduction into service of the new radar and communications equipment. At the public hearing, Defence advised that the safety audit identified a number of staffing weaknesses in the Darwin air traffic control services and that these had now been rectified.
Siting of a new control tower midway along either the south or north side of the main runway was considered. A south side location was eliminated for the following reasons:

SPEECH.PARA: the buildings would be inside the Large Public Building Explosive Ordnance safeguarding distance;
glare from the early morning and late afternoon sun severely degrades vision;
existing and planned airfield lighting presents more restrictions to night vision with a control tower on the southern site than on the northern site.

Four sites were considered on the northern side of the main runway and a Technical Site Selection Board was convened to assess each location. All sites were in the general area north of the midpoint of the main runway and east of the FAC terminal and support buildings. In determining the preferred location the board considered such issues as visibility of airfield movement areas, height limitations, compatibility with future development, and existing engineering and support services.

PARA.TAB: We did raise the issue with those involved at the public hearing of whether there was any possibility of an earthquake in the area. We were told that there was not.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was one this week.

—Yes, I was coming to that. The cyclone standards far outweigh any standards for earthquakes, anyway. But I understand there was an earthquake measuring 6.4 on the Richter scale about 100 miles north of Darwin earlier this week and there was a bit of moving and shaking during the evening. I am sure Defence will take this into account when constructing this facility. I commend the reports to the Senate.

—I welcome the report of the Joint Committee on Public Works on the development of facilities for 10 Terminal Regiment and the Army Maritime School, Townsville, and congratulate Senator Calvert and his committee for the work they did and the obvious study that was put into the report and its conclusions. As Senator Calvert has said, the location of 10 Terminal Regiment and the Army Maritime School in Townsville will provide a great boost for the economy of the Townsville region. It does to a certain extent make up for the fact that the Labor government has not fulfilled promises made by the member prior to the 1990 election, when he promised that the artillery school would be located there. It was one of the phantom promises that the Labor Party continually makes before elections. This one is not a promise of the Labor Party or the candidate; as a result of the good work done by this committee, the 10 Terminal Regiment and the Army Maritime School will be located in Townsville.

PARA.TAB: Townsville, as you would know, Madam Acting Deputy President, already has a very large service contingent. Since the Lavarack Barracks were constructed in the Townsville region by Liberal governments in the 1960s and 1970s, it has been a major base for the services. Of course, that follows its major role in the Second World War which we recently honoured in the VP 50 celebrations in Townsville. Townsville was the garrison city of the Second World War and older people have very vivid memories of the role the services played in Townsville 50 years ago.

I am pleased to see that the establishment of these facilities will complement the already very good facility and strong presence of the army in Townsville. It will join in nicely with the air force presence in Townsville. Both of those operations—the army operation and the air force operation—are a credit to Australia's armed forces. They are located in a position in Australia which I think is appropriate. The locating of these two facilities is, for that reason, also correct. It is somewhat of a pity that the Blackhawks do not fly, or very few of them fly, so if we have to get our troops around Australia in a hurry, we are a bit curtailed. That is another matter, of course, for which this government deserves very heartfelt condemnation.
It is good to see these facilities being joined together with the existing military facilities in Townsville. I welcome the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 29 August, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are addressing the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. As the Senate will be aware, the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 was debated at the end of June, with some 28 government amendments and 52 non-government amendments being moved. This prior bill arose from the May 1995 budget when the Labor government announced changes to the eligibility for claiming rebates under the diesel fuel rebate scheme, including retrospective amendments dating back to 1 August 1986 and the tightening of eligibility for residential, mining and agricultural claimants.

PARA.TAB: It is appropriate to briefly recall the Liberal-National Party coalition's original position on this legislation as a framework for the current debate. My colleagues Mr Peter McGauran, the shadow minister for energy and resources, and Senator Winston Crane in this place certainly advanced much of the debate with regard to that particular legislation. It was very complex and it certainly demanded a lot of consideration.

Of most importance, we oppose the government's attempt to impose retrospective changes to eligibility back to 1 August 1986. Among other concerns, it was unacceptable that this retrospectivity would overturn several current cases before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and the courts. The coalition also sought to maintain a diesel fuel rebate for those in rural and remote areas who do not have access to reticulated gas and electricity. These communities are forced to rely on expensive diesel generators and are heavily penalised for not living in a city by the petroleum excise levied on diesel. Finally, the coalition opposed any reductions in the levels of rebate paid to genuine mining and agricultural operations.

Due to the complexity of the legislation and the number of amendments considered, a number of errors occurred in reflecting the will of the Senate in the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1995. The bill now before the Senate is to correct those errors. However, to my regret, I have to report to the Senate that not only is the original legislation flawed but the interpretation of the legislation by the Australian Customs Service is failing to match the rhetoric of the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht.

The will of the parliament expressed in the drafting of the original act is really very clear. It is the custom in this parliament to adopt commonsense interpretations of technical language when the term is not specifically defined in an act. But a number of interpretations by Customs of the provisions agreed by parliament have failed the test of commonsense and instead adopt the most restrictive and extreme interpretations of common terminology. I certainly have evidence of that in memorandums of the Australian Customs Service.

For instance, the mining industry operates many different types of access road. These include roads for transportation of ore from the mine face to processing plants, roads linking the mine site to public roads and other roads necessary for the efficient operation of a mine. Such roads are privately constructed and owned for the sole purpose of operating remote mines. However, for the purpose of claiming the diesel fuel rebate, the Australian Customs Service has chosen to interpret `access road' as meaning a road from the top of the pit to the working face.

Another issue of concern relates to the definition of a mine site. Any commonsense definition of a mine site would include tailings dams, dumps, water supply, airstrips and so on. These elements are often separated by many miles through simple necessity and, in the case of an airstrip, may need to be located separately from the other mine operations for safety reasons. In this instance, some confusion has arisen over the interpretation of the words `at the place' in the definition of mining operations in the act.

Mineral exploration is a crucial activity since without the discovery of new deposits there can be no further mineral production. Exploration involves a number of activities including reconnaissance and soil sampling in remote areas, construction of access tracks and drilling. But the Australian Customs Service has indicated that the only activity eligible for the diesel fuel rebate will be the actual drilling of a hole.

A further issue relates to the use of the word `solely', and I state at the outset that I am aware this issue was canvassed in a previous debate particularly relating to electricity. As the term applies to the definition of mining operations, it still appears to reduce the possibility of sharing services such as water and roads between remote communities and mining operations. Where, for instance, water is shared between a mine site and a community, it may well be the case that the water would not have been available but for the mine. But in sharing the water, the mining operation will be ineligible to claim the diesel fuel rebate. A further point arises as to whether this legislation would breach provisions for third party access to essential facilities under national competition reforms.

In summary, the coalition believes it is essential that these interpretational difficulties are cleared up in the parliament so there is the minimum possible confusion for the Customs Service and claimants in interpreting these terms. Under the self-assessment process used for claiming the diesel fuel rebate, small companies are vulnerable to any grey areas of interpretation which may become the subject of repayments and court activity involving considerable sums of money.

It is not acceptable that the intentions of the parliament have been overlooked by the Customs Service through the adoption of extraordinarily restrictive interpretations of legislation. I therefore seek some assurances from the minister, Senator Schacht, as to the meaning of these terms and interpretations to be adopted by the Customs Service.

I now wish to remind the Senate of the undertakings given by the government to ensure no previously eligible mining or agricultural activity was denied the rebate as a result of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1995. Quite specifically, Senator Schacht is on the record on 23 June 1995 in the economics legislation committee as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Right from the beginning I have said I have no objection to dealing with amendments to the sweeper clauses to ensure that those people who have been legitimately eligible for diesel rebate in the mining and farming industries . . . were not accidentally excluded. I said that, if people could show that there would need to be a further drafting of or amendment to the sweeper clauses to ensure that no-one accidentally got excluded, so that those who already legitimately got the diesel fuel rebate continued to get it, I would accept those amendments.

Such an issue has arisen relating to the construction of transport networks. The service, maintenance or repair of transport networks are already covered under paragraph (v) of the definition of mining operations but it would certainly be appropriate to include the construction of networks in this definition. The construction phase does not usually involve large quantities of diesel fuel but it is an essential aspect of mining operations and it is inconsistent for the maintenance and repair of the transport network to be eligible for the rebate but not its construction.

PARA.TAB: Of more significance, the offshore petroleum industry has been completely overlooked in this process of clarifying the so-called sweeper clauses. As a result, a windfall estimated to be $12 million to $15 million is currently being received by the government at the expense of one of our most productive and most heavily taxed industries.

We have received representations from the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association Ltd, from the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies, and from the Western Australian Minister for Mines in regard to these particular issues. Those representations are very comprehensive and I know that they have also been made to the minister, Senator Schacht.

I think it is important, for the record and for consideration of these issues, that the full representations made to us by the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association Ltd, the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies, and the Western Australian Minister for Mines be available to senators and to anyone else who wishes to consider the important impact of this legislation on these important industries. I therefore seek leave of the Senate to table the representations by APPEA to Mr Peter McGauran dated 14 September 1995, the representation of AMEC to the minister, Senator Schacht, dated 29 August 1995, and the correspondence from the Western Australian Minister for Mines, Mr Cash, to the minister, Senator Schacht, dated 18 September 1995.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important that this matter be given good and proper and much fuller discussion. Therefore, it is the proposal of the opposition that, at the conclusion of the debate on the second reading of this bill, the proposed legislation be referred to the Senate Economics Committee for further consideration.

PARA.TAB: At that committee I would envisage the representatives of APPEA, AMEC, the Western Australian government, any other interested parties and the Australian Customs Service being invited to appear before an appropriate committee of the Senate to discuss fully and much more comprehensively the flaws that we now see in this particular legislation. I have prepared a series of amendments which I will certainly make available to the committee for consideration in that regard.

In consideration of the key member groups AMEC and APPEA it is important to note that the failure to notify industry and the action to subsequently legislate to remove the eligibility of industry for rebates on fuel used legitimately as part of their operations has effectively denied the industry any opportunity to contest the relevance of the case, particularly for the offshore industry. This is clearly a denial of natural justice and should be condemned by the Senate, which was not advised of the impact at any time during the debates earlier this year. There are some very important points of principle that therefore arise.

I am certainly aware that there are a number of other issues and concerns that have been flagged and canvassed by some of my colleagues, particularly with regard to the impact on limestone and mining in that regard. I know that Senate colleagues will address that matter, particularly if there is an opportunity before the appropriate Senate committee to be considered in further detail, and in the discussion that will be necessary with the minister. It is important that we proceed with the debate on the second reading today and then take on notice that it will be necessary for the Senate to give this matter much more comprehensive and detailed consideration in the committee on an appropriate Friday.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. The provisions of the bill are fairly brief and few. They address some omissions and mistakes that were made when the original bill was first before the Senate just before the mid-year break. The Australian Democrats have no difficulties with any of the provisions that are part of the bill.

PARA.TAB: With respect to the issues raised by Senator Tambling, the Australian Democrats are coming from a slightly different position. I have taken note of the Federal Court judgment in July 1993 in Pozzolanic Enterprises Pty Ltd, which dealt with the question of providing materials to the site and made it fairly clear, I thought, that the provision of these materials, the transport of these materials, was not eligible for the rebate. Admittedly, this was in the context of the agricultural industry, and it apparently took some time for the customs department to translate the effects of that decision into claims made in the mining and exploration sectors. I think there are probably some issues involved in how the customs department dealt with claims and with some of the definitions.

On balance, I am prepared to support the reference to a committee, provided we have an assurance. I think Senator Tambling suggested a committee on a Friday. That has a particular meaning in the Senate, as senators will know; that is, that we spend no more than a day. But I would have thought that half a day should be sufficient for this particular inquiry. Before I support the motion for that, I would like that assurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

—Thank you. There is no point at this stage in going through the substantive issues that will be canvassed before the committee. Just as Senator Tambling said he would defer his amendments, I will defer comment on the substantive issues until we have heard evidence before the economics committee.

PARA.TAB: Let me just state, though, the general principle that the Democrats follow; that is, that this diesel fuel rebate entitlement should not be extended unduly. We support the attempt that the government has made in the main legislation and continues in this bill to contain the drain on government revenue. I add the consideration that we need to compare the assistance being given to these industries with the assistance or the lack of assistance to other industry sectors—for instance, the manufacturing sector. We should ask ourselves whether it is appropriate, as a matter of public policy, to provide this particular assistance to the mining and agricultural sectors and to keep extending it.

So, as a matter of principle, we are inclined to construe the provisions narrowly in an attempt to contain the drain on public revenue rather than extend assistance to these industries where other industries are not favoured in similar ways. With these remarks, I wish to confirm that the Democrats will be supporting the reference to the committee on the assumption that half a day's hearing will be sufficient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). In this year's budget, the federal government announced changes to the eligibility for claiming the diesel fuel rebate. These included retrospective amendments and the tightening of eligibility for residential mining and agricultural claimants. However, due to the complexity of the legislation, a number of unforeseen errors have occurred. This has led to the introduction of the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) to rectify these problems.

PARA.TAB: Many problems are associated with some quarrying in my state of Western Australia. I did not speak on the original legislation, but I do feel the need to mention many of the concerns that have been raised with me by people who are involved in the quarrying business. I would certainly like to add my comments to those that have been made today and also back in June, when the original legislation was last debated.

This legislation seeks to exclude those involved in the quarrying business from claiming the diesel fuel rebate, but other so-called mainstream mining activities are not excluded. I find there is absolutely no justification for that in the way that there will be different treatment of different industries. When we consider that mining is defined as the digging of a deep hole to extract a resource and quarrying is defined as the excavation of land to gather a resource, surely they could be classified, broadly speaking, as the same activity. Apparently that is not the case, and for quarriers, including the many in my state, it is a very bitter pill for them to swallow because they are certainly going to be treated in a different way.

In effect, the government's amendments ensure that no rebate is available for activities such as the extraction of sand, sandstone, soil, clay or granite because the materials are not recovered for their inherent mineral qualities. In other words, if something could be extracted from the materials I have just mentioned a rebate could be paid but not if they are simply extracted for their raw properties, and therein lies the difference.

It is estimated that this legislation will save the government $5 million in the current financial year with retrospective savings of at least $16 million. Considering the net value of these extractive industries to the Australian economy and to local communities, I would have thought that would be a fairly small saving. The government is to be condemned, in my opinion, for drawing an artificial line of demarcation between mining and quarrying because there is no real reason why these types of extractive industries should be treated differently. In the case of open-cut mining, for example, the operation is very similar to that of quarrying, yet companies will be eligible for rebate for only the mining activities.

By any other name this is yet another tax on businesses, including many small business quarrying operations. Quite frankly, the coalition is vehemently opposed to such a course of action when small business is the engine room of a better economy and a better standard of living for all Australians. As if some of these industries are not being hit enough by a whole range of taxes—including the fringe benefits tax, just to name one—it is a crying shame they will now be confronted with yet another tax at a time when they are desperately trying to survive.

Large companies such as Pioneer, Boral and CSR, which constitute 75 per cent of the quarry industry, believe this measure will cost them dearly. They estimate the cost to be in the vicinity of $20 million per year and $80 million retrospectively. This is four and five times what the government plans to save retrospectively by the introduction of this ill-conceived measure.

Let us not forget that many of the materials which are quarried constitute part of the average home—bricks and mortar, just to name two of them—so in the end it will be an additional cost which new home buyers and home builders will feel. Little emphasis has been put on the end product in this measure. At a time when the housing industry is certainly not roaring ahead at a million miles an hour, I do not believe we should be imposing any extra taxes that will flow on to the end user: the average man in the street.

There is a real dilemma in front of the small quarrying operations, which are not associated with resource giants such as CSR. One of my constituents, who has a granite quarry as the family business, assures me that without the entitlement to the diesel fuel rebate it will be virtually impossible to compete with imported granite in the Australian market because of the higher cost of overheads in Australia compared with those faced by overseas quarries. What is the dilemma, you might ask? The dilemma is whether to stay open or to close. Ultimately, that decision might be made for them, unfortunately. I would have thought that, at a time when we are actually trying to encourage more local production, we would not be putting measures in place that would see importers being given an advantage over our domestic suppliers.

This gentleman has also informed me that processed granite is even imported from places such as Singapore, Japan and Hong Kong, which do not quarry granite themselves but simply act as a site for downstream processing. This product is currently overtaking the Australian product because of its in-built price advantages. This new cost impost will give these countries a further advantage and will leave local people wondering whether it is worth their while at all to continue. I am very concerned that many of these companies in Western Australia, and indeed throughout Australia, will in fact find the going so tough in the months to come that they will close. What is going to happen then? We will have a greater reliance on the imported product.

This gentleman has also very kindly obtained from the Australian Bureau of Statistics a comprehensive breakdown of the granite importation figures, which include crude and roughly trimmed granite, blocks and slabs of granite, and flat surface cut granite. The data shows that Australia imports granite from all over the world—Argentina, Brazil, Egypt, Finland, Greece, India, Indonesia, Iran, Italy, Korea, Norway, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Zimbabwe, Hong Kong, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, the United States of America, Canada, Portugal, Saudi Arabia, Taiwan, the United Kingdom, Vietnam, Turkey, Switzerland and Japan. We are importing from all of those countries and here we are putting a further impost on local industry. When you consider the odds, I suppose we are very lucky that the government chose Australian granite to clad the walls of Parliament House when there is so much imported granite on the Australian market.

Overall, the total imports of dimension stone, which includes slate, marble, granite and quartzite for facia and presentation purposes, are worth in the vicinity of $10.6 million. Granite, specifically, is worth about $3.2 million. By comparison, our exports, with a total volume of 10,008 tonnes, value about $5.8 million annually, with our two single largest market destinations being Italy and New Zealand. Most of our production is, however, directed at meeting outside domestic needs and competing against the imported product.

Interestingly enough, Western Australia leads the way in terms of total volume and value of dimension stone produced. Therefore, understandably as a Western Australian, I am very concerned that that is going to be undermined by this legislation. It just happens to be the fact that we are looking at these industries going out backwards because of a further impost they can ill afford.

In the 1993 calendar year, the year for which the most recent figures are available, Western Australia produced a massive 414 kilotons of dimension stone at a value of $14.1 million, according to the statistical data published by the Australian Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics. South Australia is the next closest producer with a production volume of 61 kilotons at a value of $2.1 million. You can see that Western Australia is the biggest contributor to this particular activity, as is the case with the extraction of most other valuable mineral resources which our nation exports, such as iron ore, natural gas and gold to name three.

If I were completely cynical I might reason that, because the production volume of the eastern states is far less than Western Australia's and the industries in the eastern states are going to be far less affected than Western Australia by the changes to the diesel fuel rebate scheme, that is why the government has moved in this direction. If the measure were going to affect everyone throughout Australia in a uniform fashion, it would be something that would be seriously reconsidered by the Labor government. So many times it has been the case that, where Western Australia stands to be most greatly affected by the government's legislative changes, this federal government simply cares not a continental about the state which is the biggest contributor to Australia's economy and simply rams through its legislation and its amendments in the same way, as if in contempt of the Western Australian people, simply to spite the Western Australian government particularly now that it is a Liberal government.
I could cite the Native Title Act as one example. The bill we are debating now is another. As I said, I would not want to be too cynical about that, would I?

On the whole, the value of dimension stone production to the economy in terms of wealth generation and employment opportunities is about $19 million as a result of employment and cash flow from the quarrying operations and from the many services which support those operations. Equipment and chemical suppliers are affected as well. Once again, we have a flow-on effect from a further taxation measure that is not going to affect just one industry but has the potential, as I said before, to affect the building industry and, now, more and more of these supportive industries that go hand in glove to make sure the quarrying industry is a vital industry for Australia.

If I were to use the multiplier effect presented by the minister in May this year at the Minerals Council of Australia-Minex health and safety awards in Canberra, I could deduce the value of dimension stone to the economy might be closer to $30.5 million. In his opening speech at these awards, the minister described the flow-on effects of mining and said:

SPEECH.PARA: These far reaching effects are not widely understood in the Australian economy and should be.

As far as I am concerned, that is game, set and match. In his own words, the flow-on effect is underestimated. Yet this government is bringing in a piece of legislation that will badly affect this industry and the flow-on will be further affected. Senator Cook, with respect to quarrying: it would seem it is the Australian community which understands perfectly well that there are beneficial flow-on effects. As I say, this government simply cannot grasp that level of debate and is not concerned about the way in which a measure has a flow-on effect to a whole lot of businesses and to a whole lot of individuals and employees throughout those industries.

PARA.TAB: In terms of general mining activities which contribute billions of dollars to the economy, it is true that granite quarrying is not in the big league; nonetheless, it is a valuable contributor, as is any other quarrying industry. Again I stress there is no local bias for separating the activity of quarrying from mining for the purpose of amending the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

If it is true that quarriers will be crippled by this change—and I have no reason to doubt that it is true, from all the information that I have been given and from the conversations that I have had with people—then this government will have successfully driven yet another industry to the wall. That will have huge ramifications on costs, taxes and charges. The personal impact is something that this government seems not to worry about in terms of the jobs that will be lost, the families who will be forced into other forms of employment, if they are lucky to get employment, or forced onto welfare.

At this time I am reminded of a story which appeared in the West Australian newspaper in June accompanied by a picture of a garage door with the words `Thanks Paul!' painted over it. That told the sad story of a local carpet factory which had closed its doors after 23 years of operation because of the state of economic affairs in Australia. The owner commented that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if we are out of recession then bring it back because business was better.
That is what we are looking at at the moment.

PARA.TAB: There are more businesses which will be affected, but this government seems not to care. That, of course, is so typical of this government's attitude to small business, whether they be in natural resources, such as granite, or in textiles, such as carpets or shirts. Typically, the government makes it tough for them to survive—and I do not envy those businesses one scrap, although I do admire their courage in the face of adversity.

When people said that it was bad through the recession of the early 1980s, they had not seen anything by comparison. Anyone who believes that the recession is now over and everything is just rosy has not gone out there into the community and talked to those operators in small business right across the market. They have not gone and talked to the real estate agents, for example; they have not gone and talked to the people who were supplying materials for new homes; they have not gone and talked to the real people who simply cannot afford to get into new homes. So here we have further and further examples.

This is a record of which those opposite should not be proud. And yet the way in which they carry on now with the introduction of more and more taxes is something that is just absolutely scandalous. They promised no new taxes at the last election. Yet, since the last election what we have seen is just a litany of new taxes and the abolition of or reneging on so many of the promises that were made.

But small business generally, as I say, has my greatest sympathy at the moment—in fact, they have had my sympathy for the last 12 to 13 years, as the Labor government has continued to tax them at a higher and harder rate than ever before. This is the legacy of this government. This is the way in which the Labor government operates, and it has to be recognised as such. When the government becomes so pedantic as to set mining aside from quarrying by playing with the words of a definition to suit their own ends and save them a measly amount, then I feel that they are really grasping as straws, and I hope that before too long they will find themselves banished into opposition.

I am sure that those owners and employees of quarries will concur with the comments I have made. They simply want to stay in business. They do not want to see a further tax impost. They are struggling enough as it is with the taxes they have had thrust around their necks. I would certainly hope that the way in which this is treated is for it to be reassessed totally by the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise very briefly to speak on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. We have been through this rather thoroughly—
—That's right, and you are going through it again—repeating yourself.

—Yes, we did go through it thoroughly—and, parliamentary secretary, I will get to why we are going through it a second time. We went through it thoroughly some months ago; in fact, it was around 29 June. I have a letter from the Minister of Mines in Western Australia who is very concerned about this situation. But he is not the only one who is concerned. Senator Knowles has very ably pointed out that there is a great deal of concern amongst the quarrying and mining industries, which I am not going to go over again. To get through to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Sherry, who is at the table, I think perhaps I should go over it again; but for the sake of time I will not.

PARA.TAB: But I make the point again that we have gone through this thoroughly and, for the benefit of the parliamentary secretary, I will quote what the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht, had to say. At Senate Hansard, page 2241, on 29 June 1995, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We will have open discussion and bend over backwards to accept those definitions to ensure that all of those who had been getting the rebate scheme would continue to get it.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, the amendments are not consistent with what was agreed to at the time. So, for those reasons, we believe that it should go back to a committee and be looked at again. That is the only way we will sort it out properly. All the advisers you have there were at that committee hearing and they sat through all that debate. I am sorry you will have to go through the committee process again.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're not sorry at all.

—I feel sorry for them. I am sorry you did not fix up the bill in the first place. That is what I am sorry about—that we have to be back here and do it again. There is other legislation for the good of all Australians that we should be getting on with; but, unfortunately, fill-in minister, you have not got this legislation right and we will be going back to it. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to confine my remarks in relation to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) to the limestone aspect of the legislation the government previously brought before the chamber and which they are trying to fix with this legislation. I am sorry the minister is not here because I really would like a comment from him in his summing up of this debate to try to clarify some aspects of this bill. That clarification may avert the need for calling a lot of witnesses to the Friday morning committee—and I stress, morning. So perhaps the parliamentary secretary or the advisers could advise me, in summing up the debate, on some of the answers to the questions that I might put.

PARA.TAB: I note in passing that the minister in charge of the bill is the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht). The legislation he is dealing with here is most debilitating to small business and to the construction industry. So one would think that he really should be called the minister for destroying small business and destroying the construction industry. I hope the minister in those capacities at least might understand what impact this customs legislation is having on small business and on the construction industry.

It also has an environmental aspect, which I am sure the Democrats and the Greens would be very interested in. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would be aware that toxic footprints are stealing across the Australian landscape, bringing destruction on a scale to dwarf other environmental threats. Ninety million hectares of fertile farmland face a slow chemical death as acid in the soil eats away at present production and future export potential. In a study released recently, the federal Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation pinpointed acid soils as the gravest resource and conservation issue facing the country and claimed that it was one of the most neglected. Acid soils already cost Australia $300 million a year in lost production—50 per cent more than salinity. We talk about salinity quite a lot. We do not talk about acid soils, yet it is destroying our farmlands.

Unless this problem is corrected now, losses will mount sharply. Part of the problem with acidity is that it is a chemical reaction in the soil and, unlike salinity, it does not strike people visually. Soil acidity is a natural consequence of any kind of farming. To maintain their internal PH, plants excrete acid substances into the soil. The constant removal of crops and pastures containing alkaline material means that most soils tend to go slowly acid. The process could be reversed by applying lime. I hope the parliamentary secretary is listening to my comments. By applying lime, you can address that enormous environmental problem.

Estimates suggest that about 35 million hectares of soil are highly acidic and that another 55 million hectares are moderately to slightly acidic. But just treating 1.5 million hectares where acid levels are dangerously high would require 2.3 million tonnes of lime at a cost of about $120 million. To protect and maintain the remainder would cost a further $130 million a year. Many farmers believe that they cannot afford such a huge up-front cost. The result is that 500,000 tonnes of lime are being applied annually, which is less than one-tenth of what is actually needed. The President of the Soil and Water Conservation Association, Mr Rick Farley, said that acid soil is the forgotten issue. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly a lot of farmers would like to do more about acid soils, but tragically that is out of the question in the present tight financial circumstances.

We have an acid soil problem, but we have a solution—limestone. But farmers cannot do anything about the problem because they currently cannot afford the cost of limestone. Through this legislation, the government will further increase the cost of limestone. Limestone producers tell me that this legislation will increase the cost of limestone by about 10 per cent. In round figures—it varies across Australia—the cost of limestone is about $20 a tonne. This will take the cost up to between $22 and $23 a tonne. It simply makes the situation more and more difficult. I would hope that the Democrats and Greens might be able to consider that point.

PARA.TAB: I raised this issue in a question on notice. I thank the department for providing me with the answer, which I received pretty late yesterday. I asked them whether the definition of `mineral' included the calcium carbonate, which is the principal part of limestone. I am not a technical person. I think I failed senior chemistry, and that will become pretty obvious in what I say in this technical area. But I hope I can get the message across. Limestone is principally calcium carbonate, which is a mineral. I asked the department whether companies which mine and crush limestone for the production of agricultural lime are eligible to claim the diesel fuel rebate, and I got this answer:

SPEECH.PARA: Under the amended definition of "minerals", diesel fuel purchased for use to extract limestone per se is not rebatable as limestone is not recognised as a mineral in its own right. But diesel fuel purchased for use to extract or crush limestone as an ore with a view to recovering from it a particular mineral or particular minerals will continue to be rebatable.

The industry people tell me that limestone is extracted for use of its mineral qualities—its calcium carbonate oxide. Does that mean that limestone extracted for the use of the calcium carbonate component—that is, its chemical and mineral qualities—is rebatable? I understand from the industry that, after you extract limestone, you crush it into varying sizes. Its exposure to soil does have an effect on the size of the final product. But, when the calcium carbonate component of the limestone spreads on acid soils, it leaches the soils, as I understand it. It is an alkaline substance and it takes away—

TALK.START.PARA: —Neutralises.

—Yes, it neutralises it. Senator Panizza obviously understands the technicalities much better than I do. Hopefully, I am getting across the problem to the parliamentary secretary and his advisers. Hopefully, in responding to this debate, the parliamentary secretary can say to me, `Yes, I agree with you and I agree that this answer that you received in writing to the question I put on notice does mean that if limestone is extracted and crushed for its use as calcium carbonate to neutralise acid soils, it is a mineral within the course of the definition and therefore is rebatable.'

PARA.TAB: The customs office is obviously having quite a deal of difficulty with this. I have been contacted by an enormous number of limestone producers—quarriers—and more recently by farmers' groups. It has taken some time for the message to get through to the farmers. They will not really understand the impact of this until the limestone producers take out the next load of lime to address acid soils and they have to pay 10 per cent more of it. At that stage the farming community will suddenly become very irate at this because it is an environmental thing. It is something that assists our export of primary production, yet they will be slugged this additional price for it. I know that the National Farmers Federation is now becoming interested in it as the full impact of the government's legislation is becoming known.

I understand that limestone is mined and used in different ways. Figures I have for 1989-90 tell me that nine million tonnes of limestone are used for the annual production of cement, 2.3 million tonnes are used in industrial lime and quick lime, 1.2 per cent is used in flux, 0.6 of one million tonnes is used for soil acidification treatment and water acidification treatment, seven million tonnes are used for construction and aggregate and 0.5 million tonnes are used for others—a total of about 20.6 million tonnes. Only one of those categories is not used for its mineral and chemical qualities—that is, for on the construction and aggregate industry. I understand from the industry that it is used in construction and aggregate simply as a replacement for blue metal. It is just used as a substance rather than for its chemical and mineral qualities. In every other instance—that is, in its cement production, in its industrial lime and quick lime use as a flux and certainly in soil acidification treatment, it is used for its mineral and chemical qualities.

My question that I would ask the parliamentary secretary to address in his response is: would he agree that the use of limestone for those other, except for construction in aggregate, does enable it to be classed as a mineral and therefore eligible for the diesel fuel rebate? As I said, the customs office is quite understandably confused about this. It is not a criticism; I simply do not blame them. It told one of the producers:

SPEECH.PARA: If you extract limestone, but because of its calcium carbonate content it is not regarded as limestone but as calcium carbonate, (Whatever percentage that has been recognised by industry standards as being calcium carbonate and not limestone) then it would be eligible.

People tell me that there is not an industry standard. They say to customs, `What do you mean by industry standards? Who makes the standard?' There are different definitions of calcium carbonate in the various state acts dealing with mining. They are not consistent, but I do not think it is the point. In this particular instance the person who has given me this, customs goes on to say:

Now with your crushing, if the crushing process further enhances (improves—such as more concentrated—this is just not blending or making in a saleable product) the calcium carbonate (not limestone) then it is eligible for rebate.

Again, I hope that the parliamentary secretary in his reply to the second reading debate will be able to say to me, `Yes, that is quite correct—providing you are crushing it, getting it to that finer stage so that it contacts with the soil in a greater area, then that is used as calcium carbonate, it is a mineral and therefore is eligible for the rebate.' I suspect that the government, in addressing this whole problem, did not focus as clearly on the environmental effects of the increase in the cost of production of limestone or on the effects on our agricultural exports. I am fairly certain—I am sure the parliamentary secretary would agree with me—that the government would not want to do anything that made it more difficult to address real environmental problems. Certainly, they would not want to do anything which would further debilitate our export earning ability from rural areas.

PARA.TAB: I hope the parliamentary secretary or the advisers can clarify those issues. I did put some of those questions on notice last night or early this morning. If we can get that clarified, as I say, it may well shorten the already short hearing into this matter when the committee meets on Friday. I know that, because of the environmental aspects of it, both the Greens (WA) and the Democrats would be very interested in the limestone issue. I am sure the government would also be interested in clarifying it.

I should mention that limestone is not only used to treat acid soils but it is also used fairly widely in treating cyanide ponds that result from mining activities of many years ago. Apparently, you can use this limestone to leach out all the harmful effects of those cyanide ponds. So it is a very necessary and useful material. We should be reducing the cost of it rather than adding to it. I hope that in my unlearned way I have got that message across and we can get a response from the parliamentary secretary that will clarify the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), I guess partly because we are responsible for it being here in the first place. This bill has arisen due to mistakes in drafting, mainly as a result of the rewording of our amendment that occurred on the floor of the chamber.

PARA.TAB: We would like to express our appreciation for what appears to be a very genuine attempt to correct wording to carry out the intention of the Senate. In terms of the supposed reduction of former application of the sweeper clauses and the reduction of quarrying, I think that was clear at the time of the introduction of the bill. The Greens (WA) have always pushed for a reduction in the subsidy to the mining industry represented by the diesel rebate. We have pushed, and will continue to push, for more substantial reductions than any included in the existing act. We voted not to apply retrospectivity to quarrying on the principle of separation of powers and respect for the judicial process in an area where Customs has never been clear on intent. Where we felt the intent of Customs and the legislature was clear, we allowed backdated clarification. But we were happy to allow the narrowing of applicability in a foreword sense.

As such, we would not support the offshore oil industry claims or the quarrying claims, and see no reason to send this bill to a committee. We support this bill as it stands, as a necessary clarification.
