DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (FAMILY MEASURES) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Family Measures) Bill 1995 will give effect to a number of initiatives announced in the 1995 budget, principally the maternity allowance, and introduce a single family payment. The legislation involves changes to the Social Security Act 1991, the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990, the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936, the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989, the Health Insurance Act 1973 and the Social Security (Non-Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Act 1995.

PARA.TAB: There are five measures incorporated in this bill. I will list them. The maternity allowance will be introduced to assist families with the additional costs incurred at the time of the birth of a baby, including reduced family income. The two existing payments of basic family payment and additional family payment will be amalgamated into a single family payment.

The bill also seeks to align the income and asset levels and indexation arrangements of family payment and Austudy. Amendments are included to increase the responsiveness of the family payment income test rule. Also, from 1 January 1996, family payment is to be payable to whichever member of a couple is the primary carer of a child. The coalition will not be opposing these measures. However, I would like to comment on a number of them.

Closer examination of the measures contained in this bill reveals that it is yet again a cynical exercise on the part of the government to hoodwink the Australian public into believing that the government is genuinely concerned about the welfare of families. If you look at the financial impact of each of the matters that have been addressed, other than the maternity allowance, you will find that in the main they are of very modest proportions and some of them, while they are held out to be beneficial to families, will have an adverse impact.

If you exclude the maternity allowance, the bill produces savings to the government; it does not produce new benefits to families. In particular, when you get to the increased responsiveness of the family payment income test, a large number of families lose benefits by the alignment of the adjustments that are made. Those who have received adjustments under average weekly earnings and now come to get them under the CPI will receive less in the nature of support than they received previously.

With respect to the maternity allowance, this is the most expensive item in terms of its financial impact. It will cost $78 million in the first year, and $184 million in the second and third years. The introduction of the maternity allowance is a further breach of good faith with the Australian public. The maternity allowance was heralded as part of the Accord Mark VII, which was announced on 19 February 1993, just before the last election. The Accord stated that the government would consider the introduction of a maternity allowance in accordance with the International Labour Organisation convention 103 entitled `Maternity protection'. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) also made a statement to this effect.

This turned out, like many other promises we had before the 1993 election, to be a total misrepresentation of what the government was actually going to do. It was a promise the Prime Minister either never intended to keep or had to break. The Australian public will have to be the judge of that. The government has all the resources to do the figures beforehand. It made a promise and it has broken it.

As the budget approached, it became clear that the government was not going to be able to honour that undertaking and it scuttled off to the ACTU, the other arm of government, to strike a new deal in relation to the allowance in exchange for an increase in the wage safety net. People were given less in the way of a salary and wage increase under the Accord.

As a result of that, they were promised there would be this maternity allowance in a budget that would follow, but it was not to be the same maternity allowance as promised before the 1993 election. If the maternity allowance had been implemented in accordance with the ILO convention, as the Prime Minister promised, it would have been for a period of 12 weeks. Instead, it is now to be for a period of six weeks and it is to be means tested.

You really cannot believe anything Mr Keating promises or says. The government promised before the election that the maternity allowance would be for 12 weeks; now we find it is only for six weeks. If the Prime Minister could find the money for only six weeks, why didn't he tell the Australian people before the election? That is the point. The Prime Minister was again toying with the emotions of families by promising them a payment and then changing the eligibility criteria.

We saw him do the same thing before the election, telling women they were going to get this enormous amount of money. In fact they found out it was just over $2.70. The government took another benefit off them, rejigged it, gave them $2.75—whacko, a whole new benefit. Talk about pea and thimble, lies and fibs before the election and, suddenly, the Australian public find out afterwards that this 12-week maternity allowance is now going to be only six weeks.

The government said that it was going to review the allowance to bring it into line with the ILO convention at some point in time up to 1989. But can you trust a government that has broken so many promises? We had the tax cuts that were going to be l-a-w law. The first tranche was stretched out, the second never appeared or reappeared as superannuation. But what happened to self-funded retirees who do not get superannuation? They got left out. Effectively, the government said, `Forget about them. We made a promise but we will just ignore self-funded retirees'.

Whatever group you are in, you get done in by this government in their promises before an election. You cannot trust a government that has broken so many of its promises. This bill is just another example of the government's lamentable record. It does not measure up to the government's promise, it does not measure up to community expectations and it should be understood for what it is.

Family payment presently consists of two components—basic and additional. They have similar payability and qualification rules but different rate structures and different income and assets tests. The Department of Social Security says that the payments are to be amalgamated to improve customer understanding. It states that there will be no changes to payments received by customers and eligibility will not be changed.

This measure is an attempt by the government to simplify their complicated payment system. Over a period of time, a number of welfare organisations have argued that the family payment system generally is in need of reform. Social Security has just been on a $200 million spending spree, producing an explanatory booklet that it has mailed out to all social security recipients. Obviously, the system is in need of reform.

There is a host of different support regimes in place: the child-care cash rebate; the home child-care allowance, which has now been subsumed into the parenting allowance; and the family payment system or, if you go outside it to other areas, child support arrangements. Each of them, in many cases, operates within different departments, each of them has different rules for eligibility and each of them provides an ad hoc arrangement for payment of family support.

The coalition agrees that this complicated system is in need of comprehensive review. The system cannot continue as it is. It is becoming increasingly complex, with different criteria applying to different benefits. I think the government also accepts that the system cannot continue as it is and recognises that changes need to be made but it finds the process of embarking upon such fundamental reform far too difficult.

The amalgamation of basic and additional family payment is an illustration of the ineptitude of the government when it comes to such reform. The government proposes under this legislation to merge the basic and additional family payment into one payment, with the same qualification rules but different rate structures and different income and assets tests. As a colleague in the House of Representatives has stated, about the only things that have changed are a title and a form. Contrary to any expectation, the change is next to negligible in terms of any fundamental reform of the system. It ought to be understood that this is another failure of the government to address the hard issues.

There are three other measures covered in this bill. First, aligning the income and assets levels in indexation arrangements for family payment and Austudy. Second, amendments to increase the responsiveness of the family payment income test. Thirdly, from 1 January 1996 family payments are to be payable to whichever member of a couple is the primary carer of a child.

While the coalition does not oppose these proposals, especially those in relation to the responsiveness of the family payment income test and the family payment being made to the primary care giver, I point out that the alignment of the income and assets levels in indexation arrangements for Austudy will have an adverse effect on many people. As mentioned previously, if you exclude maternity allowance, this bill actually produces savings to the government. Apart from the maternity allowance, it does not provide new benefits to families. The minister in his second reading speech quoted from the Agenda for Families, in which the Prime Minister noted:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . families are the basic building blocks of our national life. They provide care like no government or any other agency ever can. They are the most important providers of education, health, welfare and personal development. Families nourish our potential, and nurture our individual and collective aspirations. They shape our character and pass on our values. They create a sense of belonging and continuity . . . Because the welfare of our people and the strength of our communities and our nation depend on families, governments have a duty to support them.

I wonder how the Prime Minister can be so hypocritical that he can say this, and yet introduce policy after policy and broken promise after broken promise which have left families in an increasingly dependent state and less well off. That is what has happened after 13 years of Labor. Families are increasingly dependent, and they are less well off. Yet the Prime Minister has the hide to actually, the Agenda for Families, make that statement.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of points that need to be made about this government and families. First, its neglect of the welfare of families and its inability to deal with the increasing gap between rich and poor. The government's neglect of the welfare of families is evidenced by its inability to deal with the increasing inequality between the haves and the have-nots, the rich and the poor. I have spoken a number of times in this place about the increasing gap between those families who are able to manage financially and those families who are finding it more and more of a struggle every day.

You have to go no further than a report into poverty in Queensland a couple of months ago which emphasised this fact. The report contained a number of damning statistics, which illustrates the government's failure to assist the disadvantaged. I will just outline some of the things that study found.

Queensland had the lowest average weekly disposable income at $550 a week. Sole parent families, couples with three or more children and young single people have the greatest chance of being in poverty. One-fifth of the Queensland population lives in poverty; 18 per cent live below the poverty line; and 26 per cent of those in poverty are children. We were going to have no children living in poverty by the year 1990, if you believed Mr Hawke. Twenty-six per cent, a quarter of Queensland's children—and I do not have the figures here about the rest of Australia—live in poverty. No child was going to live in poverty, if you believed the previous Prime Minister.

The statistics showed that 27.2 per cent of elderly people live in poverty. Over a quarter of older Australians living in Queensland are living in poverty. Two in three sole parents exist below the poverty line. Two out of three families being reared by sole parents live below the poverty line. I hope the government is proud of that record and what it has done for families.

The second point that I want to make is the government's failure to introduce, as promised, a maternity allowance, as outlined in Accord Mark VII, and the postponement of any future effort to do so until 1999 in Accord Mark VIII. So the world will be a great place after the year 2000, if you believe this government. You will have some superannuation. If you are 25, you will be able to start on the full superannuation scheme. If you are a mother having a baby, you will get the maternity allowance by the year 2000. All these promises the government make they then extend out into the never-never. We ought to call it the never-never Labor government policy, because you wait for the never-never to see those policies come to fruition.

I would bet that if they ever get the chance of being in government after the next election—which I doubt, and I hope they do not, and I am working hard to make sure they do not—mothers will be unlikely to see that by 1999. There will be some other excuse. There be will be some pea and thimble trick. The Prime Minister will say, `Well, look, we didn't mean to say that. We'll give you something else. We'll convert it into some other benefit. We'll give it a new name. We'll doctor it up. We'll polish it up into some sort of flashy policy, and we'll tell you it's all new.'

The third point is that the government has misled the Australian public through the introduction of a number of measures affecting families which had not been announced and had not been policy prior to the 1993 election but were introduced after that election. After the last election, Labor introduced a number of measures for families which were not announced prior to the election. There is every possibility that the government will go down the same path after the next election. They do not change their spots, just as leopards do not change their spots. On the one hand they promise a whole swag of things and they either do not give them or tone them down, and on the other hand they say that they are not going to do certain things and suddenly after the election we find that they do.

In 1993 the government introduced no less than 10 new social security changes to the system which had not been announced before or during the 1993 election campaign. This information was deceitfully held from the voters. Some of these measures included reducing the income ceiling and assets value for the basic family payment, resulting in an estimated 118,000 families being excluded from the basic family payment. We did not see that on their brochures; we did not hear that mentioned in the election campaign.

We went to the last election with the most honest statement which could ever be put before the Australian public. We told them the good things and we told them the bad things. We told them the things we would have to do to turn this country around. What did this government do? It lied to the Australian public. It told them it was going to do things and then reneged on them and it did not tell them about other things it was going to do. The government did not tell the public it was going to include foreign payments in the income test for families, apply the income assets test to students' parents and change the rules relating to payment of overseas pensions.

It is time for me to go back over the government's record on this issue. All of these measures were quite cynically taken up by the government after the election. None of them was foreshadowed in the quite voluminous policy documents purported to be the government's mandate for the 1993 election. These were clearly matters about which the government had had advice and for which it had been preparing the scene well in advance of 1993. They knew what they were going to do. Is that the intention of this government as we move closer to the next election? Have they got things up their sleeves which will be released onto an unsuspecting public after the election?

Let the Australian public be warned of their record in the last election, because they will be no different this time. How many policies will Labor walk away from immediately after the next election? They told pensioners five days after the last election, `Oh, we didn't mean to tell you that we were going to take you out of the tax system by 1995. That was a mistake.' They said that five days after the election. They have walked away from promise after promise.

What about the retiring age for women? We honestly told people that we could not afford to have Australian women on the pension at age 60, that we would be increasing the age. We told them that before the election. What did Neal Blewett, the then Minister for Social Security, do? He made it very clear that was not part of Labor's agenda. He mocked us and said it was atrocious, what a terrible thing we were doing to Australian women. And what did Labor do straight after the election? They brought in legislation to increase the pension age for women. They lied to the Australian public, to Australian women.

Mr Keating got up after the election and said, `We thank the Australian women for voting us back in.' The government lied to Australian women. They mocked us; they criticised us. They did everything to denigrate our policies, including the policy of increasing the pension age for women, and they did it straight after the election. Time and again they have deceived the most vulnerable people in our community. They have trifled with their emotions. They have given assurances to them and walked away from them. I hope Australians remember the dishonesty of the people over on that bench in the lead-up to the next election.

Another measure in this year's budget that the government has failed to deliver relates to assistance for families. It has deferred until 1996 implementation of a modest measure in rent assistance and the guardian allowance. I could go on about some of the other promises that were stretched out but I do not have time. Making more families depend on social security is not the answer. The answer is to initiate policies which enable, encourage and support the majority of families to live independently from government support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Family Measures) Bill 1995, which contains, in the Greens' view, a number of worthwhile measures. Specifically, the bill gives legislative effect to the government's decision to pay a maternity allowance of $816 upon the birth of a child born to or adopted by a family which is eligible for the basic family payment or additional family payment. In the context of the government's family income support measures, this initiative has been welcomed by most people in the community, and rightly so. I will come back to the maternity allowance in a moment because there are aspects about its administration which cause concern.

PARA.TAB: The bill goes on to provide for the amalgamation of the basic family payment and the additional family payment—again, a worthwhile initiative. This is particularly to be welcomed because it also gives effect in this crucial area of income support to the minister's advocacy of a simpler social security system. In that regard, it is in sharp contrast to the proposed administration of the maternity allowance. The bill goes on to make changes to the family payment rates calculators—again, seemingly in line with attempts to simplify the system.

The bill also aligns the income and assets free areas for family payment and Austudy, another move towards simplification. Lastly, the bill makes the administration of family payment more responsive to the income changes which many families experience. This is particularly welcome as many families find that the present structure of annual changes, or changes only when income changes by a factor of 25 per cent, leaves them out of pocket for long periods of time.

The government is to be congratulated on any move to simplify the social security system and so we applaud such moves in this bill. I know that the minister has put considerable energy behind efforts to bring about these simplifications and it is to be hoped that there will be more to come. I will now come back to the maternity allowance because it is the one part of the bill which runs counter to that simplification trend.

To express my concern in its essence, I would want to ask the minister why the maternity allowance could not simply be paid by means of an over-the-counter cheque at a local DSS office when a person presents with a birth certificate and suitable identification. I am sure my question will draw howls of protest, not to say derision, from the department itself, from the minister and possibly even my colleagues. To quote Sir Humphrey, it would be `the end of civilisation as we know it'!

I appreciate that there is a fundamental flaw in the implication behind my question; namely, that the allowance is not universal. The government estimates that 223,000 such allowances will be paid each year, or on about 85 per cent of all births. Naturally, there is a significant difference in the amount that would be paid if the allowance were universal. It is a difference of approximately $30 million in a full year and I am not suggesting that we go down that path. However, that alone is not sufficient justification for this overly complex piece of drafting. I am led to believe that application for the allowance will be included in the family payment form, which begs the question: why do we have to have these 10 pages of legislation ostensibly to place a box on an existing DSS form?

The maternity allowance module, which the bill creates of course, provides for all the usual intrusions, including the need for the person and their partner to provide their tax file numbers and various other details. I particularly object to the inclusion of the tax file number requirements here as they are not even couched in language which allows the government to say that people are not required to provide their tax file number.

TALK.START.PARA: —And that was their promise.
—It was their promise, but I think the pretence that it is some kind of option or choice has been laid so totally bare that it is not even covered up by rhetoric any more.
—We should still refuse to accept it.

—If you are moving amendments to that effect, I might have a look at them, Senator Newman. Indeed, I cannot help but wonder why the Privacy Commissioner has not objected to the wording of proposed sections 900D and 900E.

PARA.TAB: Why do we need all this when the qualification for the maternity allowance is so simple? After all, every bit of the information sought in the new module will already be on file in the form of the person's application for family payment. Why are we setting up a new module for which the qualification criteria are set out quite succinctly in the explanatory memorandum and the minister's second reading speech? That speech said:

SPEECH.PARA: All families who meet the family payment residency and income and assets tests will qualify for maternity allowance.

Why is all this needed just to add a single box, paragraph or line on the family payment form? After all, adding a newborn child to a Medicare card to entitle that child to medical care within that system takes only a tick in a box. Why could the maternity allowance not be made a part of the family payment module? I can guess that, if I were to put my questions to the minister and his department, I would receive one of the following responses.

PARA.TAB: The first response might be: `Each payment type or allowance in the act is structured as a separate module. Therefore, we have to structure this new payment in the same way with all the attendant questions, particulars and details.' To which I would have to reply: `That may well be the case but, since payment in this case is a once only event and qualification is tied to the family payment, it must be possible to make this simpler.'

The second response might be: `We have to ensure that we do not pay maternity allowance to someone who is not qualified for it.' To which I would have to reply: `But that is already taken care of by the assessment of the claim for family payment.' Or the third response might be: `We couldn't possibly pay it by a cheque over the counter because that is contrary to the way the payment system has moved over the years.' To which I would have to reply: `That may be so, but the way this is structured will inevitably cost far more to administer than payment by cheque, especially as this is a once only payment.'

At the risk of providing ammunition to those who still regard the Greens as fairies at the bottom of the garden—and I think the number of those people are diminishing, but there are still a few left—I would like to see the payment of the maternity allowance provide an opportunity for celebration at DSS offices, and goodness knows there seems to be precious few of those. Why shouldn't the local office manager be empowered to provide a cheque in a suitable card—a birthday card perhaps—making it akin to the way we celebrate a migrant taking on Australian citizenship?

TALK.START.PARA: —They spend money on balloons.

—Absolutely. This is an event worth celebrating in most families. Even though $816 will not really be that much when you consider the overall expenditure on a newborn child, it might be a way of lightening and improving the perception of the department in the eyes of many of its allowance recipients. I believe that the way this measure has been drafted runs completely counter to the minister's commitment to simplifying the social security system. In the words of the latest edition of the `Rights Review' by the Welfare Rights Centre, the social security system is:

SPEECH.PARA: a system which, after 48 years, has not managed to develop a single, generic claim form to allow DSS staff to assess the most appropriate payment for an individual. Instead, there is a pick-a-box system, with over 25 pigeon holes, each with its own elaborate set of rules with the claimant responsible for picking the right payment first off.
Again, the `Rights Review' said it is:

a system in which people are so disenfranchised by change and complexity they can't understand and can't check that the value of an otherwise fair and effective appeal system is diminished to the point of inaccessibility.

There must be a simpler way to establish the maternity allowance and I hope I have supplied a critique of that. The Greens will support this bill, so the maternity allowance will be able to get under way at least. We have no plans at present to put amendments before the chamber, but I would appeal to the minister to go to his department, put my questions to the officers and seek their cooperation in having another look at this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Family Measures) Bill 1995 which, as my colleague Senator Patterson said, we do not oppose. I would like to make a number of comments on proposals contained in this bill and on the general issues relating to government assistance to families. The major aspect of this bill is the maternity allowance, and people have focused upon that.

PARA.TAB: It has to be said that the maternity allowance itself has had a rather tortured birth. It was originally meant to be part of Accord Mark VII and was to be work related and a non-income tested 12-week payment. All the hopes and aspirations that the unions may have had for this part of Accord Mark VII have been dashed. There was a lot of community concern about the original framing of the allowance, because there was inherent discrimination against non-working mothers.

We come back to the debate we had earlier this week about what the government is doing with child care. Again, the original proposal on the maternity allowance was to seek to draw this extraordinary distinction between mothers in `paid work' and mothers in `non-paid work'. There was a lot of reaction. The government has wilted in the face of that reaction and has now brought in the maternity allowance on a basis which we think is much more acceptable. It will be paid regardless of the work status of the mother, which we believe overcomes one of the major problems we thought was inherent in the original proposal; and it will be subject to an income and asset test, which we think is most appropriate. On that basis, we welcome the payment and support the maternity allowance.

But I think Senator Chamarette, who has now departed, had a point in saying that it, of itself, does add now again to the complexity of the family assistance programs—and that is the oddity in this bill: we have one measure in this bill designed to simplify the system, and another measure which will make it more complex. The complexity of the system is a major issue, as I think Senator Chamarette pointed out very well.

While we support the allowance itself, one does wonder whether all options were looked at as to how one could assist young families on the birth of a child, without creating a whole new allowance and a whole new bureaucracy to administer it. It was wondered whether it could be done as part of the family payment system, which I think the government is now moving towards being the core, the main vehicle of assisting families; perhaps it could have been built around that. That is something I think worth looking at, but that is not to deny our support for what is being done.

However, we do believe that Australians have good reason to be cynical about the payment of the allowance. The fact that the payment will commence being paid on 1 February 1996 really does raise eyebrows right across Australia, given the coincidence of the timing of that payment with the due date for a federal election.

The other major element of the bill is the amalgamation of the basic and additional family payments. This really does represent a belated, albeit welcome, government response to the increasing complaints about the confusion and complexity of the family assistance programs that the government administers. I would refer to some of the reaction to that.
The government's own National Council for the International Year of the Family, in its quite interesting report to the parliament, said:

SPEECH.PARA: It was also felt that simplification of the system of family payments would enhance access and clarify entitlements as many parents expressed confusion about the range of available payments.

Any one of us with an electoral office which tries to help voters will be well aware of the extraordinary confusion people have about the payments available—and, again, Senator Chamarette identified them very well. There was an interesting piece by Tom Dusevic in the Weekend Australian only recently. He is that paper's social welfare writer. He pointed to this problem, I thought, quite effectively. He said in that article:

PARA.TAB: Social engineering in Australia is a mishmash, with conflicting goals, muddy rationales and perverse outcomes.

So-called "family friendly" policies subsidise the cost of rearing children through the tax and benefit system; favour the notion of two working parents; and generally are geared to helping the poorest families, especially those headed by sole parents, the fastest growing type.
But the social system does not reward or encourage marriage, sometimes undermines the nuclear family, and often erodes the work ethic and keeps people on welfare.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an independent observer of the social security system pointing to what is an extremely complex, confusing system that the government presides over. Sure, the government is spending a lot of money on family assistance—and, as a party that strongly supports assisting families, we support that. But the way in which the money is expended with the programs the government administers leaves a lot to be desired.

PARA.TAB: So we do welcome this bill's amalgamation of the basic and family payments system. It is a sensible move; it will help simplify the system. Of course, the payments were just one payment, until the government, in another election move at a previous election, decided to split them and create the additional family payment. Now they have brought them back together again, which will make it more user friendly.

Those two measures in this bill are to be welcomed. But I would take this opportunity to express my disappointment that this is as far as the government has gone; that this is the limit of the government's reform program to help families with children. We think these are only a couple of small steps down a path which the government should be proceeding but which it shows no signs of proceeding down.

In particular, I am extremely disappointed that so far the government has done absolutely nothing to end one of the most discriminatory aspects of its policy program in relation to families—and it is an inequity which I have pointed to many times before and I will keep drawing attention to it until the government does something about it—and that is the gross inequity in the treatment of young families with children that is inherent in the operation of the home child-care allowance, now rolled into the parenting allowance, and the child-care cash rebate. I have, as I said, spoken on this subject many times and I will keep speaking on it.

When those policy programs emerged a couple of years ago it aroused an enormous bushfire of community concern. There are nationwide movements now propelled by the incredible inequities that are inherent in the operation of those two payments. I want to remind the Senate of the inequity we are talking about. The home child-care allowance, which I will call it for the purposes of distinguishing it from the other half of the parenting allowance, for a mother of two means that she can receive a maximum of $30.50 per week. There is a very strict income test on eligibility. If the recipient earns more than $30 a week, the benefit starts to reduce. I think it cuts out completely at around $85 a week.

On the other hand, child-care cash rebate for a mother of two amounts to a maximum of $61.20 a week—twice the amount that a mother of two on the home child-care allowance receives. Of course, with the child-care cash rebate there is no income test whatsoever. It is paid regardless of the income of the recipient. It would seem to be designed for wealthy, two income families working in the Public Service in Canberra. Two parents working in the bureaucracy in Canberra earning $60,000 or $70,000 each a year—a family income of about $140,000—will receive up to $61.20 a week from the taxpayer to pay for their child care. This is an extraordinary inequity.

It is so deceptive of the government. If you read the literature on the home child-care allowance, you will see that they disguise all this by referring to it being a payment of $61.20 a fortnight so that it appears to be the same as the payment that is made under the child-care cash rebate—but that is $61.20 a week. So they cleverly disguise the fact that it is half the value, which I think is grossly deceptive and scandalous in the way they try to deceive mothers, as Senator Patterson said about this issue in her speech.

We think this is a dreadful inequity. It is a deliberate bias, in our view, against a mother who sacrifices her income to care for her children at home. It is a significant sacrifice that many mothers in this community still make, despite government policy seeming to be very much favoured towards the choice of full-time work and putting your child in child care. The fact is that single income families who make that choice of sacrificing one parent's income for full-time care of the child are subsidising child care for the rich via the operation of these two payments. We think that is grossly inequitable.

When the child-care cash rebate was first proposed, we said very strongly that it should be income tested to ensure that there was not this kind of inequity operating. The government of course overrode that to ensure that it would be payable to anybody, no matter their income—no matter whether they are two solicitors in Sydney both earning $300,000 a year, they can still earn this money from the government.

It is not just us complaining about this. Peter Walsh, your former finance minister, has complained about this long and hard. The government's own advisory body, the National Council for the International Year of the Family, to which I have already referred, drew attention to these problems in its report. This is a government body with people on it appointed by the government. Their report, which makes good reading, criticised the operation of these two payments, albeit in a couched manner, because it was a government report. But it was quite clear what they were talking about.

They said in that report that there was `a compelling case for restructuring the system of family income support payments in families with young children under the age of six.' In other words, they are saying that the system is wrong and it needs restructuring. The report said, `The National Council believes that the principle of choice to remain outside of paid work or to combine paid work with employment should be made effective for parents of preschool children.' That is Chinese for saying that choice is not effective at the moment. They have said that the principle of choice to remain outside of paid work should be made effective. In other words, it is not effective right now.

The fact is that government policy is designed to reward the parents of young children who choose to undergo full-time paid work. The fact is that it penalises the choice of parents who sacrifice income in order to care for their young children. As I said, the national council drew attention to this problem in a very effective way and recommended the amalgamation of the child-care cash rebate and the home child-care allowance into a new payment, which it called the child-care payment. That was their method of overcoming what they said was a major problem in the operation of these two payments. So I am not saying this; it is the government's own advisory body.

The national council specifically made the point that the new payment would provide recognition of the unpaid work of care which all carers undertake. In other words, they are drawing attention to the fact that the current system of payments does not do that; it does not provide recognition of the unpaid work of carers. Full-time care of children by parents is not properly recognised by this government.

The national council wanted this child-care payment to be paid without any income or assets test. They wanted it to be paid at a rate similar to that of the home child-care allowance. The government has said that the problem with that proposal is that it would be expensive, and we agree. It is not realistic to make such a payment universal. We have criticised the child-care cash rebate because it is universal. We accept that the national council's proposal cannot be universal. We believe that, if you were going to do something like that, it would have to be subject to an income and assets test.

I believe that what the national council has said to the government—that is, that it should amalgamate these two payments into one child-care payment paid regardless of the work status of the parents—is worthy of consideration. We urge the government to consider that proposal. That is not the only way to go in order to overcome this anomaly. If you are going to have a tax rebate system, which is what the government says it wants, you could make that apply to child care and pay it regardless of the work status of the two parents. You have to keep the focus on children. One of our criticisms of the government is that it does not keep the focus on children. You are discriminating against children whose parents work full-time. You need to approach this issue on the basis of not discriminating in that way. You could have a tax rebate which does not discriminate on the basis of the work status of the parents. That would be another way to go.

The primary goal must be to end this discrimination against families who care for their own preschool children. That discrimination exists and has been pointed to by the government's own advisers. This issue was a key concern raised with the coalition's own Lyons Forum when it had a recent inquiry into family policy. The report called Empowering Australian families summarised the concerns raised in the course of our inquiry by families and family organisations right across Australia. It was a bipartisan look at the operation of family policy at the moment. It pointed to this particular problem. We got a lot of submissions across Australia from a wide variety of groups which pointed to this problem.

The point I want to make is that we are not seeking special treatment for single income families in the design of the policy. What we are seeking in pursuing this issue is neutrality in government policy. We want a non-discriminatory family policy. In the debate on the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill the other day, we argued that we want the government to end age discrimination. We want the government to end its discriminatory family policy and to have a non-discriminatory family policy.

The point is that the government should be seeking to maximise—not restrict—the choice available to families as to how they bring up their children. I refer to what Barry Maley, in his very good book entitled Marriage, divorce and family justice, had to say on this subject, and all members of parliament would be well advised to read this book. In chapter 11, which deals with child care, he concluded with these words:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . all parents of dependent children should be treated equally; all should be entitled to the same level of subsidy or tax concessions in respect of each child; and no group's treatment or concessions should be made conditional upon making career or family choices favoured by the state.
I do not think the point I am trying to make could be said better than it was said by Maley in that book. We continue to urge the government to go down that path.

PARA.TAB: In closing, I reiterate that the introduction of the maternity allowance and the amalgamation of the two payments under the family payment system into a single family payment are supported by us. My point is to draw attention to the fact that the government has so far failed to address the other problems in the family assistance program and, in particular, the failure to address what we believe is an unacceptable inequity in the operation of the old home child-care allowance, now part of the parenting allowance, and the child care cash rebate which, as I said, is not just our complaint but the complaint of its own National Council for the International Year of the Family.

Government policy does interfere in the choices that families make about the care of their children. It does bias choice in one direction and penalises an alternative choice. We think that is unacceptable. As I said, our position is supported by your own national council. So this bill makes a small step towards overcoming what we believe are a number of problems inherent in the government's family assistance programs, but it does not go nearly far enough.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Family Measures) Bill 1995 seeks to put in place a range of measures proposed in the budget to provide social security assistance to families. During those budget sessions and over the last fortnight at the women's conference in Beijing we heard a lot about this government's commitment to families. This bill exposes the fact that in too many areas Australia is well behind the rest of the industrialised world in achieving a better balance between working women and men and family responsibilities. A key failing is that Australia presently shares with the United States the dubious honour of being the only industrialised country not to provide paid maternity leave. From February next year—and the introduction of this $816 baby bonus—we will leave the United States at the bottom of the list and move up to providing only the second worst level of support to new mothers.

PARA.TAB: There is one tick that is due to the government—that is, I think it is true that we do have some very well targeted family payments. This bill does help remove some of the confusion surrounding family payments by combining additional family payments and basic family payments. This is a welcome initiative. At an annual average cost of $1.8 million over three years, it can hardly be described as extremely generous or radical. Indeed, the benefit of the combination of the payments is more than offset by the full year savings of $16.5 million from the other measures modifying the income and assets test for family payments in this bill.

It is disappointing that the government has declined to improve the support provided to low income families. The last time the additional family payment was increased was in the wash-up to the 1993 budget and under pressure from the Democrats and the Greens in the Senate. In this budget I am pleased to see that the government has finally responded to the increasingly stringent concern from ACOSS and welfare groups as they have outlined the dire financial position of sole parent families. The government has agreed to increase the guardians allowance by a grand total of $2 a week from the dim and distant date of 1 September 1996. So from now until then, tens of thousands of sole parent families will have to wait until the government gives them what is equivalent to another loaf of bread.

Other key measures in the so-called family friendly budget included savings of over $262 million in child-care assistance over the next four years at a time when women are still saying that they cannot find enough child-care places. By raising these issues, I want to make it clear that the Democrats believe that the government still has a great deal of work to do to address the key issue of achieving a better balance between work and family responsibilities.

The key measure in this bill is the baby bonus or, more correctly put, the lump sum maternity allowance which is to be set at six times the parenting allowance, in turn equal to the spouse's rate of unemployment benefits. It is the Democrats view that this level of support falls well short of the obligations under international treaties—treaties that Australia is unable to ratify because of our poor performance and commitment.

The key convention is ILO convention 103 concerning maternity protection, which requires member nations to provide, by national legislation, an entitlement to at least 12 weeks maternity leave, generally at a rate of at least two-thirds or more of a woman's previous earnings. The ILO now recommends a period of paid leave of at least 14 weeks at 100 per cent of previous earnings. Similarly, the European Commission issued a directive in October 1992 to encourage the safety and health at work of pregnant workers and workers who had recently given birth. European Community members are now required to guarantee paid maternity leave of at least 14 weeks, paid at the statutory rate of sick leave, which in most member countries is 75 per cent of previous pay.

Many European countries have gone much further. Sweden provides up to 15 months paid parental leave available to either the mother or the father. This, combined with up to 60 days paid carer's leave a year and widespread provision of child care, has given Sweden the highest female labour force participation rate in the world. In Germany, the law provides for 14 to 18 weeks at basically full pay. In the United Kingdom, it is 18 weeks—six weeks at 90 per cent of pay and 12 weeks at a fixed allowance.

Germany, of course, also allows a parent who stays at home to look after their child to keep many of the benefits and securities of their previous job. In Canada, paid maternity leave ranges from a minimum of 15 weeks at 60 per cent of salary to as many as 26 weeks at full pay in the federal wages jurisdiction. Closer to home, Japan provides 14 weeks leave paid at 60 per cent of earnings, Taiwan and Singapore, eight weeks on full pay and Hong Kong, 10 weeks on two-thirds pay. The point of ranging across those examples is to say that this is no you-beaut, super deal. It is a step forward but it is not deserving, I think, of the gloss that has been put on it.

In Australia, in a little known exception, Australia has failed to ratify article 11(2)(b) of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women, which binds states to take all appropriate means to introduce maternity leave with pay or with comparable social benefits without loss of employment, seniority or social benefits.

As can be seen when this bill is passed, we will be providing for six weeks pay at effectively 23 per cent of average weekly earnings of full-time women workers. This is really quite pathetically short of the mark. It falls well short not just of international best practice—which is something we like to pluck out of the air as it applies to other things when it suits us—but also of the performance of virtually all industrialised countries. It falls well short of even the minimalist position demanded by the ACTU in Accord VII and by the Year of the Family Committee headed by Bettina Cass of 12 weeks pay or the equivalent of unemployment benefits.

Under Accord VII, the government was supposed to deliver paid maternity leave by implementing ILO convention 103. The delivery in the 1995 budget is clearly well short of what was promised and expected. Australian women who are wondering when Australia will live up to its international obligations must be disappointed that the ACTU has let the government off the hook in Accord VIII, signed two months ago.

I make these points because the ACTU is usually a very fierce defender of ILO conventions. The same ACTU which is asking the government not to deliver the ILO recommendation of 14 weeks leave at 100 per cent of salary or even to ratify ILO convention 103, is saying, `Look, it's okay, just get into the spirit of it, just show that you're delivering something.' And that something is the $816 baby bonus.

I recall the ACTU welcoming the budget proposals on budget night as delivering support to those who need it, particularly women and families. But this was the same budget in which the government could find only $180 million to help Australian women and their families through the physically and financially stressful period of childbirth. In that same budget it was this government which could find $4.6 billion to prop up a superannuation deal with the ACTU—the overwhelming proportion of which will be paid to male workers earning up to $62,000 a year.

I know that we do not have the same social contract climate of the European countries—I know and understand that. I know that we are clawing our way upwards. I know that people usually say we cannot afford to do it. But the full cost of providing maternity leave to women in the Australian work force represents just 0.2 per cent of total payroll, that is, less than a third of the amount companies pay for company cars for, mostly male and mostly managerial, employees. So you can make choices.

Having seen the support that European countries are providing to working mothers during maternity, I think it is a bit embarrassing that this is the best that Australia can offer. This bill takes us only a small way or a part way towards the European standard. It takes us towards about 10 per cent of the entitlement. So at the committee stage I will be moving an amendment to allow us to at least come up to the minimal standards of Accord VIII and the spirit of the ILO convention to 12 weeks social security support over two budgets.

Before I conclude, I wish to compliment the government on one aspect of this bill: the recognition that maternity allowance should be paid to both women in the work force and women out of the work force. The period following the birth of a baby is financially stressful for any family, particularly where only one partner was previously in the work force. I am pleased the government has recognised this fact by not restricting that support to women in the work force. As I said, it is just a pity that the level of support is so low.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening to the contributions from my Senate colleagues in this debate. It is interesting to note that the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Family Measures) Bill 1995 actually passes into law great good news for Australian families: the maternity allowance and the much better streamlined and simplified arrangements for payments to families. You would have thought from listening to a lot of my colleagues, particularly the opposition, that this was a matter of great disappointment, that this was a dirge.

PARA.TAB: Senator Minchin's contribution was really best described as, `We're debating apples, so let's talk about pears.' He did not really want to address the issue we are talking about here. It is a very grudging and, as I say, gloomy assessment of what this bill is about—`Oh, yeah, we'll support it'. But it is actually a very significant piece of legislation.

I heard Senator Kernot's contribution. I thank you for that litany of other countries' payments, Senator Kernot. I think a lot of people will be interested to read that. It may look as though, when compared with other countries, we may not be doing so well. But when comparing what we are doing now with what will happen after 1 February, this is a mighty advance—$816 to each family on the occasion of a birth of a baby after 1 February, and it will probably be marginally more than that by that time. I stress that it will be $816 per family per child on the occasion of the birth.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did you tell them before the election?

—I have heard some mad interjections in my day—`Why didn't we tell them before the election?' We are saying that from time to time this government will introduce changes, improvements, that will assist—
—To their policies.

—Of course, Senator. If you are a reforming government and concerned about getting it right for the community, you are always pleased to introduce initiatives and benefits to the community. This is great good news. Senator Kernot's lines were very appropriate when she said, `This maternity allowance recognises the physically and financially demanding time of having a baby.' That is a very nice way of putting it.

PARA.TAB: We recognise the costs to families at the time of a birth of a child. It is a very useful, very significant watershed type, payment. Those of us who are old enough might remember that we used to have a maternity payment years back. It got lost; it was removed, taken away. Now there is a payment to Australian families produced by the government in recognition of the costs at the time of having a baby.

I have heard Senator Minchin say—and I think he is really having a shot at me; he usually is—that I am wrong when I say on the government's behalf that it does not interfere with what families are doing. We do not dictate to families how they sort out arrangements between themselves. We do not dictate to families whether they should be in the work force or not. Senator Minchin says, `Of course you do because of the payments you give them.' But apparently in this case that is not so.

Senator Minchin is not suggesting that the maternity allowance will lead to massive breeding of the Australian people. He apparently does not see the argument for interference applying here. It only applies with the one bee in his bonnet about whether or not we are forcing people into the work force. It is tired argument, Senator Minchin, and I will deal with that in a minute.

The maternity allowance is a great benefit payment. This is a payment that families of Australia will be very pleased to accept and will welcome. The streamlining and simplifying of the administrative arrangements will also be a great benefit to families. Certainly we recognise the complexities of those payments. That is why we have taken and will continue to take more and more steps over time to simplify and make those payments family friendly.

I draw to the attention of the Senate the document released by Social Security and sent to so many families outlining the payments for families by this government—family payments, the child care payments and so on—so that families do understand what their entitlements are and what steps they might have to take to enjoy those benefits. I would hope that most people—and I am absolutely sure that most people—in seeing and reading that document will not feel that they are being manipulated but will feel that they are being recognised as having needs—the need to bear costs, the need of assistance that families have in this country. I would also hope that most people would recognise this government's great commitment to Australian families through payments, services and now, with the great initiative of this legislation, the maternity allowance.

I want to pick up on some of the points that Senator Minchin put out yet again, quoting somehow that we should treat all children the same. Out of context I could not say what that line really means. I know what I mean about how we help children. That goes to another point mentioned by Senator Kernot—that is, targeting payments. That means we assist families with lower incomes in a different way from how we assist families with higher incomes. In other words, we do not treat all children the same. We are actually directing and skewering our assistance to families at the lower end of the income scale.

Senator Minchin keeps on with the idea that we are assisting families or directing families into the work force and that we provide more assistance to families when two parents are working than if one parent is at home. They are simply not the facts. Overall, this government's payments to Australian families, about $12 1/2 billion, are very significantly directed to single income working families and our low income families.

It is a very important point to keep reminding the people of Australia that Senator Minchin got it wrong. The majority of Australian government payments to families go to single income and low income families. That is about the government's clear objectives and priorities about assisting families at the lower income end of the scale as a priority.

Those payments are now amalgamated into one family payment, including the basic family payment and the additional family payment. The additional family payment is a very good payment of about $35 or $42, depending on whether children are up to 13 or older than 13. Those payments were set as benchmarks by this government a few years ago. That is an extraordinary initiative on behalf of recognising the costs of raising and having children. They were also indexed. We recognise that those costs do need to keep pace with the general cost of living in society. They are very generous, very excellent payments, now more easily provided to families than ever before.

I understand that Senator Chamarette thought that we might change the way the maternity allowance was made. I am sorry I did not hear Senator Chamarette's contribution but I understand that she was suggesting it could be paid as an over-the-counter cheque with a card saying, `Congratulations on having a baby.'

We hope that everybody in our society celebrates the birth of babes but it is appropriate to make sure payments to families, which is the main task of the Department of Social Security, are provided in the most efficient, effective and simple way. By and large, a cheque over the counter would not advantage most families and would certainly disadvantage many by them having to turn up and collect those cheques. It would also be very much more expensive for the department. If we are looking at efficiencies and the best way to assist families we would not want to be doing that.

I also cannot see the department going to the cost of producing congratulatory cards. They might want to stamp it on the cheque—you never know. But is there anything more joyous than the arrival of a new baby. Hopefully, those babies will be born into families that can provide that sort of joyous celebration.

Senator Patterson raised points of concern about the complexities of the family payment system. She suggested that the opposition wants a comprehensive review. Do I do justice to your comments, Senator?

TALK.START.PARA: —Should be reviewed.

—Senator Patterson is suggesting that there should be a comprehensive review of family payment. This government has an ongoing concern to simplify and streamline the payments for families, never forgetting to target them, and setting the benchmark of the additional family payment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Patterson does not say what she would do if there were a review. She does not say whether, if the opposition were ever in government, they would do such a review. I do not know what sense you could make of her comments as a serious contribution.

In summary, here is a piece of legislation that is really good news for the community. It has come out of this last budget and recognises the important concerns of families and, in particular, the costs associated with having a baby, providing a very generous maternity allowance at the time of the birth.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much do you get for twins?
—You get twice as much, Senator. It is an interesting question you ask. I have just checked on it myself. If you want to try for six, just keep going.
—Last time they didn't do that.
—Is that right? You got one amount for twins before?
—Yes.
—There we are; this government is ever improving the system.
—He has a vested interest.
—A hereditary predilection to twins in the family; is that right? You had probably better take out insurance too.
—I reckon he is past it.

—I think I did not hear that, Senator Herron. I want to close my remarks by coming back to the points raised by Senator Kernot who said that, by comparison, this is a very miserable amount. I know you did not quite put it like that, Senator, but I think I can interpret it that way. It is important to remind ourselves that the important comparison here is between the present arrangements for families and the benefits after 1 February.

PARA.TAB: You also do allow, albeit in a sort of slipping it over way, that there are questions like whether the budget will be in surplus or not—the overall big picture. The costs of introducing changes like this, particularly when we are looking at something like 223,000 babies being born in a year, mean that it is a very significant contribution against the budget. The initial step to get this significant introduction is going to be a dramatic change for families compared with the situation now.

I think it is a matter of celebration, not miseries—as the opposition would have it—or grudging comparisons from Senator Kernot. I would like to close by saying: yes, I hear your argument, Senator Kernot, but the government will not be supporting your amendments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had a choice of moving two amendments. I had two drafted. The first one sought to double it immediately—to get the government to honour the promise that I believe it made, particularly via the Accord—but the amendment I am moving is actually more fiscally responsible.

PARA.TAB: I heard what Senator Crowley said about budget bottom lines and surpluses. The amendment I am moving actually leaves the allowance, the baby bonus, at $816 for 1995-96, but doubles it for 1996-97. It would cost $184 million—that is true—but it is this government which is trumpeting that we are going to be in hefty surplus in 1996-97, even counting asset sales. We are going to have a hefty surplus, so governments have choices, and here is the choice of honouring a commitment.

What I think is philosophically wrong with the way the government has chosen to do this is this. A lump sum baby bonus takes away, in my view, from the argument of the legitimacy of an extended period of paid maternity leave. That is the choice. For me, that legitimacy is what is more important. Sure, the money in a lump sum will be helpful, but it does not address that period after a baby's birth when people need the financial security of knowing that there is going to be a continuing regular source of income. You can choose to say, `I'm going to divide that $816 over 12 or 14 weeks,' and it is not much. So that is what I think is philosophically a problem with the way the government has chosen to do it.

As I say, this amendment will cost zero in 1995-96; it will cost $184 million in 1996-97. It is this government that is talking up the amount of the surplus we are going to have. It is this government which can honour the commitment that it made via the Accord to do more to assist families in balancing work and family responsibilities. I see this as one important way of doing it. I seek leave to move my amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendments:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Schedule 1, page 6, item 1, proposed subsection 900F(1), omit "The amount of maternity allowance", substitute "Subject to subsection (3), the amount of maternity allowance".
2.Schedule 1, page 6, item 1, proposed subsection 900F(1), at the end, add the following subsection:
"(3) On and from 1 July 1996 the amount of maternity allowance in respect of a child is twice the amount of maternity allowance in respect of a child under subsection (1).".

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, could you remind the Senate of when this bill was first before the Senate?
—I understand we cannot give you an accurate answer to that. We will take that on notice.
—Can you give me a rough answer?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator West)—The second reading debate in this place was adjourned on 22 August.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is enough.
—The end of last sittings.

—We were debating it on 22 August, so it has been around for a while. The Australian Democrats circulated an amendment yesterday. We were faxed the amendment yesterday and it was circulated in the chamber yesterday. I find it difficult that the Democrats produce an amendment for increased expenditure and expect the coalition to make a decision on the run without consultation.

PARA.TAB: I admit that the government, on 19 February 1993, prior to the election, through Accord Mark VII, intimated to the Australian public that there would be 12 weeks maternity leave, that there would be double the amount that they now give. As I said in my second reading contribution, that was a breach of good faith of the Australian public. The Australian public have to realise that the government they elect is the government they get. That is what the government promised before. That is what people expected. This is now what they are getting.

With all due respect to you, Senator Kernot, we should sit down and add up—I have not done this exercise, but it is one we ought to do—every time we have come into the chamber on an issue where you have said, `It costs only $148 million. This will cost only another $500 million. This will cost only another $10 million. This will cost only another $12 million.' When we add that all up, we find that we have got budgetary problems. It is much easier for you to sit there and say, `We'll just spend a few more million here and a few more million there.' We have a debt we have to pay back. If we go into surplus, it is not money that we can go frivolously spending. This government has put this country into huge debt. I do not think the Democrats sit down and think very seriously about every time they come into this chamber with `just another amendment which will make a difference'.

The government promised before the election that this would be different. They have hoodwinked the Australian public, and I hope they are sorry about that. But, given the fact that the amendment came so late, given the fact that it has budgetary implications, given the fact that the government has reneged on its promise—that is what the Australian people have to live with—the coalition is not in a position to support the request of the Democrats.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put a couple of comments on the record. Again referring to that litany of where Australia stands compared to other countries, I am advised that it is relevant to take into account total support for low income families. Doing that in the comparison between countries, including European countries, makes Australia come out toward the top of the list of the most generous countries. So that one item of comparison does not give us the kind of comprehensive picture—

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose we could get into a debate about what is in Senator Kernot's figures and what is in mine, but I just wanted to put that on the record. We are now specifically addressing the amendment moved by Senator Kernot on behalf of the Australian Democrats. While the government is going to reject that amendment, it may be of some encouragement to you, Senator, to know that the government is committed to reviewing the maternity allowance with a view to improving it or extending it as economic and budgetary circumstances permit, as set down in Accord Mark VIII with the ACTU and consistent with the spirit of ILO convention 103. That convention identifies 12 weeks maternity leave through social security arrangements as an appropriate goal. Doubling the rate of the maternity allowance, as you say, Senator, on today's figures is $184 million. That would make a total of $368 million.

PARA.TAB: The government will keep its commitment to review the maternity allowance but in the context of budgetary and economic circumstances. I do not think you were actually saying, Senator Kernot, that you agree that there will be a hefty surplus as an assurance—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, you were saying that.
—I do understand the point you were making.
—Are you saying that there won't be?

—Not at all. I wanted to be clear that that was not an absolute assurance that that was the case and you knew it to be so. What I am saying, though, is that the difficulty I have with your amendment is that it does put actual years in. It may well be that you are right and that by that time, within a year or two, there will be entirely appropriate budgetary and economic circumstances to allow the review and possible improvement of the maternity allowance. But it is not possible to accept an amendment that puts a time line on that at this stage.

PARA.TAB: I noted Senator Patterson saying that if we added up all the Democrat amendments they would come to a huge bill. I remind the Senate that Senator Patterson's opposition yesterday to the child-care bill is going to cost this government $140 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —It wasn't me.

—You are the same party. It was your party that was opposing it. I do allow that the Democrats, in moving that amendment, are genuine about looking at the bill in November, but Senator Minchin and Senator Troeth, on behalf of the opposition, want to oppose the bill. They opposed it in the House of Representatives; they will oppose it in November. They have said that they will oppose it, but they are not going to just oppose it today so that they are not caught with being charged with dudding this government of $140 million over four years. That is just the sort of convenient figure that might assist in changing payments on the maternity allowance.

PARA.TAB: The moral high ground is a pretty dangerous place to try to get to. I am here on behalf of facts. We know how good they are. You can make your own assessment. The maternity allowance in this bill is a great improvement, a tremendous contribution to Australian families. It is $816 at the time of the birth of a baby, after 1 February next year.

On the record is a commitment by this government to review that maternity allowance with a view to improving it once the economic and budgetary circumstances permit. I take the sentiment of your amendment. It is entirely in concurrence with the government's intention, but because there are specified years in there the government is not able to accept it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to address a couple of the points that have been made on the so-called high moral ground. Senator Patterson said that receiving the amendment yesterday has not given her sufficient time to consider it. The opposition is so selective about when this matters and when it does not, and the way in which they do unto others. I recall getting land fund bill amendments two seconds before we were to debate them. It happens that way. Twenty-four hours is a reasonable time to give attention to something like this.

PARA.TAB: When you say that `You add up all the Democrats' promises and what they try to do,' you fail to acknowledge that we at least put to this government, and do regularly, a balanced, revenue neutral budget submission. We are prepared to say, `This is where we would raise the money and this is how we would spend it,' and we, I think, have a record of being fiscally responsible. You can look at the 27 commitments that John Howard and others on your side have already made in the course of not releasing policy, and those commitments are going to cost an awful lot of money, too.

So there is no moral high ground to be gained by you or anybody else by saying, `There has not been enough time to consider it but the Democrats come in here and make all these amendments all the time without any regard for what they cost.' That simply is not true. As you and I know, governments and oppositions, and Democrats and everybody else, have the right to make political choices about the priority they will give to where they raise and where they spend public money.

Senator Crowley said that the government will review this always as economic circumstances permit. Okay, but that is what it always says—`As economic circumstances permit we will review this measure.' What about the politics of it? What it really points to, in my view, disappointingly, is the lack of clout of women in this decision making process. I suspect that if there had been more women in the cabinet when it was decided that the government could only go this far, instead of going as far as it had promised, we would have had more of a fight. So it is disappointing.

I do not believe that this is a fiscally irresponsible amendment, even if it does have the years specified. I did not expect opposition senators to support it. Why would they? I do not believe that it is their policy to embark upon paid maternity leave. I stress again: it is not the super-duper good news, excellent-excellent good news. But I am also realistic enough to know that women and families will welcome $816 compared with zero. However, I really would like to see this government get serious about formally legitimising the right to paid maternity leave.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just have to make a comment about the minister's response to Senator Kernot that the government cannot agree with the amendment because it has to wait until it is fiscally responsible to do so. You promised before the last election that you would give them what Senator Carr is asking for—and now you are reneging on it. You must have known what the financial situation was like before the last election.

PARA.TAB: I just find it amazing, Senator Crowley, that on that argument you can squirm out of your promise so easily. But you will not squirm out of the fact that you have reneged on promise after promise that your party made before the last election. This is another one of them, and you have just squirmed out of it again.
