DEBATE.TITLE: STUDENT AND YOUTH ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT (YOUTH TRAINING ALLOWANCE) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 20 June, on motion by Senator Robert Ray:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will now be supporting the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill 1995 on the basis of the concessions that the government has been prepared to make, which I presume the minister will announce at some appropriate time.
—This is the student youth assistance—
—I have a brief which was sent to me from your colleague's office which tells me that you are making major concessions which I think will resolve outstanding matters in relation to this bill.
—You have seen these government amendments, have you?
—Yes.They delete a number of the schedules. Schedule 6—with the exception of item 7 to the schedule—schedule 7 and schedule 8 are to be deleted, according to Minister Free.

PARA.TAB: This bill makes changes to the youth training allowance provisions of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973. The youth training allowance is intended to replace the jobsearch allowance for young unemployed persons under the age of 18 years.

The relevant policy agency for the youth training allowance is DEET and the relevant payment agency is the Department of Social Security. As a consequence, we have a cumbersome procedure whereby changes in the Social Security Act need to be constantly mirrored in the Student and Youth Assistance Act. At the time when the youth training allowance was substituted for the jobsearch allowance, the coalition expressed concern about the creation of unnecessary bureaucratic procedures with the two large departments, DEET and the Department of Social Security, dealing with one client group. This bill bears out the coalition's concern. Having dealt with many of the amendments in the social security bills—in particular, my colleague Senator Patterson has been involved in this—bills which have now passed the Senate, we have to revisit them in relation to the Student and Youth Assistance Act.

Some of the proposed changes mirror amendments already made to the Social Security Act 1991 by way of the Social Security (1994 Budget and White Paper) Amendment Bill 1994 and the Social Security (Parenting Allowance and Other Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1994. We have no difficulty with these amendments. Others of the proposed changes are intended to mirror amendments to the Social Security Act 1973. They have now been passed through the Senate, as I said, in the form of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995 and the Social Security (Non-Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. Our position on merit was put fully in that debate in the Senate. As a result of our arguments, the government made a number of concessions. Really, what it is doing, as I understand it, is mirroring those concessions in its decision to delete the schedules that I mentioned a moment ago from this piece of legislation.

The amendment to schedule 3 and schedule 4 of the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill 1995 is in part the mirror amendment of schedule 16 of Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995 and relates to lump sum compensation and compensation recovery. We expressed in the debate under the social security legislation the concerns raised by the Welfare Rights Centre and others about the amendment on compensation recovery. The government has undertaken to clarify the administrative guidelines to the Social Security Act and to introduce a legislative amendment to address these concerns. As we said, we were satisfied with the undertakings that were given in that regard.

Schedule 6 of the Student and Youth Assistance Amendment (Youth Training Allowance) Bill 1995 relates to continuation, variation and termination of determinations. It is the mirror amendment to division 18 of the Social Security (Non-Budget Measures) Legislation Bill 1995. Our opposition to that was stated in the Senate in debate of the social security legislation. This amendment, in the view of the coalition, places an unreasonable onus on clients, a responsibility which is more appropriately placed with the department. We therefore indicated opposition to schedule 6. As I said, the government has now said that it is prepared to delete that, with the exception of item 7. We are therefore pleased that the government has made this decision.

Schedule 7 relates to the power of the secretary to disclose client information. We understand this amendment mirrors proposed amendment to the Social Security Act which has been withdrawn. We are pleased to see that the government proposes an amendment to omit schedule 7 from this bill. Schedule 7, as it stood, would have allowed the secretary to disclose information not only to the secretary or head of the department or authority but also to staff. It also would have allowed the secretary to delegate his disclosure power. As we argued in here under the social security legislation, it is essential that the integrity of client information held by departments is upheld and strengthened, rather than weakened. We are therefore pleased to see that the government now intends to omit this schedule.

Finally, schedule 8 on the reviewability of some ministerial decisions relates to division 16 of the Social Security (Non-Budget Measures) Legislation Amendment Bill 1995. We earlier set out the coalition's opposition to this amendment. The coalition is concerned about the expansion of non-reviewable decisions. As we said earlier in the debate, the coalition believes that the parliament should be cautious in considering any widening of non-reviewable decisions. We therefore were opposed to schedule 8 of this bill and are pleased to see that the government has decided now to delete that schedule. On the basis of the government's decision to delete provisions which were subject to our objections, I therefore indicate on behalf of the coalition that we will support the passage of this legislation.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! It being past 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

DEBATE.TITLE: RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSMITTER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1994RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (RECEIVER LICENCE TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1994RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS TAXES COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 March, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Radiocommunications (Transmitter Licence Tax) Amendment Bill, the Radiocommunications (Receiver Licence Tax) Amendment Bill and the Radiocommunications Taxes Collection Amendment Bill, which are being debated cognately. These bills will amend the Radiocommunications Act 1992.Under this act, an apparatus licence may be issued for a five-year period. At present, the licensees must make an annual tax payment for the term of the licence.

PARA.TAB: The measures before the Senate today will allow the Spectrum Management Agency to offer other options for the payment of these new licences. The coalition believes that this is a reasonable change. As a result, there will be a reduction in the administrative costs of the Spectrum Management Agency. Presumably, the administrative cost savings will also be passed to radiocommunications licensees.

These amendments introduce more flexible options. Significantly, no licensee will be forced to change their payment procedures by the SMA. If they want to continue with the old arrangements, they can, but they are now being offered new flexibility. The Spectrum Management Agency reviewed the radiocommunications apparatus licence in 1994. The review recommended a wide variety of payment options to be made available. The existing legislation offers only one way: the regular annual licence tax payment.

Many licences are issued for periods in excess of one year. The annual administration of the licence tax adds unnecessarily to the cost burden of the operation of the SMA. The SMA review has properly identified the need for a more flexible payment of the tax. That flexibility is to allow the option of an up-front payment by the licensee, and that up-front payment can cover the term of the licence—not just for one year but for a maximum of five years. That change is most welcome. Where a licence is issued for 12 months or less, the fee will fall due, as currently is the case.

The apparatus licensing system will in future have three options for payment with licence terms exceeding 12 months—to pay up-front a lump sum fee; to transfer from the annual instalment method of payment by paying a lump sum amount to cover the balance of the license term of up to five years; or to simply stay with the present payment procedure of an annual fee plus an administrative charge for sending the annual notification.

Another change that has been brought about by these bills relates to penalties. Under the old penalty system, they could just suspend and cancel the licence, which is a pretty brutal way of doing it. In the spirit of the flexibility of these bills, they have also changed the way in which penalties may be imposed. They are doing this because 40 per cent of the licence renewals are processed late because of late payment. It is a high figure, and new up-front payment fees might help to reduce this problem. The SMA will have the power to make disallowable instruments setting interest penalties on outstanding amounts. That is a welcome addition to the other formal ways of bringing in the money more quickly.

As I indicated, the coalition supports the bill. The opportunity to reduce administrative costs and possibly more efficient collection of licence fees and the reduction of late payment to the SMA are welcome changes. The SMA estimates that, on the basis of the 1994-95 fiscal year, 10 per cent of the licences for the renewal make up for the up-front payment in the future. On the 1994-95 figure, 10 per cent take up of the licence revenue would increase from $94 million to $136 million per year. This increase would be offset with reductions in the following four years. The Australian Telecommunications Users Group supports the greater flexibility in the payment option. We hope that the administrative savings, with fewer payments being processed, are actually passed on to the people who are taking out the licences. We will be watching to see that the SMA does pass on any such savings.

My compliments to the SMA, which have so far been fairly extensive, will end at this point because the coalition is not particularly happy with some of the other ways in which schemes of the SMA are being administered at this time. I refer, in particular, to community radio stations and what is happening with the allocation of parts of the spectrum to these groups. The role of the SMA is to manage this process in an era of rapidly changing technology. There is enormous demand on the spectrum and this must be properly managed and people must be allocated licences in an orderly manner across various regions. We are questioning the way in which the government is administering this process.

Yesterday we had some people from community radio speak to us and talk about the enormous delays with the SMA on this matter. There are 75 stations ready to go around Australia at the moment and they have been totally hamstrung by the bureaucratic procedures set up by the Department of Communications, in particular, the SMA. Basically there are three teams going around the regions of Australia holding inquiries. A management plan is then developed and licences are to be issued. This process has been going on for several years. We were told yesterday that the number of licences that have been issued out of the process was zero. I find this amazing. As the government implied, it had a priority set for holding these inquiries. If it had a priority set, when those inquiries finished in a particular region, why is it not allocating part of the spectrum via licences to people and organisations out of its management plan? This is not happening at present.

When I challenged the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) on this two years ago he promised to look into it and said he would try to see in what way the whole procedure could be speeded up. We have discovered that it has actually slowed down. He said several years ago that there were three teams going around and the process would take, in the case of getting to Newcastle, from 1993 to 1996—three years. I said, `If you had six teams, you would be able to drop that to 18 months.' He said, `Yes, we have 12 teams and we will drop it to nine months.' He did not continue the spirit of that in reality because now we have a situation where it has blown out. Newcastle—it will not get to it in 1996—will now take to 1997.

We have a whole lot of operators who are ready to go. We could understand that in a highly populated area such as the Hunter Valley there might be some spectrum crowding and that is probably a reason for delay. But we are at a bit of a loss to understand why in other areas of the country that are more remote, where in many cases there is only one applicant, why it has been so slow to issue a licence. Why is the government waiting for further competition to emerge? Surely that could be considered later.

If, over the last few years, there has only been a very small number of people applying for a licence and they have applied in a remote area where there is plenty of bandwidth in the spectrum, why not issue the licence? We are terribly short of small businesses to employ the youth of this country. There is a golden opportunity in allowing these community radio stations to employ people to do useful work, but the government has hamstrung that effort. They are sitting on these plans and not allowing these stations to develop.

They sometimes issue temporary licences, which allows them to go on air for several months and then they have got to shut down. So they are in the studios, they have got everything set, they have got it operating, people are in work, they are building a listening audience, then it closes down for nine months and they have got to start again. It is a ridiculous system. The government really must look at its procedures.

Even though we are complimenting the SMA for getting it right in this bill on licence fees and the way in which they are handling them, which seem a far more efficient way to go about the procedure and is a procedure that will save costs, there are other areas of the SMA's operation that leave a lot to be desired. We have raised the matter in the Senate before. There has been no action. I am getting those groups to provide me with very comprehensive information so that we can take this matter further. It is only through the proper management of things like spectrum management that we can create new work in this country and give people the opportunity to undertake that work. If we continue with the current situation, people who have the possibility of getting a job, businesses that have a chance to start up, will not have that opportunity.
I commend this bill to the Senate, with those reservations that I have already mentioned about the Spectrum Management Agency.As I have indicated previously, we are not opposing these bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support this legislation but I wish to point out a few problems that I can see with the Radiocommunications (Transmitter Licence Tax) Amendment Bill 1994 and other bills. Actually, this is Victor Juliet Whisky 479 speaking. When the CB had to be licensed, I was Whisky Alpha Tango 114. Anyhow, that is by way of an aside.

PARA.TAB: I will address these bills in two phases. I will deal first with the commercial aspect of radio. I will deal with the amateur radio situation a bit later. This bill brings in new licence fees. The minister's second reading speech and the explanations which went out regarding the renewal of commercial licences this year stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The radiofrequency spectrum has been recognised for some time as a scarce commodity. Previous radiocommunications licence fees included recovery and cost of spectrum management plus a tax to provide a return to the community for the use of that scarce commodity, but the components were not separately identified.

The situation now is that it is broken up into three categories, which include licence fees, although it seems to be called a licence tax at present. I do not know when it went from a licence fee to a tax. Someone may be able to explain a bit later why there was this change of term. A tax is a tax is a tax, and so is a levy. I would rather it were called a licence fee.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're not the same.
—When the parliamentary secretary replies at the end of this debate, he can probably explain to me why it has gone from being a licence fee to a licence tax.

PARA.TAB: The situation is that there are now three categories. There is a spectrum access tax, a spectrum maintenance component and a licence issue or renewal charge. The tax component is termed the spectrum access tax and provides the community with a return or rent for the private use of a scarce commodity resource—the radiofrequency spectrum.

I would like to know how the government can justify that situation, because the commodity that is being used is the atmosphere. The atmosphere is accessed as a highway for radiocommunications. Apart from management of the spectrum by issuing licences and that sort of thing, how can it charge tax on space? I would like to have that explained to me. You have not built a highway; you have not done anything else, yet we have a tax. The parliamentary secretary who is at the table said that it is a tax and he reckons that is different from a licence. Perhaps that can be explained to me. This government does not have anything left to tax. It is probably even taxing the air that we breathe.

The government further justifies its situation when it comes to the financial impact. This was the explanation when we got our licence renewals: while these changes in fees may result in a fee increase or decrease for individual licensees, the total amount of revenue to the Commonwealth will be approximately the same as under the previous fee regime. I would like to know how they arrived at that.

I happen to have my licence renewal due for payment on 7 October. Last year for our total commercial two-way radio licence, that is on HF, I paid between $550 and $600. This year I am renewing the licence for the same frequencies, the same bases and the same mobiles—mobiles do not have to be paid for separately if you have a base licence. I am paying for the same licence in exactly the same situation. It is a simplex situation, that is, messages are transmitted and received on the same frequency; as against a duplex situation where messages are received and transmitted on different frequencies. In other words, with my simplex system, a person can carry on a conversation like on a telephone. It cost between $550 and $600 last year. This year the cost is $1,889, and the government is saying that there is no financial impact and no change in the financial impact. Perhaps they can explain this.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a rort!

—It is a rort. It is three times the previous amount, or a 300 per cent increase, if I am right. The minister has the gall to say that there is no change in the financial impact. That is the situation with the commercial licence. He is also presuming that all existing licence holders in the HF spectrum will be renewing their licences.

PARA.TAB: I will pick one of the frequencies and split up the cost. It is split into spectrum access tax, spectrum management component and an administrative charge. The government is taxing the waves going through the air. One of these days it will tax surfers for the waves coming onto the beach. It is $327 for a commodity that has had no input from this government. It is a tax for access. The spectrum management component is $98.16. I suppose this is to justify the government's new computers. The administrative charge is $11. That is about $435 per frequency. A commercial operator of reasonable size—for instance, aerial sprayers, farmers or interstate truckers—normally has about four frequencies, and that is the case with my own licence. The cost has gone from $550-odd to $1,889. I would like an explanation for that increase because it certainly goes against what the minister had to say. I have got all the paperwork from this year and last year if anyone doubts my word.

I will move on to amateur radio. Amateur radio is quite different and has also had an increase in licence fees. There are about 20,000 amateur radio operators in Australia. Their fees have also increased, although the minister did say that the increase is now not going to be as bad. It was going to increase from $37 to $71 but, after a lot of pressure from the amateur radio operators of Australia, the minister decided to reduce it to $51. That is nearly a 40 per cent increase, anyway. I would like to know what spectrum management there is for amateur radio.

The world is divided into three spectrums for amateur radio. We are in the Oceania section. Then you have a European section and, if I am right, the other one is regarded as the American section. Those spectrums are managed by international agreements and an international organisation. We are in the Oceania section. The government claims amateur radio has to pay more for spectrum management. I would like to have explained to me how that situation comes about.

I did say that amateur radio operators are vastly different from a commercial two-way HF or UHF licence. On the commercial side, and even in aviation, you license the apparatus, as it is called these days. I believe that calling it apparatus is downgrading the currency in radio.

In the case of amateurs, you license the operator. Also, people have to study three aspects to get a licence: radio theory, regulations and morse code. That is what is holding me up from getting my licence at the present moment but, with a certain amount of coaching, I will get there. The difference is: with amateur radio, you are licensing the operator. How can you then increase their fees when you are not licensing the apparatus itself? That is an explanation I would like to hear in due course.

The 20,000-odd amateur radio operators in Australia are there as amateurs, exactly as the word implies. They cannot charge for their work when they work in an emergency situation. It is their hobby to talk to each other across the country—they talk about radio and anything else—but they have become very useful, as we heard in the inquiry into national disasters by the committee of which I am a member. It reported on that some time ago.

If I remember rightly, the first news of Cyclone Tracy that went through Darwin in 1974 was sent by amateur radio. Amateurs are doing work for nothing. What is more, they are not allowed to charge for their services. The way the advisers are carrying on over there, they might think I do not know what I am talking about, but I do know what I am talking about. I cannot see why the government loaded these amateurs up.

At the same time as it was loading up the amateur operators, the government decided to take off the licences on UHF CB and 27 meg band CB. I do not know why it decided to do that. It was only $10 a set, but I believe it was a way of providing some sort of regulation and supervision of what was going on. At least you knew who had licences. I suppose those licences could be inspected and there could be interception. I believe the conduct on the UHF CB band and on the 27 meg band has definitely deteriorated in the last couple of years, since this was taken off.

Okay, the government decided to take it off. I do not know what it was collecting from those licences, but obviously it has loaded up the amateurs. It has certainly loaded up commercial radio. As I said, in my situation—which is everyone's situation—we have gone from $550 a year; the government has trebled the charge for that licence. I can tell you what is going to happen. The government will be collecting less in this situation because of rationalising of frequencies.

Where this scarcity of spectrum is, which the government is talking about as an excuse to put up access tax, I do not know. It may certainly differ in the built-up areas, but in the remote areas there are a lot of us operating. We have very little use of a particular frequency for 24 hours a day. If we have got traffic on it for half an hour in 24 altogether, I would be surprised—for the ones I am experienced with, anyhow. Even the Flying Doctor frequency would not have an occupancy of more than 10 per cent.

Even though the coalition is supporting these bills, I believe the government has got a lot to explain to the commercial two-way radio users and to the amateurs. I would be very interested to hear what the parliamentary secretary at the table has got to say when he does give his delivery.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to join this debate on the radiocommunications bills. At the outset, I declare a personal interest. In the words of the Spectrum Management Agency, in their impersonal documents, when they send out a gouging statement each year to extract more money for a licence, I am described as a client. So I put that clearly on the record when I start.

PARA.TAB: I view the Spectrum Management Agency as just a monster that has been created by this Labor government to raise more and more money from the unsuspecting, uncomplaining Australian citizen. I cannot see the purpose of it in any way at all, and my worry is that it is just going to go on growing like some cancerous growth on the Australian community, charging more and more each year from those people that it has within its claws.

My particular concern, unlike Senator Panizza's, is in relation to the way the agency is now operating in the civil aviation field. I have owned and operated aircraft for 27 years, I suppose. For most of those years I never paid a cent for my radio licence. Out of the blue, I got a demand from the Spectrum Management Agency about four or five years ago to pay a licence fee, and I think most years the fee goes on increasing.

My fee, unlike Senator Panizza's, is only $45 a year but I have every expectation that, unless something is done, that will go on increasing. To me, whether it is $45 or $4.50 it is too much, because the services that I use a radio for are services that are demanded under the Civil Aviation Safety Authority's requirements. I am not speaking only on my own behalf here but probably on behalf of about 4,000 aircraft owners in Australia who do not operate under the instrument flight rules and for whom the carriage of radio is largely an elective procedure.

The only reason that we have to carry a radio is that there is a civil air regulation that states that if we are going to operate into controlled airspace—and that covers secondary airports such as Archerfield, Moorabbin and the rest of them—we carry a radio. But it is not mandatory from a functional point of view. It is not so many years ago, 1988, the bicentenary year, that there was a big air race around Queensland that ran for seven or 10 days. I cannot remember how many aircraft were in that, but my air race number was 137. I think there were about 150 aircraft in the race.

The race was designed on daily legs. The slowest aircraft departed first and the fastest departed last. The aim was that as many aircraft as possible arrived at the same time at the end of each flying leg in the day. The race was operated strictly without radio. Pilots did a test call before they took off to make sure the radio was working and then the only other call they made in flight was when they passed over the finishing point for the leg, which was always some miles from the airport. It was just a simple call to say, `Air race 137 over the top.' The aircraft then joined the circuit and there might have been 50 or more aircraft in the circuit, which is a very confusing situation. However, that was done with absolute safety, without any incidents at all and entirely non-radio.

I do not argue that radio is not a safety aid but it is not mandatory for VFR operations. The reason that we carry a radio is that, as I said, civil air regulations require us to have one to operate in controlled airspace. It is also a safety measure. I would argue that, in those circumstances, there is no reason at all to impose a fee upon us. We have got by for all these years without having a fee imposed. We pay a levy on avgas, and avgas is considerably more expensive than motor spirit because of the taxes that this government imposes upon it. Part of that avgas levy is to cover the use of civil aviation airways facilities outside controlled airspace, where we make these radio calls. So, basically, we are paying for it that way. The other point that is quite pertinent to this is that radio is, in some way, a safety feature. If someone is prepared to have the initiative and generosity to add to their safety—they are not only dealing with their own safety, but there is a community interest element in this—I think it is quite wrong to tax them for it.

I come now to the business of the regulation of the spectrum itself. Senator Panizza spoke about other parts of the spectrum. I want to talk about the both civil aviation VHF—very high frequency communications, which is the common one for civil aircraft—and the high frequency band, which is only used to a very minor degree now. They operate within certain frequency bands. From memory, the VHF band for aviation is about 118 to 127.9 megahertz. That is an internationally agreed convention. It applies to all countries around the world. So there is nothing unique and there is no management involved in Australia. It is just a simple convention that that band is an aviation communications band and everyone else stays out of it. I do not see any justification at all for setting up a vast bureaucracy to manage something that does not need much managing at all.

The really worrying thing about all of this is that there is no control mechanism on the activities of the Spectrum Management Agency. I have spoken many times in the Senate on the fallacy of the user-pays doctrine. The user-pays doctrine falls down in relation to government agencies because there is no control over them. The user-pays doctrine works quite well in private enterprise where a customer goes along to a supplier or a vendor of goods and says, `I wish to buy such and such.' The vendor has control, to some degree, over the management of that service in that if the company is not managed effectively its cost of production and cost of operation goes up and they lose market share. But that never applies with a government body. A government body is never censured. In fact, if a government department runs in deficit, the secretary running it gets promoted to a higher grade and they get a bigger budget next year to cover the deficit.

When you introduce a public payment component into that, the poor old unsuspecting public, which simply cannot defend itself, gets slugged with higher and higher fees. We see this every year with the Spectrum Management Agency. So it is time the government had a good hard look at what it is doing here. If it is going to charge fees for services, then it has got to have an unambiguous reason for charging those fees. Senator Panizza has demonstrated very clearly that the reason for most of these fees is extremely obscure. Also it has got to run the system efficiently. Until that happens, I am going to be a continual critic of the Spectrum Management Agency.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—This debate on what I thought was non-contentious legislation has turned into a bit of `bash the SMA' and complaints about charges when, in fact—
—Give us some answers.

—These bills do not relate to those issues—that is the problem you have got. Maybe if the senator consulted with Senator Alston he would find out that the purpose of the legislation does not relate to most of the issues he was raising. If the senator wants to have general complaints, raise general issues, fine. I will attempt to address some of the matters he has raised but they are not relevant to the legislation that is before us. I know that we are always very reasonable in our approach to that standing order, but it is non-contentious legislation and there is a time and a place to raise those matters.

PARA.TAB: In respect of changes for the fees for amateur radio operators, this is part of broader changes to apparatus licences. Under the proposal contained in the document Inquiry into the apparatus licence system: a new outlook, which was released in February, the fees for apparatus licences are based on a combination of the administrative and maintenance costs of issuing a licence, and a tax component based on the value of the spectrum used. Many apparatus licence users will see fee reductions under this formula, including the Royal Flying Doctor Service, state governments and taxi services. But some fees, such as amateur fees, are to increase under the draft proposal as published. Most amateurs were paying $37 per annum but, under the formula being applied to apparatus licences in general, their annual fee would have risen by between $8 and $34 to a maximum of $71.

As part of the implementation process for establishing a new apparatus licence regime, it had always been intended that a first round of consultation would take place before the fees were set. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Elliott) announced in March this year that the SMA had further considered the level of fees to be applied to amateurs in the light of the public benefit that amateurs provide to the community, and that a lower overall fee was then to be introduced. In view of the training and experience in communication technology that amateurs provide to young people and the role that amateurs provide in maintaining communication links at times of emergency, the SMA had decided to reduce the tax component of a licence fee to the minimum level. This reduced the fee from the proposed $71 to $51 per annum.

TALK.START.PARA: —A 38 per cent rise.

—I have just dealt with some of the matters you raised. I cannot deal with all of them, but I have asked the advisers to take your general complaints about the SMA and the licensing issues, and they are going to respond by way of correspondence to those more general matters raised. But the bills before us today do not increase charges or reduce charges in the way the senator has complained about—the reason, I understand, the opposition is supporting this legislation. What it does mean is greater flexibility in organising licensing arrangements.

PARA.TAB: Under the amendments proposed in the three bills, an applicant for a licence will be able to choose between the following tax options: the first option is for an apparatus licence issued for a period of 12 months, with payment of the annual licence fee current at the time when the licence is issued; the second is for a licence issued for a period of more than 12 months, with payment at the time of issue of the total licence fees; the third is for a licence issued for a period of more than 12 months, with payment of an annual instalment upon issue and on each anniversary of the date of issue during the term of the licence; and the fourth is for a license issued for a period of more than 12 months, where the licensee has previously elected to pay by annual instalments and then decides to pay the balance of the licence fees by payment of the balance on the next occurring anniversary of the issue of the licence.

This legislation is about providing those four options as forms of payment. It does not deal with the issue of the level. That is why, from our perspective, the legislation does not affect government revenue in the sense of a loss or a gain. So that is the purpose of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The higher amateur licence fee must affect it.

As to the more general issues you have raised, the minister, through the departmental officers, will deal with those more general issues—some of which I have dealt with, although I acknowledge that I have dealt with all of them this afternoon in this debate—and will get a response. Senator Panizza might like to give us a copy of his licence. TALK.START.PARA: —Today, we are debating the Transport Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1995, which the opposition supports. The purpose of this bill is twofold. One of its purposes is to make amendments to the Air Navigation Act 1920 in respect of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigations, known as BASI, which is a branch of the Department of Transport, quite separate from what was known as the Civil Aviation Authority or, as it is known today, Airservices Australia or CASA, being the Civil Aviation Safety Authority.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the purpose of the BASI amendments is to ensure that the powers of investigations have a sound legislative basis. It allows BASI to play an enhanced role by clearly defining its functions and to ensure that the organisation's investigations of aviation accidents and incidents conform to the international civil aviation standards.

The amendments include definitions of accidents and incidents. Accidents occur when a person on board an aircraft dies or is seriously injured. It also covers cases where an aircraft is missing or inaccessible or has suffered some significant damage. An incident is a near accident or an event that adversely affects the safety of the aircraft. People working in the industry and the staff of CASA and Airservices would be required to report an accident or serious incident to BASI as soon as possible. The legislation provides that there be a penalty for intentionally or recklessly failing to report an accident or serious incident. The penalty for this would be six months imprisonment.

The bill also empowers BASI investigators to enter and search premises—something which they are not entitled to do at this stage—although they would first have to obtain a search warrant from a magistrate. It would also mean that, if an Australian operated, designed or manufactured aircraft was involved in an accident overseas, the minister would be able to appoint an accredited representative to participate in the inquiry. BASI would still be able to conduct investigations into accidents overseas at the request of the country where that accident had occurred. Division 6 of the part sets out BASI's power in relation to accident sites. Curiously, the current regulations do not allow BASI staff to enter accident sites without the permission of the occupants.

This bill would empower the investigators to enter an accident site without first obtaining permission and the investigators will be able to secure the site against unauthorised entry—a sensible provision. The wreckage of an aircraft and its contents would be taken to be in the custody of the Director of Air Safety Investigation and it would be an offence for a person to interfere with the wreckage except under certain circumstances, such as saving of lives or protecting wreckage from fire.

Division 9 would include the disclosure of air safety information by the organisation. Proposed section 19HC(8) would provide that air safety records, other than cockpit voice recordings, could not be produced in civil proceedings unless the court was satisfied the public interest in disclosing the records outweighed the adverse impacts of disclosure. It would not be possible to compel the production of air safety records, except cockpit voice recordings in a criminal case. Cockpit voice recordings would not be admissible in evidence in any civil or criminal case against a member of the aircraft's crew.

This has been the subject of some debate over a long period and of course it is important that the cockpit recordings be used without fear by the people using them. The purpose of investigations into aircraft accidents is to determine the cause and to try to prevent accidents occurring in the future. It is generally believed that any restriction on that, or any concerns that pilots might have, might affect their willingness to speak into the voice recording mechanism. As I indicated at the beginning, the coalition supports this bill.

With regard to the amendment to the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act, this means that the authority would cease to be a statutory body in the terms of the corporations legislation. Again, this is sensible because under the corporations legislation the authority would have to be required to have an audit and prepare a business plan. As the Seafarers Rehabilitation Authority does not run a commercial business, there is nothing to audit and there is no need to prepare an annual business plan. The opposition supports both of the amendments.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Parer for his contribution. I do not think there is any need for me to comment further on the legislation.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I have a definition of the powers of CASA and BASI in relation to incidents and accidents. Is it correct that CASA has no right of inquiry or access to an accident or power to investigate an incident, that that is purely the preserve of BASI?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that BASI does take precedence over CASA. CASA's responsibilities, in terms of recommendations, relate to regulations only.

—Could we expand on that a little bit. Say we have a simple accident, an engine failure and a forced landing that is a consequence of that engine failure and an officer of CASA comes along and wants access to the aircraft or wants a statement from the pilot in command. Is the pilot in command obliged to speak with the officer of CASA? Must he allow the aircraft to be inspected or is that restricted to BASI? The reason I am asking this is that there is a degree of confusion in the aviation community as to what the boundaries are between the two authorities.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the case of the example you have cited, the pilot concerned would have to speak to both organisations. BASI takes precedence in investigating accidents. The pilot would have to speak to CASA in respect of its role in regulatory matters.

—I would like to take that a bit further. What is the regulatory incident in the hypothetical case I have put up? Presumably the regulations may not have been breached. So how would CASA have a place in this inquiry?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —There may not have been a breach of regulation by the pilot in the accident, but CASA still has to be satisfied that there has not been a breach of regulation. It would inquire to find out whether a breach has occurred. It does not know that until it has made its inquiry. It may be there has not been a breach of regulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On page 12, clause 19CB(1) says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Director may investigate:
(a) the circumstances surrounding any accident . . .

Why is a discretionary power granted to the director of BASI that he may investigate an accident? I can understand, in the case of an incident, it could be so trivial that it is pointless having an investigation into it or inquiring what happened but, by definition, accidents are serious events. Why is it not mandatory for the director to investigate all accidents?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that there may be some accidents that are not necessary for BASI to investigate. I am given the example of a wheels-up accident. That may result in some damage to the aircraft. I am not an expert on aircraft and I do not profess a great deal of knowledge in the area. That is the sort of damage in which BASI would say they do not have to be involved in the investigative process. That is why the word `may' is in there rather than `shall'.

—Now we come to clause 19CD concerning the rights of an investigator to enter premises. I would like an explanation of the difference between the cockpit voice recorders not being used as evidence in either a criminal or civil action against the air crew or anyone in the aircraft and yet the bill grants the right for an investigator to use force to seize documents, materials or whatever else might be deemed necessary for an investigation. Presumably the right to seize those documents or equipment would relate in some way to the laying of civil or criminal charges against that person.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The cockpit recorder is there for the protection of the individual pilot, whereas the provision under clause 19CD is for the purpose of investigation of the company or the operator of the aircraft involved. That is why it is included under general power of entry to premises, because of the operational nature and administrative nature of the aircraft by the company or the individual who may own that aircraft.

—Yes, but surely the purpose of both the investigation of the cockpit voice recorder and the access to documentation or equipment is to detect a breach of procedures or regulations, or something like that, to determine the cause of the accident. The purpose is the same. Yet, in one case, immunity is granted to the transgressor; in the other case, there is no immunity given. That philosophic difference is the point on which I seek explanation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that the act is much more restrictive about what can be done with the cockpit recorder—for example, in a court of law. BASI's purpose in investigating is not for that investigation to be used in a court of law. That apparently is the responsibility of either CASA or the Federal Police, if legal proceedings are to be initiated against the person or persons involved in the aircraft accident. BASI's role is to examine, learn and, perhaps, at some stage, change the way in which procedures should occur, rather than to be an investigative enforcer that will have some legal outcome on the individual involved in the accident.

—That is my understanding of it. To take that a point further: when those documents or equipment are seized by BASI and they find there have been breaches of regulations that were the reasons for the accident, does BASI maintain a confidential position with respect to that information or is it obliged to inform CASA? Does it return the documents and the equipment to the operator? What is the next step downstream from that, once BASI has made its investigation and come to a conclusion?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that, yes, BASI does write a report. It has to return the documents, if it has taken some documents, to the owner or the operator of the plane or the company. It is not unusual for BASI to be called or subpoenaed if legal proceedings are taken by the Federal Police or CAA; it can be called to give evidence. But it does not initiate a process of legal action which results in the prosecution of someone. It is not uncommon, particularly in coronial inquiries, apparently, for BASI to be asked to give its views on the matter. But it does not initiate a process as such. It has to return all documents to the person it has taken the documents from in the course of its investigations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One final point, on the issuing of a warrant for an investigator to seize these documents: we have had a series of unfortunate incidents where the Civil Aviation Authority has used excessive force and behaved in an unreasonable manner in exercising precisely the same powers to get documents. Clause 19CN provides:

PARA.TAB: (b) the investigator or a person who is assisting the investigator in executing the warrant may use such force against persons or things;

SPEECH.PARA: as is necessary and reasonable in the circumstances.
While that reads very clearly, in practice it is very hard to define. I would like to ask, in general terms: what restraints are binding on an investigator of BASI to behave in a reasonable manner?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, clause 19CN (b), at page 20, provides some more assistance in terms of the way in which a warrant is to be executed. I also understand that BASI has not had complaints laid against it. I do not know the details of the problems that have been brought to your attention about the CAA's conduct. But BASI has not had complaints in this area. The approach would be the same as it has been in the past. I do not know whether the legislation is identical, but it is very similar in the use of its words and terminology. Obviously any investigator, in an extreme circumstance, having to execute a warrant, would, I am sure, get advice about the way in which they conduct themselves in the execution of that warrant. So it is very difficult for me to define the precise circumstances of a person executing a warrant, other than to outline the sort of approach BASI has adopted in the past and, I am assured, will continue to adopt in the future.

—In conclusion, for the record: I have never heard any complaint about BASI's operations in this regard. No complaint has ever been made to me that anyone has behaved in an unreasonable way. But there certainly have been cases in the past where officers of CAA have operated in a manner that many people viewed as unreasonable at the time. Where you grant authority to people, there is always the risk that some immature personalities will abuse that right. The reason I raised it was to put the organisation on notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Yesterday you were asked about yet to be released new Labor policies and whether such policies would be funded by increased taxes or an increase in the budget deficit. In your response you stated, `None of the above.' Can the minister confirm to Australian families that ALP policy for the next election will be to guarantee no new taxes or increases in existing taxes in the following three years?

—This is cheeky in the extreme. It also could be described as outrageous. We do not have any secret policies. We are not the Liberal Party; we are the Labor Party. Our policies are out in the open. They are the policies that we have been working on for so many years. We are planning further policy announcements—that is true—but that is what the government does. That is what vision is about. That is what leadership consists of.

PARA.TAB: Our policies will be a further development of what we have been doing all along. One of those, for example, will be about innovation. We posted the subject `innovation' as an important driver of economic growth for Australia. We did that ourselves as a government. I am very pleased to see that the opposition are copycats, that they now are going to bring down an innovation statement. We set the bar. We said this is the direction to take the Australian economy. Belatedly, the opposition decided to join us, and that is a welcome change.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: the issue is one of relevance. The question related to the tax policies of the Labor government as it goes to the next election. Specifically, could Senator Cook tell us whether the government has a policy not to impose any new taxes or increase existing taxes so the Australian people know those policies? Could you tell us your policy? That is the question.

—On the point of order, Mr President: the open-ended question from Senator Alston asked if the Labor Party were considering different policy, which could go over the totality of anything. In the totality of revenue measures, Senator Cook is entitled to go over the whole ground. If Senator Kemp wants Senator Cook to restrict his answer, then he had better rewrite Senator Alston's question to make it more specific.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Alston

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: Senator Robert Ray is obviously distracted by other matters and did not hear my question, because only one part of it had a question mark. I will read it out to you:

INTERJECT.PARA: Can the minister confirm to Australian families that ALP policy for the next election will be to guarantee no new taxes or increases in existing taxes in the following three years?

You could not get a more specific, closed, narrow-ended question than that. For Senator Robert Ray to get up and pretend that somehow this gives the minister licence to wander around talking about everything except the question is absolute nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order: if, in fact, Senator Cook can only address the thing with the question mark in it, then the preliminary remarks were out of order. If they are not out of order, they are there to clarify what is in the question and, therefore, Senator Cook is entitled to comment on them.

—On the point of order: Senator Cook may need protection on this issue—and, Senator Robert Ray, we understand you jumping up to try to defend him—but there is a specific question. The Labor Party has been demanding that other people produce policies, so we have asked Senator Cook, on a very important issue that we have stated our position on, whether the Labor Party as it goes to the next election will guarantee that there will be no new tax increases and no further rises in existing taxes. Senator Cook may need protection, but it is a specific question. Could Senator Cook stand up and answer that question to the Senate and the Australian people?

—Since everybody is talking about me, I thought I should contribute to the point of order debate. On the point of order, this question related to a question that was asked of me yesterday about alleged so-called secret policies of the ALP. It also had a long preamble. We find in a lot of preambles in questions to ministers erroneous facts are included as if they are true.

PARA.TAB: It is idle to pretend that is not part of the question and that ministers, in properly representing government policy, should not be able to deal with mistruths contained in preambles of questions, as well as imputations or inferences in preambles of questions. To pretend that only the part of his question that has a question mark in front of it is really what he wants asked is something that only a smart slippery lawyer like Senator Alston could come up with.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Alston

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it is very important that you do address yourself to the facts of this issue, not what some people might wish to think is before the chamber. The preamble to my question was simply this:

INTERJECT.PARA: Yesterday you were asked about yet to be released new Labor policies and whether such policies would be funded by increased taxes or an increase in the budget deficit. In your response you stated, `None of the above.'

There is nothing there that could, in any shape or form, be characterised as a misstatement of fact or something that provides licence to wander around the chamber and talk about policies in general. It simply directs Senator Cook to something that was said yesterday and goes on to ask him, again, a very specific question about whether or not the government is going to make any promises about no new taxes and increases. That is the question. That is the one thing he has not answered and you are now in a position to do something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —This question is couched, as so many others are, in such general terms as to demand almost any response.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It also refers to a question that was asked yesterday which broadens it yet further and you make my task impossible when you ask such broad questions, full of invective and full of claims and counterclaims.
—What! Where's the invective?
—I am talking about general things now.
—What's that got to do with—

—Order! I am speaking now and you will keep quiet. I take it that Senator Cook will get to the question mark part of the question in due course. You make it very difficult for me when you ask such general questions.
—Mr President, on a point of order: would you ask Senator Cook to withdraw that crack about a slippery lawyer?
—Senator Cook, would you withdraw that comment?
—Mr President, because you have asked, I withdraw.
—Unconditionally.
—Order! He withdrew.

—I was saying that we, as a government, do not have any secret policies, but we do develop new policies and provide leadership for this nation. In the case of the innovation statement, we put that issue on the agenda. The opposition is now copycatting us on that issue. We welcome the competition. Thank God they have caught up. When we bring down our innovation statement, we will show a new vision for science, technology and industry in Australia. So much for yesterday's question and the alleged secret policies. It is what governments do. Maybe you have been in opposition too long and do not know.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday's question and today's question are also about what the budgetary implications of any new policy might be. Let us just go back to what the budget settings are for this government and what the core goals have been for this government in terms of taxes and managing the budget. We have brought the level of tax burden in this country down, and what this government will be doing in future policies is maintaining that record and improving on it where possible. Australians can be sure that we will certainly maintain our record and where we can we will bring the burden of taxes down.

We are now the second most lightly taxed country in the OECD. That is a reputation and record we are proud of and it is one for Australians to celebrate. On the question of new taxes, you can be sure, Senator, that we will maintain our record and, where possible, we will bring the burden down. On the question of a budget deficit, we have brought this budget into surplus. It is the opposition and the Democrats who reduced that surplus in the June debates over the budget. You have reduced the level of budgetary surplus and now you have the hide to ask us: are we going to go into deficit?

You have put constraints around our budget to make it harder, but this budget is still in surplus. We will keep it in surplus. That surplus will grow in future years. It will add to the level of national savings so that there will be more funds for Australians to invest in the Australian economy and in the world economy as well. You can be sure that will be a feature of our future policy settings, to maintain a level of public savings with the budget playing its role in doing so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this what it boils down to: you are going to announce a bucket load of new policies—
—Ask your question.

—This is the question. You are going to announce a bucket load of new policies whenever it suits you in the run-up to the next election. If possible, if you can, you will not have any increase in taxes—in other words, a licence to print money. What you are seriously saying is that it is not going to cost taxpayers one more cent unless you think it is necessary to do that. In other words, you want absolute carte blanche to go out there and promise the world, to not even tell people where the money is coming from, and yet somehow you think people are going to take you seriously. Is that your policy approach?

—The answer to the question is: no, it is not. We always show quite exhaustively where the money is coming from. And our policies are based on very solid figuring, unlike anything you have presented in the past. Mr President, standing orders prevent me from using the word `hypocrite' in relation to other members of this chamber—
—I suggest you do not use it then.
—My understanding of the definition of `hypocrite' is a person or a body that might say one thing and do another. What we have here is an opposition with no policies—
—What's the relevance of this then? Aren't you going to step in?

—Order! Senator Cook, take your seat, please. Senator Alston, you have consistently, throughout this session of the parliament, made what I can only call rude and offensive comments about rulings by the chair at various times. I have heard them and I have deliberately chosen to ignore them in the interest of keeping question time going. This is your final warning on that. You will be named in future.

—Thank you, Mr President. What we have here is an opposition that has no policies, that will not produce any policies, except in industrial relations, where we know what their policies are—the second wave of industrial relations changes.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You are not allowed to debate the question. That is what he is doing. We have asked him for his policies on taxes. He has refused to tell us. He has refused to rule out new taxes. I ask you to bring the minister to order and make sure that he answers questions and does not debate the question.
—Don't worry, there is no point of order—all right, Senator Ray, on a point of order.
—On a point of order on the interruption of question time: we have gone 13 minutes on one question because the other side has consistently interrupted—
—Are you addressing the first point of order? We can't have another point of order without addressing the other one.
—No, I said a separate but related point of order. This is an irrelevant point of order and an interruption of the debate.
—Point of order: is he speaking to a point of order or is he speaking—
—Yes, he is speaking to the point of order. Senator Campbell, do you have a comment to make on the point of order?
—You had ruled on the point of order, Mr President.
—I have not ruled on the point of order.
—Does he seek leave to make a short statement? You said there was no point of order.
—No, I let him speak on the point of order.
—You had ruled on the point of order. You said there was no point of order.
—I let him speak on the point of order. Be seated.
—Mr President, we have an opposition that does one thing and says another.
—That is exactly your problem.
—Order! Senator Kemp!

—I leave it for those listening to this performance to judge what that means in terms of that word I used earlier. This is a silly foray by the opposition which will rebound on them. It is about time the opposition produced their policies, other than their industrial relations one, so Australians can judge for themselves. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins. Has the minister's attention been drawn to a press statement issued by the shadow spokesman on primary industry, Mr Anderson, in which he claims farmers' terms of trade have been ignored by ABARE in its latest economic forecasts? Can the minister inform the Senate if this claim is correct and whether, as Mr Anderson has stated, the farm cost price squeeze is as bad as ever?

—No, it is not correct. I have actually commented before in this chamber on the extraordinary capacity of the shadow minister for primary industry—or his office or someone—for getting almost every press statement that he issues factually wrong 100 per cent. And he has done it again.
—In your opinion.

—Yes, in my opinion, Senator Macdonald. John Anderson yesterday issued a press release in which he claimed that ABARE's commodities forecast, which I have here and which contains very positive news for Australian primary producers, does not canvass farmers' terms of trade.

PARA.TAB: At the head of page 385 of the commodities forecast, in heavy black type it says this: `Farm costs—terms of trade and net returns'. Admittedly, this is not in National Party font—that is, letters an inch high and words of only one syllable—but it is there in heavy black type `terms of trade'. There it is in the commodities forecast. So Mr Anderson, once again, is flatly wrong.

I can understand why he would not like this report, because it contains, as I told the Senate yesterday, some very positive news for rural Australia, and for Australia generally. The forecasts in this document, in fact, run completely counter to the opposition's current scare campaign in the bush, that there is a crisis of confidence in rural Australia. ABARE in this report have, in fact, noted that rural prices will rise overall, as I told the Senate, despite forecast declines in prices for wool, sugar and cotton.

Mr Anderson, in fact, focused his press statement on the estimated decline in farmers' terms of trade of 3.2 per cent for 1995-96. That, of course, is due to what has been, without question, the worst crisis that Australian primary industry has ever faced in the recorded history of this country—the worst drought in living memory. What he chose to ignore—and it is contained in this document—is that the long-term decline in farmers' terms of trade has, in fact, stabilised over the last five years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—He has also missed the point, an interesting point I would have thought, that the bottom line for farmers is income, Senator Panizza—and yours is pretty healthy, as I know—and the value of net farm production is up a massive 80.5 per cent.

PARA.TAB: The stabilisation in farmers' terms of trade is directly attributable to the internationalisation of the Australian economy that this government has successfully driven: improvements in the international marketplace, improved access to markets, increased efficiency in domestic industries and, importantly, the changes to the composition of our agricultural exports. Australia is exporting, in fact, I am glad to say, an ever-increasing level of higher value added farm products like wine, dairy products, grain-fed beef and specialist horticultural products.

I would like John Anderson to put out a couple more press statements. I would like him to put out a press statement explaining why, in a recent statement to the rural press only about a week ago, he said that there would be cuts in government spending if the coalition win the next election. But, in terms of all the hoo-ha we have just heard about hidden agendas and whether there will be any new taxes, I would also like Mr Anderson to put out a press statement explaining why, in that same interview to the rural press, he said that the defeat of the coalition's goods and services tax proposal at the last election was `a major setback for tax reform'. I would like Mr Anderson to explain how long it will be after the election of a coalition government that we will see the re-emergence of a goods and services tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the minister to the Treasurer's repeated assertion on ABC radio this morning that Australia's record $180 billion foreign debt `has no impact at all' on interest rates. Does he agree with the Treasurer?
—I agree with what the Treasurer has said.
—That's what you asked. We didn't want to stray. You should congratulate us for not straying.

—Okay. Given his agreement with the Treasurer's views, I ask how he explains comments in the budget papers that high foreign debt `can impose costs on an economy by making it more vulnerable to external shocks and by raising interest rate premiums on borrowings', and the Prime Minister's comments just yesterday that we need to tackle the current account deficit which leads to foreign debt. Again, yesterday the Prime Minister said, `So we're not paying too high a premium on world interest rates.' Finally, how does the minister explain Vince FitzGerald's comments in his national savings report to the government that, `We need to pay higher interest rates to compensate for the risks inherent in our high external debt'? I ask: does the minister still stand by the Treasurer's remarks this morning, or is he prepared to jump ship and support his Prime Minister's contrary views?

—Shucks; I have got to do all that in one minute. I stand absolutely by what the Treasurer said. He is right, you are wrong and so is Peter Costello. What you have done is misrepresented the position in the budget papers. The disgrace here is on your side because you know better than that. You know the truth of the matter and you are purporting a mistruth on a massive scale in the public domain to justify your debt truck.

PARA.TAB: John Howard was Treasurer for five years in this country. He and Senator Short know very well that the domestic interest rate depends on what inflation is now and what inflation will be in the future. Both of them know that official interest rates were increased last year to keep down future inflation and not as a response to the level of foreign debt. The quickest way I can answer this question in the amount of time that I have is to say that on ABC's PM program Professor Tony Makin said, `It is not correct—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. My question relates to a real concern of small business groups; namely, their possible exploitation by big business. Is the minister aware of calls from the small business community to strengthen the Trade Practices Act to prevent this from occurring? Can the minister advise the Senate whether the government has considered this issue and, if so, what the result of that consideration has been?

—It is a big day, and it is a very big day for small business because today I announced on behalf of the government that we will be amending the Trade Practices Act to give a better deal to small business in their relationships with big business. Over the last six or eight months, or even back into the end of last year, the Small Business Forum, the small business community, has been asking for amendments to the Trade Practices Act in this area so that they would get a better deal. The only senator on the opposition side who has spoken up in various forums in favour of this is Ronnie Boswell. Ronnie, this is your day.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that throughout all of this time the Leader of the Opposition has not, despite making endless speeches—headland speeches, as he calls them—about how he is going to help small business, made one comment about the call from small businesses to amend the Trade Practices Act to give them better protection. He has not made one comment. The shadow spokesperson on small business, Judi Moylan, said at a small business coalition dinner that she hoped this government would fix up the Trade Practices Act before she became minister because it was too difficult for her to deal with.

There has not been from any frontbencher in the opposition one comment to support the government or the small business community in amending the Trade Practices Act other than from Senator Boswell. Senator Boswell, when we introduce this legislation, I hope you, as a senior leader of the National Party, can convince Liberal Party members to support the government and small business in changing the Trade Practices Act. This is the most significant change to the Trade Practices Act for small business since the act was first introduced in 1974.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you do it before?

—Senator Calvert stupidly interjects, `Why didn't you do it before?' Why didn't you announce the policy throughout the last 13 years? I will tell you why. Because every time someone hints that this act is going to be changed, big business trots around to the Liberal Party and says, `Don't change it.'

PARA.TAB: We already know that Mr Costello has been lobbied by the big end of town not to touch this amendment. We already know that is why Mr Howard, despite all his protestations about helping small business, will not stand up and make a comment about it. The government has now announced its policy. We will be amending the act, we will put an exposure draft of the proposed amendment to the Trade Practices Act and you will have a chance to comment—but I bet it will be a silent comment from you except, possibly, for that which comes from Senator Boswell individually.

It has been an outstanding achievement of the government, in consultation with the small business community, to make these changes to the Trade Practices Act. It just shows the difference. Despite the rhetoric of the opposition—that they are out there to help small business—they have not made a comment at all on this issue. The shadow minister does not want to deal with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you give us your exposure draft if you are so confident of your position?

—The reason we are having an exposure draft is that that will give you one last chance, Senator Hill, to make a comment. We are giving an exposure draft so that the business community can still make a contribution about how it is drafted, so that we get the outcome absolutely right to help small business and protect it from economic ransom by large business.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Minister, do you agree that it is vital that any proposal for foreign interests to buy into a crucial Australian infrastructure, such as Telstra, needs to be vigorously scrutinised against proper national interest criteria? Why is the government being so tardy in responding to the all-party recommendations of the Senate foreign ownership in the print media inquiry to reform the hopelessly inadequate Foreign Investment Review Board? Surely, if the government is serious, as you say you are, about keeping Telstra in Australian ownership, this reform is the first step. If you do not, then do you not forfeit the right to complain if or when the coalition flogs Telstra off to foreigners, the same way Aussat, Qantas, various Victorian power stations, Bankwest yesterday and probably South Australian water tomorrow have already been flogged off with your government's approval?

—The role of the Foreign Investment Review Board is to scrutinise inward investment in Australia and to do it with a clear brief to apply national interest criteria to that investment. Part of that consideration, quite clearly as well, is to ensure that this enhances competitiveness and so forth within Australia and broadly by Australia in the world economy. The point here, though, is that the Foreign Investment Review Board makes that consideration, forms a recommendation, puts that recommendation to the Treasurer and the Treasurer then announces what he or she will do.

PARA.TAB: If we go to each of the major events of the Foreign Investment Review Board and to each of the Treasurer's statements with relation to it, I think we will see that there are good and sound reasons in the national interest why, on each of those occasions, the investment has been welcomed or, where it has not been, why it has been stopped.

In this question there is a degree of speculation, I might say. The speculation starts: what if there is a coalition government and then they sell off Telstra? We do know that if there were a coalition government, they would sell off Telstra and a major part of Australian ownership in telecommunications, and our competitive advantage would move from the public sector to the private sector. It may well be that it would move into foreign hands. We know that. What I am saying is that this is speculative. The first part of the speculation is: `if there were a coalition government'. That is one good reason why there should not be a coalition government and why a lot of Australians should vote for this government—to ensure that it does not happen, to make sure that Telstra does not get privatised in that way.

To continue with the speculation inherent in the question I am asked and therefore invited to answer, it would be a decision of a Liberal Treasurer to pass Telstra into the hands of foreign ownership after the scrutiny had been undertaken by the FIRB, however constituted. It would therefore be an albatross around the neck of a Liberal government in those circumstances. That is a fate devoutly not to be wished and I am sure most Australians agree with me on that.

The part of this question that deals with the government's response to the print media inquiry I will, if I may, take on notice and I will provide a more detailed answer later. The first part of the question related to whether the FIRB should exercise public interest judgment on foreign investment. The answer to that part of your question is: yes, of course it should. That is what it is there for and that is what it does.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you say that it is hypothetical and that Mr Peter Costello would be the Treasurer, but the point of my question is that you can reform the processes now to make the Foreign Investment Review Board work properly, can't you? Are you confident—whether Mr Costello is the Treasurer or somebody else is—that the current Foreign Investment Review Board processes can guarantee that Telstra can remain in Australian ownership when it is not even allowed to examine Australian bids?
—Irrespective of the advice that the FIRB might offer a Treasurer, it would be the Treasurer's decision. It would be a decision, in this very hypothetical—

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections. There are people interested in the answer to this and they are straining to hear—like Senator Woodley. I call Senator Cook.

—It would be a decision of a coalition Treasurer, not of the FIRB. The FIRB guidelines as presently constituted do enable it—in my view and in the view of this government—to conduct a proper, thorough and effective examination on public interest criteria and to provide legitimate, fair, reasonable and properly constituted advice to the government.

PARA.TAB: It is a body that obviously needs a degree of latitude in providing that advice, and it has that. But, in the end, the inescapable conclusion here is that the government will make the decision. Senator Kernot, you and I might disagree in particular cases but, in the case of Telstra, I suspect that we do agree. In your hypothetical case, it would be a Liberal Treasurer who would hand Telstra to foreign ownership, not a Labor one. (Time expired)
