TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. The government's pharmaceutical industry development program, which includes the factor F scheme, has helped Australian pharmaceutical companies achieve $1.4 billion in additional exports, $1.14 billion in additional value-added activity, $323.5 million in additional research and development and an extra $598.9 million in investment. Is this yet another example of government industry policy working? What are the next steps for this particular industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, this is another example of government industry policy working. The pharmaceutical industry—the industry that this question relates to—has increased exports to $700 million; they have gone up by 400 per cent under our government. The automotive industry has increased exports to $1.5 billion; they have gone up by 300 per cent under our government. The textile, clothing and footwear industry has increased exports to $690 million; they have gone up by 235 per cent under our government and are expected to go to $2 billion by the year 2000. Elaborately transformed manufactures have gone up by 17 per cent in export terms each year for the last 10 years.

PARA.TAB: It may well be because of this performance that, at yesterday's MTIA conference entitled `What would a coalition government mean for business', Mr Howard said:

ANSWER.PARA: It is fair to say that in many industry policy areas, there is a lot of common ground between the government and the opposition.
In other words, this is a strong performance and a good performance, and our policies that have produced this performance have been endorsed by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Can I turn to the pharmaceutical industry itself. On 6 September I announced a 10-point industry development plan for the pharmaceutical industry in Australia. The final detail of this plan will be put into effect after the Industry Commission's report on the pharmaceutical industry has been brought down. I believe—and I have said this to the industry—that we need to see some form of continuing industry assistance, whether it be factor F or some other form, because we put a price cap on this industry in order to keep the cost of pharmaceuticals to Australian consumers low and to underpin our very competitive health system in Australia.

The factor F companies have had strong results over the last several years. They have achieved $3.47 billion in new activity to this date—and that is a very strong performance by this industry sector. The 10-point plan that I have announced consists of the government and industry working together to improve on those figures.

One of the startling elements of this industry, one of the most attractive features of it, is that it has a very enviable record of industrial relations achievement. It is the industry sector that has more enterprise agreements than any other, and it has done so in a very harmonious way.

One could therefore reflect that, while the opposition endorses our industry policies but disendorses and opposes our industrial relations policies, what we see as being the very fine achievements of this industry sector—in building harmony in the workplace, a cooperative approach to growing the company and, therefore, the remuneration of the employees—would be, at one fell swoop, swept aside if an opposition industrial relations policy were applied; and the achievements of this industry sector in becoming more world competitive, the possibility that it creates of Australia becoming a world supplier of pharmaceutical products and certainly a supplier to the Asia-Pacific region, would be totally and utterly undermined by the destructive industrial relations policies of the opposition.

So, on the one hand, you cannot as an opposition endorse our industrial policies and, on the other hand, bring in destructive industrial relation policies which will countermand the achievements that this industry sector and others that I have referred to—automotive, textiles, clothing and footwear, and many others—have been able to rack up.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Collins. Minister, yesterday you conceded that Telstra's handling of the CoT cases was not an admirable part of its history. Austel has described Telecom as `less than a model corporate citizen'. The Commonwealth Ombudsman has described Telecom `defective administration'. The telecommunications ombudsman has described the arbitration process as `clearly the low-water mark of effective customer relations'. Coopers and Lybrand have said that Telecom's customer complaints service `failed to meet the minimum standard of adequacy, reasonableness and fairness'. The Federal Police found prima facie evidence of Telecom's monitoring and taping of CoT members' services. In view of the weight of this condemnation from the watchdogs and yourself as a former communications minister, will the government refer this matter to an independent inquiry?

—I did say yesterday that this was not an admirable part of Telstra's otherwise impressive record of service delivery in Australia. And I say that with deep regret, because one of the most appreciated government owned entities in the part of the country that I come from, the Northern Territory, is Telstra, which has done an extraordinarily good job of providing outstanding communications to Australia's rural isolated areas—an outstanding job.
—Why do you want to sell it then?
—I do not want to see it owned by Bell Telephone, actually, or ATT—
—You are going to sell it; Labor's going to sell it.

—No, we are not. I said that it was one of the sorriest episodes in Telstra's history. I thought it was, personally, regrettable that, on a freedom of information application that was made by people in that category of clients—small, thankfully, in number—that Telstra were servicing, on that occasion they had to get the aid of the ombudsman in that application under freedom of information. But I did advise the Senate yesterday, as Senator Boswell knows—and I acknowledge his long time personal interest in pursuing this matter—

PARA.TAB: Senator McKiernan interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, you have to pay credit where credit is due, Senator McKiernan—and I am happy to. He has doggedly pursued this issue for years here in the Senate. I did give an undertaking when I was communications minister that I would do something about it—and did.

PARA.TAB: The situation is, as I have described it yesterday, that one of the cases has been already completed; one has been settled; nine others are well advanced, I am advised at this point, and close to completion; and one application has been withdrawn. As to what further action the government might take in respect of Telstra when this matter is concluded, I will refer that part of the senator's question to the Minister for Communications and the Arts.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer the minister to a statement earlier this year by Justice Michael Kirby, President of the Australian section of the International Commission of Jurists, who called for all Australian political parties to support the reference to the World Court of the legality of the use of nuclear weapons and threatening such use. I also refer the minister to Senator Gareth Evans's answer to my question without notice on 2 June 1994 on the same question. I ask: what is the current position of the Australian government in relation to the reference of the question of the legality of nuclear weapons to the International Court of Justice? In particular, will Australia be taking any part in these hearings? Does the minister acknowledge that the decisions by China and France to continue nuclear testing after the finalisation of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty has highlighted the need for a legal ruling on the use or threat of the use of nuclear weapons?

—The government is aware of the call by Justice Michael Kirby for all Australian political parties to support the reference to the International Court of Justice of the question of the legality of use or threat of use of nuclear weapons. As the Prime Minister said in his Hiroshima Day statement on 5 August, Australia will make a submission to the forthcoming oral hearings on the two advisory opinions the court has received on the subject, taking the opportunity to make clear both our general position on nuclear disarmament and our strong opposition to nuclear testing.

PARA.TAB: The government is committed without reservation to the eventual elimination of nuclear weapons and sympathises very much with those who seek an advisory opinion from the ICJ designed to secure a ruling on their legality. The difficulty, however, of exacting any such opinion from the court is that we seriously doubt whether it would in practice assist the goal of eliminating nuclear weapons. In the first place, there is a very real chance that the ICJ may actually find the use of nuclear weapons legal and, in some instances, the cause of eliminating nuclear weapons would obviously not be advanced.

In the very unlikely event the ICJ were to find the use of nuclear weapons illegal, in every possible and relevant way, this would contradict the stated doctrines of those nuclear weapon states and be extremely unlikely to be accepted by them. It is for this reason that Australia's earlier written submission to the ICJ on the request of the World Health Organisation for an advisory opinion on the illegality issue has argued that the court should exercise its discretion not to provide such an opinion on the substance of the question asked. It is for this reason that we made no further written submission to the ICJ in response to a request by the UN General Assembly for a similar advisory opinion.

As to the second part of your question: you would be aware that the government has emphatically condemned both China and France's nuclear testing. What their testing has highlighted is the need to bring an end to all testing for all time. The government is working actively to achieve as soon as possible a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty to ban all testing. Practical measures such as this are the most effective means of moving towards our common goal for the eventual elimination of all nuclear weapons.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development. Why is the government spending $300,000 on consultants for a media campaign to be conducted between now and January next year to publicise Mr Howe's housing and regional development statement, which was scheduled for next Monday? Why aren't Mr Howe's departmental public relations group and staff being used in the exercise?

—There has been one consistent thrust from the opposition over recent years, and that has been the need to contract out services to cut down the size of government and to be able to get specialist services from outside of government to perform functions—some aspect of your policy that was maybe on the second page of that document you circulated just a few months ago, the disposable policy document. But it has been consistent. When we in government develop programs and services, we recognise that development is one important aspect. But for people to know about them—to know what their rights are, to know what services are available to them and to know what is available to their communities—is also an important aspect, not just as an information service but also as an access to government service.

PARA.TAB: What Mr Howe is doing here is developing programs and services in such a way that the community will have rights and aspects of access available to them. As a consequence, there is a need for the community to be made aware of that. We are doing so probably in the most cost-effective way—by getting specialist services from outside government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Howe's department has a public relations group. Why is it not being used in this instance? Why are you spending $300,000 of taxpayers' money on this statement? What is the total cost of the campaign, including the cost of advertising and departmental support? Who is the successful consultant? How much will the Labor Party be contributing, or is this just another grubby attempt to transfer the cost of Labor Party political advertising to the long struggling Australian tax paying families?

—This is not a supplementary question. In fact, it is another question asking for more information which will be taken on notice. It is the ordinary function of government to promote government services. This is no such grubby attempt. Let me say to you, Senator Macdonald, that what you do by asking both that question and the supplementary question is once again expose the inadequacy and incompetence of your side of parliament. You have got no idea about government. We are just looking at the frontbench over there and wondering what you would be like in government. I must admit that any person outside here who has a perception of a new group coming in with new ideas will be very soon discouraged. As Senator Ray said, what party pretending to take over government would put a rabbit in charge of the environment? Only the opposition.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley. Is the minister aware of a statement today that the peak organisation of private child-care centres, the Australian Federation of Child Care Associations, has dissociated itself from claims made against the accreditation system? Can the minister provide further information to the Senate on this important accreditation system.

—I thank the senator for her question. I also very much appreciate the press release issued today by the Australian Federation of Child Care Associations in response to the attacks by some child-care operators, and of course the opposition, on the accreditation system and the 13-member council. The federation has dissociated itself from those outrageous comments and the huge misrepresentations being made about that very successful accreditation system, which is improving quality care for our children in child-care centres.

PARA.TAB: I repeat for the benefit of the opposition, who cannot or will not hear, that no child-care centre has failed to get accreditation because children say grace. What centres do in this regard is up to the parents and the centres. It is up to the parents and the centres to make those decisions. No child-care centre has failed to get accreditation because children say grace. In any one week, 230,000 children will attend a long day care centre. It is hard to understand why the opposition would want to oppose any efforts to ensure the quality of child care.

Some 99 per cent of child-care centres have registered for accreditation. They are getting on with the process. Most have found it a very rewarding experience and most report that the quality of child care in their centres has improved as a result of that accreditation process. I refer senators to the report from Coopers and Lybrand. I have quoted that report in this place before, and I am happy to do so again. But it shows conclusively—that is an independent evaluation of this system after the first year—that the process was a constructive one for people to participate in and that the quality has increased in child-care centres.

There are five steps in the accreditation process, and I will outline them for those on the Liberal Party benches and those on the National Party benches so that they can be clear. Those five steps are: registration; self-study; review by a peer; examination of the reviewer's comments by recognised experts in the early childhood field; and, to complete the process, a decision of the national accreditation child-care council.
The important thing is to remind senators, particularly Senator McGauran, who I note is not here, that reviewers—

TALK.START.PARA: —You were the first one even to notice.

—I apologise for that, Senator Ray. Reviewers are not government officials; they are child care workers who understand the challenges of delivering long day care. Staff in child-care centres are reassured to know that the person who is reviewing their centre is someone just like them. They are not government officials.
—That is a misrepresentation.

—They are not government officials, Senator Troeth. If you are talking of misrepresentation, check your own colleague's press releases. It should be noted that the information provided by centres is treated confidentially by the council, not by Senator McGauran, who has actually put out a press release naming a centre. That centre is deeply distressed, and it properly ought to be. The council has preserved its privacy and the government has not named it, but you over there have broken that confidentiality and privacy. You say it out one side of your mouth, but you do not respect it.

PARA.TAB: I listened to the opposition yesterday talking about truth in political advertising. If they took seriously the pious words that they were putting on the air yesterday about the seriousness of truth and truth in the political process, they should look to the misrepresentations that have been going out about this accreditation process. It is a process that has improved quality, families like it and the opposition is out of step. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is it true that the resignation rates from the Royal Australian Navy have increased significantly in the recent past? If they have increased, is it true that, on an annualised basis on the latest figures, they would be approaching 16 per cent?

—The most desirable attrition rate in any defence force is 10 per cent. In economic good times they usually reach about 13 per cent and in times of recession they go down to about six per cent. We would all agree that about 10 per cent turnover is ideal. I cannot give you the actual figures relating to attrition in the navy, but I will get back to you on that. The more worrying areas are some of the more specialist areas where it can absolutely affect the competency of those particular weapons platforms. They are the areas of most concern to us.

PARA.TAB: In the last two days I have received the Glenn report, which has looked at some of the personnel matters. It is quite evident from that study—I do not want to go into the details yet because I have not given it full consideration—that there will be recommendations and a changing of the way the various services do business. It is not just a matter of pay and conditions—they are always important—but it is also a matter of family dislocation, opportunities for spouse employment and a whole range of things that put pressure on whether people stay in the services.

On top of all that is the society pressure of change which means that very few people stay in the same profession forever. You can see that reflected in the rest of society. That will impact back on to the defence forces. The way that it can be most effectively resisted is through changing the way in which the job is done in many cases. Consideration will have to be given to a whole range of measures in the long term. The next decade will see a much higher concentration on development of personal skills and the retention of personnel in defence forces than the previous decade. Consideration to issues such as payment for tasks rather than according to rank will be one of the many issues that are thought of in the next few months and years, I suspect.

I think what you will see in order to meet these sorts of problems is governments of the future concentrating on these personnel areas. It is not just the simple question of money in the direct sense of money in the pocket; it is also the way they do business and the way they exist within the defence forces that people must be dealt with.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his answer and accept his assurance that he will get a percentage figure for the Senate as soon as possible. In relation to manning strengths for ships, has there been an order promulgated through maritime command to increase the number of reservists available for seagoing duties to get ships to sea?

—It is also related to the traditional level of tasking, which is another thing we have to look at. That sort of tasking quite often perpetuates from year to year without a lot of challenge or a lot of analysis. In terms of reservists, we do encourage, where there are shortages, reservists to come in. There are limitations on that. Again, the Glenn review goes to that—limitations as to how long a reservist can serve in a full-time capacity and a whole range of other things. But in terms of reservists, I see nothing wrong with their coming in and getting that sort of experience. I think we have to do a lot to eliminate some of the restrictions that currently exist on them in terms of days served.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the report of the Industry Commission inquiry into charities which will be tabled in the parliament next week. The concern of many people about the effect of this report remains high. Therefore, I ask the minister: firstly, whether the government agrees with the Director of the Australian Catholic Health Care Association that:

QUESTION.PARA: Charity and benevolence are traditionally signs of a mature and substantial community. . . They are the basis on which the charitable organisational system in Australia is sustained.

Secondly, is the government aware of the disastrous effect of tendering on the quality of such Victorian services as Meals on Wheels, the ambulance service and maternal and child health? Thirdly, does the government intend to introduce competitive tendering for services in the community and welfare sectors?

TALK.START.PARA: —Charitable organisations are very significant to the Australian economy and to Australian society. I do endorse the quote employed in the first part of the question. That is why, of course, the government and the Industry Commission decided to conduct an inquiry into this sector. The commission's draft report was released on 28 October last year. The draft report, when it came down, was broadly welcomed by organisations such as the Salvation Army and the Brotherhood of St Laurence.

PARA.TAB: The significance of this sector was demonstrated by the Industry Commission's draft report. The commission estimated that out of the total expenditure of $4.4 billion annually, $2.5 billion is provided by governments, $1 billion from fund raising and other income, and $900 million from client fees. The draft report also highlighted the significant and diverse contributions which these organisations make in delivering community services to Australians.

Many of the recommendations contained in the commission's report focus on the need for improved accountability of charitable organisations to their donors. This includes a consistent set of principles to guide funding agreements between governments and charitable organisations. The Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs has already acknowledged that the Industry Commission draft report on charitable organisations has assisted his initiatives to improve the accountability of organisations providing overseas aid. I think they are quite important points to bear in mind.

As Senator Woodley said, the government will be making its initial response—and I emphasise the word `initial'—to the commission's report when it is tabled next Wednesday. It is not appropriate for me to pre-empt what the government will say in that response. But I assure the Senate and Senator Woodley—who, I might say, deserves some recognition as one of the senators in this place who have pursued this question consistently—that the government is well aware of the significant contribution which this sector makes. We are aware of the concerns regarding some of the commission's recommendations, but you will have to wait until we formally provide our response to the report before I can enlarge on that any further.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. What guarantee will the government give that the effect of its move to a tendering model will be any different from the effect on the Victorian community and welfare sectors?

—With the greatest of respect to this question, it involves me to assume that there will be a move to a tendering model. As I said, I cannot pre-empt what the government will say, nor should I. When it does respond to the report and when its position—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand there was some sort of offensive interjection, but let me just let that pass. The appropriate point is: we will respond to the whole report. I do not want to speculate about what that response will contain now.

—My question is directed to Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Defence. Minister, I refer to your widely reported comments from July this year in which you stated that you would take legislation to cabinet to overturn the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission on HIV-positive members of the ADF. You repeated this commitment to the national congress of the RSL in Melbourne on Thursday, 7 September. Have you taken the draft legislation to cabinet yet? If not, when will you honour your commitment to do so? If the matter has been considered by cabinet, what has been the decision, and when shall we see the legislation before the Senate?

—The matter has not gone to cabinet yet. The submission is ready. There is a view in the legal section of Defence that we may be able to do this by way of regulation, which was not apparent before. Even though the cabinet submission is ready to lodge and go through, I would rather explore that and save the Senate the time. If, indeed, that view does not prevail and we need to legislate, then it will go to cabinet within the next two or three weeks.

PARA.TAB: You asked when we will legislate on it. Drawing up legislation in this place is dead easy; getting it through this chamber or through the parliamentary process is not easy. I think the very intention, if it is introduced and attracts a majority of support, will have the effect in any event.

In summary, the submission is ready. An alternative and more convenient way is being explored. If that does not come to fruition, I will take it to cabinet and take my chances there. If I am successful, legislation will be drawn up according to the government's timetable and the priorities it gives it. I will be trying to push those priorities. If you have no supplementary, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, as you are aware, opposition senators are becoming increasingly frustrated by the apparent bias in the calling of senators to ask questions, which is a bias against the interests of the coalition in favour of the minority parties. I simply draw your attention to today, which is pretty typical, I would say. Yes, you count them, Mr President, because I have counted them as well.
—What do you count as a supplementary?

—I remind you, Senator Kernot, that the Democrats had two questions today and both of you asked supplementaries. Let us not allow the question of supplementaries to derail the principle. The principle is that the Democrats were called two times today—two questions out of seven Democrats, a ratio of one to 3 1/2; the Greens one out of two Greens; and the coalition six out of 36, a ratio of one to six. The question, therefore, is: why are opposition senators not given the same opportunity to ask questions as members of the minority parties in this place? Mr President, why should you call senators in this place on our side in prejudice to us and in benefit of the minority parties?

PARA.TAB: It would seem from correspondence that you recognise that the practice that has been adopted in recent times is unfair and that it was your wish to move to a fairer system but, because of pressure from certain parties in this place, you feel unable to do so. I put it to you, Mr President, that you should not be pushed around by minority parties. You have a responsibility to all senators to act fairly in relation to each and every individual in this place. That means on the coalition's side that out of 36 senators—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is Noel in the party?
—Thirty-five. The principle is just the same, Senator. If you want to emphasise—

—On a point of order: I take very great exception to aspersions cast on the chair, and there was another one. I do not know if you wish to defend yourself, but I ask you to rule on the aspersion that you were pushed around by anybody.
—I will be commenting on that in due course, but thank you for your support.

—I voice the frustration of those on this side. We are entitled to a fair go. We are entitled to fairness from the chair—fairness in relation to not only government senators but also minority parties. I take this opportunity to ask you what you are going to do about it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I do not think these matters would ever be settled in the chamber in any event. I must say I missed the last Procedure Committee meeting. It would be much better if we belt it around in there. I do not think anyone wants to deprive the opposition of its fair share of questions. Certainly it is not the attitude on this side that we do, that we want to deprive those opposite of their fair share of questions. I point out we did probably cost them a question this time, although we got the final question in with five seconds to go, which probably balanced up the account today, but we may not have if Senator Cook had expended his full time.

PARA.TAB: Turning to the question on proportionality, there is also a thing called tradition and that is basically what the President is ruling on—the way it has been traditionally done.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not tradition at all. It is a practice adopted of recent times.

—No. Let us put it this way, it is a sort of evolving tradition—the way the minority parties have been looked after in terms of questions. They are not in a position numerically to defend themselves on this particular issue. We do neither seek to condemn nor defend them in any particular thing but steer a neutral course where people are satisfied with question time. The only point I make is that you should go away and look at it again. I do not think you would be able to negotiate or settle it here.
—You cannot negotiate it.

—Senator Hill says you cannot negotiate it. What I am urging on him is at least one more attempt to negotiate it over the next week at a Procedure Committee meeting. If we cannot, then take your matter further. I say from a government point of view that we seek fairness at question time in the distribution of questions. We do not know whether there are any magic formulas to do with it. I do not think this has ever been evolved in order to dud the opposition. The way it has evolved has been an historical sort of thing under three Presidents, different ratios of minority parties, et cetera.
—Governments become oppositions; oppositions become government.
—I wish you would remember that just once, Senator Newman. It is a very prosaic thing. What goes up comes down. You do not remember that, but we will not start that debate here today.

—by leave—I have two things I want to add to the points that Senator Hill has just made. As you, Mr President, and the other whips will recall, we did have a meeting on this subject. I am sure Senator Panizza would have reported back to Senator Hill on the attitudes of the different participants in that meeting. I am sure he would have reported back to Senator Hill that the attitude of the Democrat participant in that meeting was that we would abide by your ruling and we would hope that the whole thing would go to the Procedure Committee, which has happened.

PARA.TAB: We did not say at any time in that meeting that we demanded that it remain the way it was. In fact, if I recall, it was the Democrat representative at that meeting who suggested that the way it should go ahead was the way that you, Mr President, had suggested in your letter and that the whole question should go to the Procedure Committee to be dealt with.

Following that, we received some communication from you—I cannot remember whether it was a letter or phone call—saying that others in this chamber had said that if the status quo did not remain then there would be problems. It was not the Democrats who said that. You ought to know that, Senator Hill. If you do not, then there is a real problem with communication between the leader and the whip of the opposition.

I would like to make one more point while I am on my feet—that is, this whole thing will go to the Procedure Committee. It has been referred to the Procedure Committee. It will be looked at by the Procedure Committee. I know the Procedure Committee will question the assumptions upon which these allocations were made and will finally come up with some solution which will be agreed to amongst the Procedure Committee. I hope that will then be agreed to by the Senate as a whole.

The Democrats would really appreciate it if we were not tarred with the same brush because we are not entitled to be. That is totally unfair. Senator Hill knows it. If he does not know it, there is a real breakdown in communications between him and his whip.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I agree with Senator Ray: the Procedure Committee is the place to sort this out, not here. However, it needs to be said that the reason the Greens were not comfortable with the proposals that were being made is that it is the Greens and the Independents who are being asked to accept a reduction from one question every three days to one every four days. That will have considerable implications, not just for us but for others as well.
—I only get one every month.

—I understand that. We believe that the opposition has a very legitimate point. We are asking for the situation to be addressed in a more equitable way but not by penalising the people at the bottom of the pecking order. If we stay with the status quo for single senators, in the long run each of us will benefit because the opposition will be responding proportionally.

PARA.TAB: There are two principles involved. It is not just a matter of the proportion in which we are represented in this place; this is the only opportunity for the opposition to question ministers. Ministerial accountability is the major consideration at question time. Ministers must be accountable to the rest of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —In proportion.

—Yes, in proportion to representation—minus the ministers and the President—because that is the role of question time. The Greens have a proposal that they are prepared to take to the Procedure Committee, which will look at this and obtain a consensus position.

—by leave—Mr President, I can assure you of one thing: there is no breakdown in communication between the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) and myself. I can also tell you that what Senator Bourne has said about the arrangement under the new pro rata system—fair proportional representation of the whole Senate—is correct.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, you used that system of proportional representation for about one week. I believe it worked very well. Obviously, unbeknown to us, there was pressure on you from someone who was not satisfied with it. Without any reference to us, you went back to the old system.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's not listening to you.
—How far back do you want me to go, Mr President?
—It is all right. Go ahead.

—I will go back a little bit. After the negotiations we had, which included everyone—Senator Chamarette was part of it—we agreed on proportional representation. I understand that you, Mr President, operated that system for a week, more or less.

PARA.TAB: You may have missed this point while you were talking to Senator Faulkner: obviously you had pressure from someone in this chamber—and Senator Bourne said it was not her and Senator Kernot went along the same line. If you were not under pressure from them, you must have had pressure from somebody. You reverted to the old system, and you told me you reverted to the old system, without referring back to us. So I believe, Mr President, that you have to explain to the chamber why you went back to the old system, because I thought that that system worked very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, just to clarify the situation, you had a meeting with the whips, and we discussed question time. After a long discussion, we could not resolve the situation. We then decided that we ought to have the questions asked on the basis of the representation of the various political parties within the Senate. That is the way that it went. The Democrats went along with that. The Greens, of course, were not happy with that.

PARA.TAB: So, because we could not get a general agreement, we said that maybe the best way to go is to continue with the questions being asked on the basis of the representation in the Senate and to refer the matter to the Procedure Committee for a further discussion. That is where it sat, and that is exactly what happened. Whether what Senator Panizza told Senator Hill got mixed up in the communication, I do not know, but that is exactly what happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —The President is not calling them on the basis of representation.

—What you have to say is that it is the basis of the way in which it would be called, yes. But at different times it just depends. If the President is calling the people, then he has to call it the way that he sees it. He is in the chair, and he tries to go to the proportion that we said. If you go through and look at the total number of questions asked, you will find that it works out fairly evenly. You only have to look at the sheet that was sent out, and I think it was sent to everyone. If you look at the sheet that was sent out with the questions on it and the proportion of the questions that were allocated to each political party, you will find that it is fairly true to what we are now talking about.
—That is how it should be.
—No, you are arguing about something you don't know about. Do you want to have a look at the sheet?

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—While it has been indicated that we have behaved cooperatively, and I am talking about my behaviour and Senator Bourne's, I still want to say that I think there is room in the Procedure Committee, as I have said to the President previously, for some assumptions to be questioned. I just put on the record that I think these assumptions which govern the decisions about the allocation of questions need to be questioned. I do not have a definitive view on them, but I think they need to be questioned.

PARA.TAB: The first assumption I think we should question is whether ministers should be counted in the total or not. On the one hand, they equal the total of representatives that have been elected but, on the other hand, they cannot physically ask questions—that is true. The second assumption I would ask to be tested is whether supplementary questions should count as full questions or not. The third assumption is whether the right to ask questions is a collective or an individual entitlement—whether it is a collective party entitlement or the individual senator's entitlement. I think that whatever discussion the Procedure Committee has, to be fair, it must at least address those assumptions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to prolong this debate, but I just want to comment very briefly. Firstly, this is not the appropriate place to be discussing this; outside is. Secondly, I am not pushed around by anybody or threatened by anybody, and I do not respond to those sorts of things.

PARA.TAB: I did write to the parties because there was, based on a longstanding agreement between the parties as to how question time would be organised in the proportionate sense, a skewing of the questions, which I drew attention to originally and agree with. There is a skewing of the allocation of questions now which works against the opposition on the one hand, but more so against the government, and is in favour of both the Greens and the Democrats.

I called a meeting of the whips to discuss this. We could come to no agreement, but I went away to look at a series of proposals that I might put back to that whips' committee. I then wrote to the whips with a proposal which I did, as Senator Panizza correctly says, apply for a week.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was very fair, too.

—It did not have time to be fair, Senator, because it did not get to the point where it was actually applied, so you are not making much sense in that comment. There was reaction to that; a second whips meeting was called, and the whole question of assumptions underlying the issue of question time, which both Senator Chamarette and Senator Kernot have raised, was raised there. It was at that meeting decided that we would pursue the thing through the Procedure Committee, which is now happening. All senators will be written to—if they have not already been written to—for their views. The Procedure Committee will meet to look specifically at that question. In the meantime, I made it clear that we would go back to the old system until the Procedure Committee met, and that is where we are now.
—I wish to provide additional details in relation to a question that was asked of me yesterday by Senator Chamarette.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the four-member panel of independent scientists referred to in her question was selected to provide a balance of experience and included members with expertise in conservation, biogeography and botanical disciplines and experience of Western Australian forests. The panel has collectively consulted with over 15 scientists in Western Australia and in other states, including, where available, the authors of the key scientific references on the subject. In addition, the panel consulted the relevant Australian scientific literature, along with information supplied by Western Australian CALM and the submission from the Western Australian Conservation Council.

The composition of the scientific panel was the responsibility of Professor Michael Pitman as Chief Scientist and chairman of the scientific advisory group. As the panel was to assess Western Australian reserves established by CALM, the composition of the panel was discussed with the agency prior to the Commonwealth determining the composition of the panel. The panel has advised the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet that, while the system of administrative, riparian and road reserves made a significant, though non-quantifiable, contribution to the protection of conservation values in the south-west forests, large consolidated forest areas should remain the priority choice in the assembly of a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Alston this day, relating to the ALP policy for the next election with regard to guaranteeing no new taxes or increases in existing taxes for the following three years.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cook did not answer the question. In fact, he said, among other things, firstly, that there would be a continuation of existing policies, and, secondly, `We will, if we can, bring the budget burden down.'

PARA.TAB: Let me go to the first point—continuation of existing policies. I remind the Senate and the Australian community that this government, since Mr Keating has been Prime Minister—let us go back only in that period—has increased the taxation burden very substantially on the Australian community. For the financial year 1992-93, which is the first full year of Mr Keating's reign, the total burden taken from the community by taxation and other charges by the Commonwealth government was $95 billion. This current financial year, it is $125 billion, an increase of $30 billion, or over 30 per cent, over a four-year period. The CPI adjustment over that period is something less than $12 billion. So there has been a huge increase in taxation and charges on the Australian community over that short period.

But that is not all. In the financial year at the start of Mr Keating's reign, the debt by the Commonwealth was $30 billion. It is estimated that at the end of this current financial year it will be virtually $100 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who owes it?

—It is Commonwealth government debt. You have spent an additional $70 billion. Not only have you increased the burden of the community for payment from $95 billion to $125 billion, but you have borrowed an additional $70 billion and spent that as well. Not only have you done that but you have also spent assets. We cannot find out the aggregate numbers of assets spent.

PARA.TAB: In addition to that, the investment by the Commonwealth back in 1984-85 was about eight per cent of total outlays. In this current financial year, investment by the Commonwealth is minus 2.3 per cent. So what has happened? We have had this big spending, big taxing government that has increased taxation revenue enormously, borrowed enormously and sold off assets—and Senator Cook says that we will see more of the same. Well, pity help the poor Australian community if we are going to see more of that.

The other day the World Bank brought out a report which said Australia is the wealthiest country in the world because of our high assets. However, our income is low. Our income used to be the highest in the world, but it has now dropped down to about 18th. Something with high assets and low income in the commercial world is ripe for takeover because it indicates poor management. That is exactly what applies to this government—poor management: high assets, wasted assets and low income for the Australian people. Senator Cook promised us that your government will offer us at the next election more of the same. Well, pity the poor Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question that was asked of Senator Cook today was: can the minister confirm to Australian families that ALP policy for the next election will be to guarantee no new taxes or increases in existing taxes in the following three years? The relevancy of that question is very important, given this government's record, as my colleague Senator Gibson has just enunciated, since Paul Keating took over as Prime Minister. The day he became Prime Minister he made three pledges. The second pledge was to deal honestly with the people and tell them the truth. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: In tough times, of course, the temptation is always to gild the lily. I'll be resisting that temptation as much as is humanly possible. I'll speak honestly with them, to them, and realistically . . .

The heart of this question goes to that honesty. Since the 1993 federal election, Mr Keating has jacked up taxes by more than $3 billion a year. We have higher taxation of unused long service leave and annual leave lump sum payments; an increased tax on credit unions; increases in fringe benefits tax; increases in the general rate of wholesale sales tax, which is up two per cent right across the board, on everything; extra sales tax on wine and cider; an increase in petrol excise, which is up 7c a litre for leaded petrol and 5c a litre for unleaded petrol; an increase in tobacco excise; an increase in departure tax; an increase in sales tax on cars; an increase in company tax; and an increase in Medicare tax, otherwise known as the levy.

PARA.TAB: We are quite legitimately asking this government to come clean, in advance of the next election, as to whether they are going to increase existing taxes and introduce any new taxes. They went to the last election, the 1993 election, promising no increases in existing taxes and promising no new taxes. All of those lies have now come to fruition. All of those promises have been broken. Not only have those promises been broken but the much heralded l-a-w tax cuts were jettisoned within a matter of weeks.

Until this government starts to come clean and say whether or not they are going to have a policy on tax this time and detail the taxes they are going to increase, one can only quite rightly presume from their record that they are going to continue in the way they have done in the last 12 years; that is, steadily increase taxes. You cannot have over $3 billion worth of tax increases in but two years, since the last election, and then come in here and try and hoodwink the people of Australia into believing that they are not going to be suffering further tax increases.

The one per cent tax increase across the board as of 1 July meant that every single solitary product that is sold in Australia went up, including things like fruit, vegetables and meat, which this mob claim are not taxed. The fact of the matter is that every section of input taxes went up thanks to this government's increase of two per cent in the last year and one per cent in July of this year. That is on, as I say, fruit, vegetables, meat, confectionery, washing powder, detergents, soap, personal hygiene products, fruit juices and pet food. And the list goes on and on and on. Most people do not realise they are now paying 22 per cent sales tax on things like toothpaste, recycled paper products, toilet paper, umbrellas and all of those sorts of things that they were told prior to the last election were not taxed by this Labor government.

The fact of the matter is that the government has simply not told the truth prior to the last number of elections, in particular prior to the 1993 election. It will be interesting to see whether Senator Cook eventually answers the question that Senator Alston rightly put to him today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wheelwright Sen T.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Treasurer (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Short this day, relating to the economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I rise because there was an implication—in fact, if memory serves me it was an outright allegation—on the part of Senator Short that there was a connection between the foreign debt of this country and home mortgage interest rates. That is absolutely, completely and utterly untrue. I will argue that anywhere in this country in front of any audience.

PARA.TAB: The reason is perfectly simple. There are two categories of interest rates. There are short-term interest rates and long-term interest rates. That fact is known by any 20-year-old money market dealer on any dealing desk anywhere in this country. The home mortgage rate is driven by short-term interest rates, and the long-term interest rates are the ones affected by the overseas debt.

There are two consequences for this untruth, which I believe is being peddled deliberately by those senators opposite. Either they do not know the distinction, in which case they should be nowhere near the treasury bench in this country, or they do know the distinction and they are deliberately seeking to deceive people and frighten them about the future of their home mortgage rates and, might I also say, seeking to frighten people who are in small business who are dependent on the short-term money market through 90-day bills to finance their business.

If you look at what this government has done, you will see that it has an exemplary record as far as short-term interest rates in this country are concerned because it has brought down inflation. That is what makes a difference to the home mortgage rate. Since the home mortgage rate was deregulated by this government as part of its deregulation of the financial markets, the home mortgage interest rate has been determined by the cash rate plus a margin. Senator Short knows that. Senator Short must know that because he has a career as an economist. Any economist could tell the Senate that fact.

If you look at the cash rate, you will see that it is driven by the inflation rate. That is why it is as low as it is today. If you look at long-term interest rates, you will see that the Commonwealth government does not borrow overseas on the long-term bond market. It has not done so for eight years. The total outstanding debt in terms of Commonwealth government bonds is only five per cent of the foreign debt. All of these facts are known perfectly well by senators opposite.

What we had in the attempt by not only Senator Short but also his colleagues, by their vociferous interjections during question time and by the shadow Treasurer on the AM program this morning, was a deliberate attempt to deceive Australians about a matter which is serious to them in terms of the future of their home mortgage rates. It is cheap politics. It is cheap politics in the same way as it was cheap politics to bring on the Western Australian royal commission. It was cheap politics to have this `lorry of lies' running around the countryside seeking to trivialise what is a major problem in this country and it is cheap politics now to make this assertion that somehow the government is responsible for higher mortgage rates. It is absolutely not true—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is irresponsible to suggest that it is not otherwise.
—It is absolutely the case that there is no relationship between the two, Senator. If you do not know that, you should go back and study economics. That is the only hope for you.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, let me say that the people of Australia will realise that this sort of shabby politics, this seeking to deceive, this trying to pull the wool over the Australian public's eyes will not work. If the senators opposite want to come out with some real response to home mortgage rates, if they really want to come out with some real response to long-term interest rates, if they want to come out with some response to the foreign debt in this country—where is your savings policy? That is the thing that makes a difference to foreign debt in this country.

The last budget, which you sought to sabotage, was the real and effective way of addressing the savings imbalance in this country through superannuation. You have nothing to say on that subject now and you never will. We can wait a long day before we hear it. This dishonesty has to stop.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Wheelwright, I understand, advised Mr Keating when he was the Treasurer—
—You are wrong again.
—the Prime Minister. I also understand that, when Senator Wheelwright got the Senate preselection, Prime Minister Keating described him as a bonehead—and today I can understand absolutely why.

PARA.TAB: This morning on ABC radio the Treasurer, Mr Willis, jumped on this bandwagon of Labor's campaign of lies about foreign debt, and Senator Wheelwright has perpetuated that campaign this afternoon. The two big lies are the denials that foreign debt increases interest rates and that the increase in foreign debt has been caused by the government. Of the coalition's point that the foreign debt means higher interest rates for Australians on their mortgages—

TALK.START.PARA: —You said mortgage rates.
—on their mortgages and, indeed, all other forms of borrowings, Senator Wheelwright—the Treasurer this morning said:

SPEECH.PARA: That is completely and utterly untrue. There is not one skerrick of truth in that point.

Mr Willis's claims that foreign debt does not affect interest rates is the biggest piece of economic illiteracy to emanate from Labor to date. It indicates a desperate government more intent on misleading the public than owning up to its own mistakes. Yesterday even the Prime Minister admitted that:
We must work to deal with the current account problem so we are not paying too high a premium on world interest rate markets.
Dr Vince FitzGerald, the author of the report for the government on national savings and a former very senior government economic adviser, wrote:
We need to pay higher interest rates to compensate for the risks inherent in our high external debt.

The OECD in its report on Australia in just June of this year said that the widening external deficit which leads to higher foreign debt exerts `significant upward pressure on Australian real long-term interest rates'. This year's budget papers, which Mr Willis himself personally circulated, showed:
A high level of foreign borrowing relative to GDP can impose costs on an economy by making it more vulnerable to external shocks and by raising interest rate premiums on borrowings.
Inevitably, higher interest rates on foreign borrowings will flow through to the home mortgage market—

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—If you listen, you will get an answer—and the business lending market, as banks hold a large proportion of Australia's foreign debt. It is no coincidence, Senator Wheelwright, that Australia has the highest current account deficit in the OECD, the 47th worst ratio of net foreign debt to exports out of 51 countries rated by Standard and Poor's, and the highest bank prime interest rates amongst the developed countries surveyed by the Economist.

PARA.TAB: What Labor is doing is desperately trying to escape culpability for Australia's record $180,000 million of foreign debt. In doing so, it and you, I very much regret to say, today fell into the same net of throwing economic truth recklessly and wantonly out of the window—and you ought to be ashamed for doing so.

The reality is that Labor is to blame. There is a direct connection between Labor's budget deficits and Australia's foreign debt. The real story has been told by Dr Vince FitzGerald in his report. In a speech last year, he emphasised that even more. In terms of foreign borrowing, at the end of June 1995, 46 per cent of Australia's gross foreign debt had been issued by the public sector. True, most of that is state debt; but it is debt incurred because of the federal government's policies in relation to the states.

Far more importantly, the Commonwealth's massive borrowing within Australia to fund its budget deficits has crowded out private sector borrowers and forced them to go overseas to secure loan funds. It is that pressure on the private market that is forcing people to go overseas. It does not matter whether it is the private or public sector going overseas to borrow. The fact is that the government, through its budget deficit policy, has put such pressure on the domestic markets that interest rates inevitably go up, home mortgage rates get hit, as does every other interest rate in Australia, and it costs every Australian dearly. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had these questions now for two days.
—You will get them for more than that.

—We will be happy about that, because we will continue to highlight the fact that you have no policies and that all you want to do is pursue silly questions in this place and waste time. You think it is all so important to the Australian public about how they are going under us. We should have a look at how they are going under us and how they went under you lot when you were last in charge of the treasury bench. That is what is important. You will not come out and tell the public what you plan to do for the future, so we have to look at the past. The past is simply this: single age pensioners went backwards 2.3 per cent and age pensioner couples went backwards 2.1 per cent.

—I raise a point of order. Madam Deputy President, I know that debates on taking note of answers are usually far ranging; but you cannot possibly link what a pensioner was paid in 1977 to a debate about the foreign debt and interest rates in Australia in 1995. I ask you to rule on relevance.
—Senator Murphy, I think you perhaps should take some note of the question which you are debating.

—Madam Deputy President, I understood the question was about interest rates, how they affected the Australian public in paying for their homes, how their lives are going under this government and what might be the future for them. All I was doing was pointing—

—I raise a point of order. The debate is not about that. The debate is about the relationship between foreign debt and interest rates, and the government's lies in saying that there is no relationship.
—There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. As I said, we have to look at this whole process—whether it relates to interest rates, which ultimately have some impact on the people of this country. That is what we are really talking about. You can try to draw some parallel in terms of the question, but the reality is that the purpose of your question is designed to get a message out to the Australian public.

PARA.TAB: We have to compare the records. We do not know what your policies are for the future because you will not come out and tell anybody, so we have to go back to the past. A long time ago it may have been, but the reality is that under you in government last time round the people went backwards. Under us, disposable household income—despite all of your claims about taxes—has increased by almost 20 per cent. It did not do that when you were last in government; people went backwards.

You could not even get industrial relations right. We have brought about the lowest level of industrial disputation since 1942 when the records were first kept. That is what the people want to hear about. What is important is that we have been looking after the Australian public by implementing policies that have seen significant job growth that you could never even dream of. The inflation rate during the period that you were in government under Howard was 9.8 per cent. You could not even get it below seven per cent, and you talk about economic management. In terms of interest rates, which are so important to you, Senator Short, the underlying inflation rate when Howard left office was 10.5 per cent. What is it now? Substantially lower.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it now?
—It is less than 2 1/2 per cent.
—It is the second highest in the world.

—No, it is not. Then there is the matter of the share of debt and all of those sorts of things. One of the important factors in terms of interest rates versus foreign debt is the capacity of this country to service its debt. In that respect, we have never been in a better position.
—Stop lying about inflation. Inflation is 4 1/2 per cent. Why are you lying about it?

—You might not like the facts, Senator Campbell, but they are all there for everyone to see. It may be 13 years since the opposition has been in government, but the people have not forgotten, and they will not forget when the next election comes around.

—I will not deal with what Senator Murphy said because it had nothing to do with the issue. He was deliberately avoiding the issue. What concerns me is that a man for whom I did have some respect, Senator Wheelwright, has participated in what strikes me as being one of the most disgraceful attempts by this government to cover up its incompetence. Poor Australians, particularly young families, are having rising interest rates forced upon them as a result of not only government incompetence but also government malevolence.

PARA.TAB: I want to remind Senator Wheelwright of a few things. A year ago, the bank housing rate was 8.75 per cent; it is now 10.5 per cent. That is a 20 per cent increase in the rate; it is a one-fifth increase in the rate. I suppose it is just bad luck that our balance of payments happens to have blown out and that other rates in the marketplace have had that sort of effect. We have had a double lie. The first lie is that the foreign debt has had no impact at all on interest rates, and I will demonstrate that to be a lie. The second lie is that it was all due to the private sector anyway.

Detailed statistics put out by the Parliamentary Research Service show that public sector debt is $101 billion and net foreign debt is $180 billion. Some 60 per cent of Australia's net foreign debt is due directly to the public sector. Senator Wheelwright is going to say, `But that's all the states.' Those state borrowings are agreed at Commonwealth Loan Council meetings.

This is all part of the great economic plan by the world's greatest Treasurer. What has happened is that this nation has gone massively and hopelessly into debt. One of the reasons it has gone hopelessly into debt is that we are not exporting enough compared with the amount that we import. Another major reason is that we are not saving enough. If any Australian business person—remember, they account for only 40 per cent of the foreign debt—wants to borrow money, where do they borrow it from? They cannot borrow it in Australia because there is not enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have to go offshore.

—They have got to go offshore. There are not enough savings in Australia as a direct result of this government's incompetent policies. Let us see what happens. Not only is this government running the economy down, as it did with the worst recession we have had—the recession we had to have—but also it cannot run its own matters. It goes into the marketplace and chases the scarce resources with its massive deficits.

PARA.TAB: Not only is the government ruining the economy; it is also going into the marketplace with an $11 billion deficit. Where does the money come from? It has to borrow that money. It goes into the market, doesn't it, Senator Wheelwright, to borrow that money? Are you going to tell me that no foreigner invests in those Commonwealth securities? Of course not. It is phoney, and Senator Wheelwright knows it is phoney, for him to pretend that the marketplace for money is not influenced in any way by our massive deficit or by this government's incompetent management of the economy or by the positive and determined disincentives that this government has for savings in Australia by taxing the hell out of anyone who is foolish enough to save in this place.

The facts are that this government's policies have led to this disaster and this blow-out in the foreign account. Senator Wheelwright knows it perfectly well. He knows it is only because of a failure of Australia to participate fully and properly, as it could under decent management, in the world marketplace that we are going broke at the rate of between $2 billion and $3 billion a month. That means that people overseas are less willing to lend money to us to survive unless we pay a higher interest rate, and that higher interest rate pervades itself throughout the society. As I said, there has been a 20 per cent increase in the housing rate that Senator Wheelwright quite improperly sought to distinguish from the marketplace as a whole. What we have heard from Senator Wheelwright demeans him. It is disgraceful that a man of his background, who has been in the marketplaces, should convey this nonsense. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I knew that Senator Wheelwright was making some very pertinent points when the other side continually interjected or took points of order on him. Senator Wheelwright, you are new here: that is a compliment to you on the very points that you were making. The basic thrust of what you were saying is that interest rates are very much related to the rate of inflation. One of the confusions in this debate is that the Liberal Party and their spokesmen have shifted constantly between interest rates and mortgage rates and tried to transpose government comments accordingly and then say that there is a contradiction where, in fact, what they have done—I think through incompetence, not through maliciousness—is confused the two.

PARA.TAB: It is very important to understand where the basic economic position is and the comparative position when John Howard was Treasurer to understand interest rates. The pertinent facts are these: the average rate of economic growth under John Howard was 2.6 per cent while the average rate for the entire life of this government is 3.5 per cent. The average rate of inflation under John Howard was 9.8 per cent; under the Labor government for 12 to 13 years it has been 5.3 per cent, and since June 1991 it has been 2.3 per cent. The rate of inflation when John Howard left office was 11.4 per cent; the current rate of inflation is 4.5 per cent. The underlying rate of inflation when John Howard left office was 10.5 per cent; the underlying rate of inflation now is 2.5 per cent. The average number of jobs created per year when John Howard was Treasurer was 51,300; under this government 163,000 jobs have been created for its entire period. The average annual growth in employment under John Howard as Treasurer was 0.8 per cent; under this government it is 2.3 per cent.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for this debate has concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the 1993 federal election. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: THE GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS ENTITLED "THE 1993 FEDERAL ELECTION"
On 9 November 1994 the Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, Senator Dominic Foreman, tabled the Report on the Inquiry into the 1993 Federal Election.
That the AEC notify political parties and candidates at least 48 hours in advance of the date, time and place of a proposed visit of a mobile polling booth to an institution.

Supported. Under existing administrative arrangements all candidates are advised in writing of times and places of mobile polling in institutions at least one week before the commencement of mobile polling. The State Branches of the major political parties will be advised as well. However, it should be noted that mobile polling often requires last minute rescheduling within 48 hours of polling day due to local circumstances. For these reasons notification should remain an administrative arrangement and not be made mandatory by law.

That all patients in institutions be advised of their right to cast a postal vote if they are unable to vote at a mobile polling booth. The AEC should provide advisory forms for distribution in the institutions to assist in this process.

Supported. Hospital and institutional administrations are already supplied during the election period with postal voting materials where mobile polling facilities exist. The AEC will undertake to provide a standard advisory form to hospital and institutional administrations for distribution to patients and inmates prior to the visits by polling officials.

That standing instructions for AEC officers be amended to make clear that all patients in hospitals and nursing homes are to be presumed able to exercise their right to vote, unless the responsible AEC officer is satisfied on medical grounds that a patient is too incapacitated to cast a vote.
Supported. However, the decision of the responsible AEC officer should only be made on the advice of a medical practitioner or a responsible member of the medical staff of the hospital.

That the AEC improve education for hospital and nursing home administration staff to ensure that patients are not deprived of the right to vote, and that the rights of party scrutineers are understood and applied consistently.
Supported. The AEC will arrange for information to be made available to party scrutineers and to hospital and nursing home administrations for distribution to staff members.
That section 234 of the Electoral Act be amended to require that:

every elector voting at a mobile polling booth be informed of his or her right to be assisted in casting a vote. Where the elector requests assistance, the officer in charge of the booth shall identify the AEC officers and any scrutineers present, and inform the elector of his or her right to choose any one or none of those present to assist; and

require that unless the elector's medical condition necessitates the presence of medical staff, only the elector, an AEC officer and a scrutineer nominated by a candidate in the election may be present at the filling out of the ballot paper.

Supported in part. While the recommendation to advise every elector voting at mobile booths of their right to assistance is supported, it is essential that the right of the elector to nominate whoever they wish to assist them in casting their vote be retained. Existing administrative arrangements already require polling officials to advise voters of their right to assistance. However, the recommendation appears to seek to prevent the voter from nominating a friend or relative or a hospital staff member to assist them. This would constitute an unnecessary reduction in the current rights of the assisted voter and may cause distress to the aged and frail. The recommendation also appears to seek to allow all polling officials and scrutineers to observe the marking of ballot papers in all cases. This would infringe the secrecy of the ballot. Finally, the recommendation that polling officials and scrutineers should be formally identified to each voter is already catered for by provisions of the Act which require all polling officials and scrutineers to wear identification.

That subsection 226(5)(a) of the Electoral Act be amended to provide that subsection 340(1) (relating to canvassing near polling places) applies to a hospital that is a polling place, or a special hospital within the meaning of section 225, once such a hospital is actually in use as a polling place rather than from the issue of the writ.

Supported in part. For special hospitals, within the meaning of section 225, canvassing should not be permitted on any of the five days prior to and including polling day when mobile polling may take place. Without a definite cut off there is the possibility of disputes between mobile polling staff and canvassers, especially when last minute changes to mobile visiting times have been made necessary. The Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill currently before Parliament disallows canvassing in and around hospitals that are polling places on polling day and in special hospitals during the five days before and including polling day.
That subsection 225(1) of the Electoral Act be amended so that special hospitals can be gazetted at any time.
Supported. The Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill currently before Parliament makes provision for this.

That subsection 227(4) of the Electoral Act be amended to delete the requirement for the AEC to gazette the details of visits to remote communities by mobile polling teams, and to insert a requirement that the AEC give maximum public notice of the places, dates and times of such visits.

Supported. While gazettal of the place to be visited would continue, gazettal of other details is unnecessary and does not assist public information. Public notices lodged in other mediums, such as local newspapers, would more readily come to the attention of electors and allow the AEC more flexibility in scheduling mobile polling visits.

That subsection 222(2) of the Electoral Act be amended to restrict the right to vote, at a hospital which is declared a polling place, to an elector who is attending the hospital on polling day as a patient or visitor of a patient or an employee in the hospital.

Not supported. Implementation of this recommendation would disadvantage the public in their not being able to vote in places which are essentially public places. Polling booths in hospitals are established on the approval of the hospital administration and in such a location as to not inconvenience the day to day operation of the hospital. They operate as any other polling place on polling day, except that mobile teams also operate in the hospital wards. Should such a convenient location not be available in the hospital, a polling booth is not established on polling day. Instead, the hospital is declared as a special hospital and only mobile polling is undertaken. The implementation of this recommendation would create a practical problem of enforcement, effectively requiring the polling officials to interrogate voters as to their eligibility in an environment where such officiousness would not be appreciated.

That the AEC, in consultation with the political parties, review procedures to ensure that access to polling booths in remote and isolated areas is equally available to scrutineers for all candidates contesting an election in a Division.

Not supported. Administrative arrangements already require the AEC to advise candidates of remote mobile polling schedules and to carry how-to-vote cards where scrutineers are unable to reach all remote locations. This is the extent of the involvement the AEC should have in the canvassing activities of the candidates and political parties. The AEC should not be responsible for directly providing or in other ways ensuring that scrutineers have access to remote mobile locations, by for example providing transport. This should remain the responsibility of the political parties and candidates. The provision of transport facilities to remote polling places for the scrutineers of all candidates would not be economically feasible.
That the AEC minimise the use of dual booths at the next federal election.

Supported. While the use of dual booths increases the number of ordinary votes to be counted and speeds the result in an election, the AEC recognises the difficulties experienced by participants in the voting process resulting from dual polling booths. Accordingly, the AEC will actively review these and other polling places with a view to their rationalisation. Where population research indicates voter convenience and operational efficiency will be enhanced by the provision of dual booths, ways of providing for better signposting, better separation of voters, and better education will be investigated to minimise any identifiable local difficulties. It is noted that the Committee appears to be inconsistent in commending the use of multiple booths in metropolitan locations but not dual booths on Divisional boundaries.
That the AEC consult all parties contesting an election about the location of dual booths in a Division.

Not supported. The use of existing dual polling booths and the creation of new ones are decided well in advance of the election period on the basis of population research and administrative guidelines with the aim of enhancing voter convenience and operational efficiency, and before all parties contesting an election are known.
