DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to a report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee on rural adjustment, rural debt and rural reconstruction. I seek leave to have the document incorporated in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: The document read as follows—
Senator D Brownhill
Chair
Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Brownhill

I am responding on behalf of the Government to the Report of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee on Rural Adjustment, Rural Debt and Rural Reconstruction which was tabled on 6 December 1994.

First, let me congratulate the Committee for the thorough approach it took in addressing the terms of reference and for presenting what I consider to be a well-balanced report. I note from the Report that the Committee received 290 submissions, held 17 public hearings and took evidence from 262 witnesses.

I am pleased that the Committee supports the policy settings of the current Scheme (RAS `92), particularly the three-pronged objectives of farm productivity, profitability and sustainability. The Committee has also endorsed the significant shift in focus from the assistance measures provided under the RAS `88 to the central thrust of the RAS `92 arrangements which reorients the Scheme towards improved farm productivity, profitability and sustainability, or farm exit.

The Government supports the thrust of the Committee's report and recognises the Committee's concerns about aspects of administration and management of the Scheme. The Government has a program of measures in place to more effectively deliver the program to the target groups and monitor the performance of the Scheme against its objectives.

A number of the Committee's recommendations have already been implemented or are under active consideration outside of any Government response to the Committee's report. In the context of the Government's response to the drought, an enhanced Farm Management Bond scheme, removing the linkage between re-establishment grants and Job Search Allowance and new funding for a regional adjustment approach have already been implemented. The issues surrounding re-establishment, training, exceptional circumstances support, farm business plans, orderly exit, young farmers and appeal mechanisms, raised in the Report, have been under active consideration in the context of a review of the RAS guidelines which commenced in July 1994. A revised set of RAS guidelines are scheduled to
be completed soon.

The Report identified several major policy issues which require further consideration. These include whether interest rate subsidies are an effective instrument to facilitate structural adjustment, whether the principal mechanism to deliver outcomes should become skills enhancement rather than productivity enhancement, and the removal of exceptional circumstances provisions from the RAS and their inclusion in a separate Commonwealth-State agreement. These issues will be further considered by the Government, including as part of an evaluation of the RAS scheduled to commence early next year and to be completed by 31 December 1996.
A schedule outlining the Government's response to all recommendations and providing comment on the major conclusions and recommendations contained in the Report is attached.
Thank you again for the constructive approach which the Committee adopted in relation to this matter.
Yours sincerely
(Bob Collins)
Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee
Committee Recommendations and Major Conclusions and Government Response
RURAL ADJUSTMENT SCHEME (RAS)
Conclusion 1: Adequacy of the RAS

1.76 On the basis of the evidence presented to the inquiry, the Committee considers that in the short to medium term, several aspects of the Rural Adjustment Scheme must be improved and changed. The Committee is of the view that there is considerable confusion in the rural community about the focus and objectives of RAS 92. This confusion is so widespread that the Committee considers that, if accepted by the government, the recommendations in this report should be implemented as a revamped program with a new name. This program should focus on farm productivity, profitability and sustainability with a principal component being skills enhancement, professional advice and financial management, as well as the re-establishment grant. The Committee is of the view that exceptional circumstances should be removed from rural adjustment and made the subject of a separate Commonwealth-State agreement.
Government Response
Noted

The Government welcomes the Committee's support for the RAS 92 objectives and notes its concerns regarding confusion in the community about the focus and objectives of the Scheme. The Government has decided that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, in conjunction with State and Territory RAS authorities, will develop a communications strategy to address this problem for implementation during 1995-96.

The Government will further consider the name of the program and the mix of instruments for achieving its objectives during the evaluation of the Scheme scheduled for 1996. The Government considers that action prior to this time would be premature due to the recent introduction of the Scheme and the limited information, therefore, on its performance.
Conclusion 2: Guidelines

2.32 The Committee recognises that in relation to Commonwealth-State agreements a fine balance needs to be drawn between guidance or direction and the need for administrative flexibility in the delivery of programs arising from Commonwealth-State agreements. Nevertheless, the Committee considers that it is essential that the Commonwealth Government promote a more consistent and uniform approach to the implementation of rural adjustment measures. To achieve this objective, the Committee is of the view that guidelines should be more prescriptive to avoid ambiguities and anomalies in interpretation and results. This in tum will mean that potential recipients of RAS will have a clearer understanding of their eligibility for and entitlements to RAS programs.
Government Response
Noted—action already in train

Following comments from various interests, including from recipients of RAS support, and a recognition of inconsistencies in the treatment by States in their interpretation and application of the RAS guidelines, a review of the guidelines was initiated by the Commonwealth Government in July 1994. A Commonwealth and State working party to examine the consistent application and interpretation of the guidelines was established.
Consultations with the States on new guidelines are continuing.
Recommendation 1

2.33 The Committee welcomes advice from the department that it is preparing a manual of accounting and administrative procedures for use by the Commonwealth and States to ensure consistency but is disappointed that this manual was not prepared earlier. The Committee, however, is not convinced that this measure alone will solve inherent problems with the formulation and implementation of guidelines. Accordingly, the Committee recommends that, in some instances, guidelines should include a memorandum of understanding on the scope and application of the measures agreed to between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories. The Committee considers that the memorandum of understanding need not be a legalistic document but should contain clear definitions of purpose, scope or application of adjustment measures.
Government Response
Accept—action already in train

The specific need for a Memorandum of Understanding will be considered in the context of the current review of the policy guidelines. It is proposed that the manual of accounting and administrative arrangements will contain clear definitions of purpose, scope and application of adjustment measures.
Conclusion 3: Funding
2.44 The committee considers it essential that funding for RAS is appropriate to meet the aims and objectives of rural adjustment.
Government Response
Noted

Funding to meet the aims and objectives of the Scheme is considered on a four year program basis in the Budget context following consultation with the States. The Scheme is resourced on a funds limited basis with the exception of drought exceptional circumstances which is funded on a demand driven basis. Funding for any other exceptional circumstance will be considered according to the requirements of that exceptional circumstance.
Recommendation 2

2.45 The Committee recommends that when presenting RAS expenditure figures, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy draws a clear distinction between annual appropriations and reserves held by States.
Government Response
Noted—action already in train

When presenting RAS expenditure figures, a clear distinction is shown between expenditure sourced from the annual appropriations and expenditure drawn from reserves held by States and Territories. For example, this treatment is followed in the 1993-94 RASAC Annual Report.
Conclusion 4: Funding arrangements

2.56 The Committee welcomed recent enhancements to RAS in order to improve overall financial management, control and accountability. In particular, the Committee welcomes moves between the Commonwealth and the States to rationalise previous programs.
Government Response
Noted

Improved management controls over RAS has been a key priority for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy since at least the beginning of 1993. The Government will continue to monitor the overall performance of the program and, where necessary, introduce further changes to financial management, control and accountability arrangements.
Conclusion 5: Interest Subsidies
Recommendation 3
2.77 The Committee recommends that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy reassess whether interest rate subsidies are an effective instrument to facilitate rural adjustment
Government Response
Further Consideration

Review of the effectiveness and appropriateness of the Scheme's instruments, ie interest rate subsidies and grants, will be considered by the Government, including within the context of the major evaluation of the RAS, scheduled for 1996.
Conclusion 6: Skills Enhancement
Recommendation 4

2.89 The Committee is convinced that sound financial and management skills are the key to a robust, competitive, profitable and flexible farm sector. Accordingly the Committee recommends that, in the medium to long term, skills enhancement, including education, training and access to professional advice, should become the principal component of the Rural Adjustment Scheme.
Government Response
Further Consideration

The need for greater emphasis on assisting farmers to improve their technical, financial and risk management skills was identified as part of the new policy direction for the RAS announced in the context of the 1994 Budget. The Government accepts that there may be further opportunities to give effect to this objective. Indeed, legislative amendments to the Rural Adjustment Act 1992 to facilitate group training received the Royal Assent on 12 April 1995. The Committee's recommendation will be reviewed and further developed in consultation with stakeholders. Review of this issue will also take place in the context of the 1996 RAS evaluation.
Recommendation 5

2.90 The Committee also recommends that the Commonwealth and States develop procedures to ensure that recipients of RAS productivity and skills enhancement measures have sustainable business and farm plans.
Government Response
Accept—action already in train

The role of farm business plans is being examined in the context of the current review of the RAS policy guidelines (see Government response to Conclusion 2). The Prime Minister's Land Management Task Force is also considering options for the wider adoption of Property Management Planning, which incorporates financial and natural resource management.
Conclusion 7: Amount of the re-establishment grant
Recommendation 6

2.99 The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth government consider increasing the level of re-establishment grant or alternatively, modifying the current assets threshold so that farming families may exit with more assets.
Government Response
Further consideration

The issue is being examined in the context of the current review of the RAS guidelines (See Government response to Conclusion 2). Provision for enhanced re-establishment support is an element of the South West Queensland regional strategy and the drought support package announced on 21 September 1994.
Conclusion 8: Re-establishment grant and JSA

2.102 The Committee considers that regulations stipulating that a farmer or spouse who remains on JSA for longer that 9 months is excluded form the $45000 re-establishment grant cannot be justified on the ground of basic rights to access government programs.
Accordingly, the link between eligibility for the re-establishment grant and job search allowance should be abolished
Government Response
Noted

Abolition of the link between eligibility for a re-establishment grant and for Job Search Allowance was announced by the Prime Minister on 8 December 1994 and implemented in the revised policy guideline applying to re-establishment support issued on 16 December 1994.
Conclusion 9: Re-establishment grant and orderly exit
Recommendation 7
2.106 The Committee recommends that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy reviews the need to include orderly exit requirements in the re-establishment guidelines.
Government Response
Accept
Orderly exit requirements are being considered in the context of the current review of the RAS policy guidelines (see Government response to Conclusion 2).
Conclusion 10: Re-establishment grant and re-training
Recommendation 8

2.109 The Committee found the evidence on retraining and re-establishment persuasive. The Committee therefore recommends that the Commonwealth government includes a specific retraining component in re-establishment grants.
Government Response
Accept—action already in train

Provision for this was made in the SW Queensland regional pilot program. Immediate access to DEET labour market programs has also been made available to exiting farmers under the regional RAS and drought exceptional circumstances provisions. A specific re-training component in normal re-establishment grants is being considered in the context of the current review of the RAS policy guidelines (see Government response to Conclusion 2).
Conclusion 11: Exceptional circumstances

2.131 The Committee considers that the Commonwealth government has a responsibility to provide additional assistance in times of exceptional circumstances, as it is in the national interest to protect and maintain Australia's agricultural base and productivity capacity, including the breeding stock.
Government Response
Noted

The Government currently provides additional farm business support under the exceptional circumstances provisions of the RAS. For example, in the context of the current exceptional circumstances drought in parts of Australia, almost 4600 farm businesses had received (up to the end of June 1995) farm business support through the drought exceptional circumstances provisions of the RAS, at a total cost of more than $65.0 million.
2.132 The Committee considers that the Commonwealth government should define exceptional circumstances.
Government Response
Noted

Exceptional circumstances support is already defined as support to farm businesses viable in the long term but facing short term difficulties due to events which could not reasonably be expected to be incorporated into normal risk management strategies.

The Government is prepared to consider submissions for exceptional circumstances support on a case by case basis. It would be difficult to provide precise definitions of all possible exceptional circumstances events, although in the case of exceptional circumstances drought, the Commonwealth and State Governments, through the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand (ARMCANZ), have recognised the importance of developing a more precise definition of exceptional drought. ARMCANZ Ministers have agreed on a process for considering drought exceptional circumstances based on six core criteria: meteorological conditions, agronomic and stock conditions, water supplies, environmental impacts, farm income levels and scale of the event. Work is continuing through the On-Farm Risk Management Working Group of the Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management to further develop a framework which includes drought criteria, indicators, attributes and benchmarks.

The Commonwealth's approach to drought exceptional circumstances support for farm businesses is based on the National Drought Policy and its principles of sustainable development, effective risk management, productivity growth and structural adjustment in the farm sector.
Recommendation 9
2.134 The Committee recommends that exceptional circumstances provisions should be removed from the Rural Adjustment Scheme and included in a separate Commonwealth-State agreement.
Government Response
Further Consideration
Review of this issue will take place in the context of the RAS evaluation during 1996, and also in the drought review announced.
Conclusion 12: Exceptional circumstances—funding

2.138 The Committee notes significant improvements to the funding of exceptional circumstances. In particular, the Committee welcomes the provision of sufficient resources so that all farm enterprises eligible for exceptional circumstances for the drought in Queensland and New South Wales will be fully funded. The Committee supports the move to `demand driven' exceptional circumstances.
Government Response
Noted
The demand driven nature of drought exceptional circumstances funding was introduced as part of the 21 September 1994 drought package announced by the Prime Minister.
Conclusion 13: Exceptional circumstances—guidelines

2.143 The Committee reiterates its view that the Commonwealth government must promote a more consistent and uniform approach to rural adjustment and that guidelines should be more prescriptive. This conclusion is particularly relevant to guidelines for exceptional circumstances as it is essential that potential recipients who are experiencing hardship, have a clear understanding of access to and eligibility for assistance.
Government Response
Noted—action already in train
These issues will be examined in the context of the current review of the RAS policy guidelines (see Government response to Conclusion 2).
Recommendation 10

2.144 The Committee recommends that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy re-examine recommendations to improve exceptional circumstances guidelines proposed by the National Farmers Federation and the Grains Council of Australia.
Government Response
Further Consideration

The revision of exceptional circumstances guidelines, issued on 16 December 1994 and 28 June 1995, were developed in consultation with the States and industry. The NFF and the Grains Council of Australia recommendations received on 1 November 1994 are being further considered in the context of revision of RAS guidelines (see Government response to Conclusion 2).
Conclusion 14: Exceptional circumstances—definition—drought

2.149 The Committee reiterates the view it expressed in its 1992 report entitled A National Drought Policy that the Commonwealth's role in relation to severe drought must be consistent and clearly enunciated. Therefore, the Committee considers it imperative that the Commonwealth government develop a definition of severe drought and that the proposal from the Cattle Council of Australia provides a useful framework for this definition. The Cattle Council proposed that the trigger mechanism to activate Commonwealth involvement and assistance should incorporate:
(a)an application for extreme drought status, presumably emanating from the shire concerned,

(b)use of an objective measure of extreme drought calling on satellite technology, sophisticated mapping techniques and ground checks, which could include soil moisture readings, rainfall records, etc, and
(c)an overriding subjective assessment by a tripartite drought committee or structure involving the Commonwealth, States and producers and drawing upon local knowledge and expertise.
Government Response
Noted
See Government response to Conclusion 11-2.132.
Conclusion 15: Exceptional Circumstances-drought relief payments

2.162 The Committee considers that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the Department of Social Security must monitor the effectiveness of the drought relief package to ensure that funds are properly targeted and is providing effective assistance. This will enable the Commonwealth government to respond promptly and effectively if conditions worsen.
Government Response
Noted—action already in train

RAS exceptional circumstances support and rural counselling positions, the drought relief payment and Austudy are being monitored by the Departments of Primary Industry and Energy, Social Security and Employment, Education and Training respectively. A Post Implementation Review of the drought relief payment by the Department of Social Security is currently scheduled to commence in October 1995. The review forms part of the Department's ongoing review process. Other elements of the drought relief package canvassed in the Report (eg investment allowance for farm storage and water facilities) were introduced in March 1995. The effectiveness of assistance provided by the overall package will be evaluated after termination of the drought exceptional circumstances event. In the meantime monitoring of performance is being conducted by means of State reports in an agreed standard format and through State input of data on exceptional circumstances applications and funding to the MIS.
The Department of Employment, Education and Training will also monitor the effectiveness of labour market programs used by farmers in drought exceptional circumstances areas.
Conclusion 16: Farm household support
Recommendation 11

2.168 The Committee received consistent evidence that the farm household support program is "a total failure" because of ill-defined guidelines, inadequate training for DSS staff and poor communication. The Committee agrees and recommends that this program should be significantly overhauled. The Committee understands that more appropriate and effective assistance will be available when income support measures announced in the White Paper on Employment and Growth are introduced.
Government Response
Further consideration

Comprehensive operating guidelines for the Farm Household Support Scheme were issued to Department of Social Security staff before implementation of the program. These guidelines are maintained as part of the Department's overall administrative guidelines. A training package was developed and delivered in regional offices. A National Help Desk was established and has been in operation for the entire duration of the scheme. The low take up rate of the Scheme may account for the lack of experience of some staff in dealing with claims for Farm Household Support, in that the numbers on the scheme are small and spread nationally. Therefore, officers would have few dealings with farmers claiming Farm Household Support at a given time. Information packages were produced and widely distributed several weeks prior to implementation of the Scheme. Information leaflets have been available since implementation of the program and are widely available through a number of sources, including all Social Security regional offices.

While the White Paper on Employment and Growth changes were not specifically directed to farmers and entitlements to payments will depend on individual circumstances, the introduction of Parenting Allowance may benefit some farm families. Parenting Allowance will be payable to the partners of low income earners with children and may therefore be payable to the partners of some farmers. Parenting Allowance will not be activity tested but will be subject to the JSA/NSA income and assets tests.
It is proposed that a review of the Farm Household Support scheme be held in 1995-96.
Conclusion 17: Commonwealth administration performance indicators
Recommendation 12

2.176 The Committee considers it is imperative that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy develop performance indicators for the Rural Adjustment Scheme and recommends that this matter be addressed urgently.
Government Response
Noted

A RASAC working party completed a set of broad performance indicators for the RAS in December 1993. Subsequently, a Commonwealth/State RAS Officers Group Management Information System (MIS) working party examined arrange of performance indicators based on RASAC's report. The Commonwealth and the States have now agreed that the MIS is to incorporate performance indicators based on these reports. The new arrangements are expected to be operational in the second half of 1995.

The effectiveness of the Scheme is also monitored through ABARE agricultural surveys. The surveys provide information on the performance of farms receiving RAS assistance and enable comparison of RAS and non-RAS farm performance.
Conclusion 18: Commonwealth administration—management information system

2.189 The Committee considers that effective program management demands an ability to monitor performance. The failure of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to develop a Management Information System is a serious deficiency in the administration of RAS that must be addressed immediately.
Government Response
Noted

The Commonwealth has been working jointly with the States to develop a MIS. A working MIS and automatic data transmittal system has been developed and is now in place. Work is continuing on data accuracy verification and reporting systems which will enable data to be produced from the MIS in 1995 to assist in monitoring the performance of RAS.
Recommendation 13
2.190 The Committee recommends that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy accord the highest priority to the development of a fully operational management information system.
Government Response
Noted

The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has dedicated resources to make the MIS fully operational in 1995 and action has been initiated in RAS Management Branch to overcome existing data accuracy, consistency and reporting difficulties.
Recommendation 14

2.191 The Committee is also of the view that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy must gain a better appreciation of, and monitor more closely, the effectiveness of programs at the grassroots level. The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth government ensures that the department has sufficient personnel and financial resources to undertake proper monitoring and evaluation of rural adjustment programs.
Government Response
Noted

Additional resources have been allocated to the administration of the Scheme since September 1994 including additional staff devoting part of their duties to assist in the development of the MIS. The use of ABARE agricultural surveys as a vehicle for assessing effectiveness of the program is also important in this regard. More definitive assessments of the Scheme will be possible in future years as further data on the impact of RAS `92 becomes available. The adequacy of resources will be an element of the 1996 evaluation.
Conclusion 19: Regional approach to RAS
Recommendation 15
2.210 The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth government provide new funding for integrated regional adjustment and recovery programs, but not at the expense of "normal" RAS funding.
Government Response
Accept—already in place
The RAS reserve was established in the 1994-95 Budget context to provide

PARA.TAB: funding for RAS regional initiatives
a basis for smoothing between year (and between State) variations in demand for assistance and/or fund specific productivity improvement measures.

SPEECH.PARA: Funding for the RAS reserve is not established through a lower level of normal RAS activity than would otherwise be the case.

The first of these integrated regional adjustment and recovery programs is the South West Queensland Regional Strategy. This program integrates the RAS, Landcare programs, Department of Social Security work programs and an agribusiness kangaroo management program.

Since the South West Queensland program was initiated, offers have been made to the New South Wales government for Commonwealth regional RAS initiatives in the western Division and in the central west of New South Wales.
In addition, $10m was provided in the 8 December drought relief package for regional RAS.
Recommendation 16
2.210 The Committee also recommends that underspends arising from the annual allocation to normal RAS should also be directed to these programs.
Government Response
Accept—already in place
This recommendation is already current policy.
Recommendation 17
2.211 The Committee further recommends that the Commonwealth government should not impose levies on the States and territories for the purposes of funding regional adjustment and recovery programs.
Government Response
Noted

The Commonwealth regards mandatory levies as inappropriate for this purpose. However, the Commonwealth and the States have agreed to earmark, where appropriate, part of a State's normal RAS allocations to support specific regional programs. This has been done in the case of the South West Queensland regional adjustment strategy.
Conclusion 20: Fisheries
Recommendation 18

2.217 The Committee recommends that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, in consultation with State and Territory governments and the industry, re-examine whether it is appropriate to include fishing within the scope of rural adjustment.
Government Response
Further consideration
The Government is examining whether there is a case for referring this matter to RASAC for advice.
Conclusion 21: Young farmers
Recommendation 19

2.221 The Committee recommends that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy examine whether it is appropriate for rural adjustment programs and, in particular, the skills enhancement component, to include measures that will encourage young farmers.
Government Response
Accept

Recognising that young farmers will play a critical role in improving productivity, sustainability and international competitiveness in the future, the Government will examine the scope to build on current efforts to enhance the skills of young farmers through relevant components of the RAS.
Conclusion 22: Integration of RAS with other programs

2.225 The Committee endorses evidence presented during the inquiry that an holistic approach must be adopted when addressing rural adjustment. The Committee considers that the synergy between RAS and other programs, such as Landcare, is increasing and that this must be reflected in government programs.
Government Response
Accept—action already in train

Better linkages of Commonwealth and State programs will be possible in the context of regional RAS. The SW Queensland initiative integrates Landcare, Agribusiness and RAS elements as well as linking RAS assistance to other Commonwealth and State farm improvement programs. Better linking of programs, including labour market programs, will permit an integrated, comprehensive approach to improving productivity, sustainability and competitiveness of Australian agriculture, including an upgrading of the technical, financial and risk management skills of farmers.
Conclusion 23: State administration—promotion and delivery of RAS programs

2.236 During the inquiry it became apparent to the Committee that detailed information, on the Rural Adjustment Scheme, guidelines and assessment criteria have not been widely disseminated or are not well understood. In particular, Commonwealth and State governments have not made clear to rural communities the change in focus from carry-on assistance provided by RAS 88 to adjustment measures contained in RAS 92.
Government Response
Accept

A RAS communication strategy is to be developed by the Commonwealth and the States to further emphasise the change in focus between RAS 88 and RAS 92 for implementation during 1995-96. The Commonwealth proposes to develop fact sheets to replace State information sheets.
2.237 This confusion is so widespread, the Committee considers that the Commonwealth and the States must, as a matter of priority, improve the promotion and delivery of rural adjustment programs.
Government Response
Accept
See Government response to Conclusion 23-2.236.
Conclusion 24: State administration—access to information
Recommendation 20

2.240 The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth government ensures that procedural guidelines and policies used by State and Territory RAS authorities to assess eligibility for assistance be made available to the public.
Government Response
Accept

The Commonwealth supports ready access by clients to this information. States are encouraged to make all information pertaining to RAS farm business support freely available. The Commonwealth proposes to develop fact sheets to replace State information sheets which will seek to explain procedures, policies and guidelines in "plain English" and to publicise the names and numbers of contact officers for further information.
Conclusion 25: State administration—conflict of interests

2.247 Given concerns expressed on this matter during the inquiry, the committee welcomes advice from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy that RAS administration in the States and Territories will be separated from commercial lending activities. This will allay concerns and perceptions about conflicts of interest between these functions and activities.
Government Response
Accept—action already in train

Separation of RAS administration from commercial lending activities is being achieved in most States. Ongoing monitoring of the situation is continuing, and, where necessary, further action will be considered.
Conclusion 26: State administration—competence and integrity

2.254 The Committee is not in a position to assess whether accusations concerning the competence and integrity of some State RAS authorities are well founded. Nevertheless, the Committee is concerned that this evidence may reflect the low regard in which some RAS authorities are held by some people. The Committee considers that State RAS authorities should promote a positive perception of their role in the rural community.
Government Response
Accept

The Commonwealth is prepared to fund promotion of the RAS, including the role of the State RAS authorities in the effective delivery of assistance. The issues will be taken up with State RAS authorities.
Conclusion 27: Appeal mechanisms
Recommendation 21

2.258 The Committee notes concerns that some States do not have properly structured appeal mechanisms for unsuccessful RAS applicants. The Committee also notes assurances from State and Territory authorities that proper and independent avenues of appeal are available. The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth government ensures that properly structured, independent avenues of appeal are available.
Government Response
Accept
The Commonwealth supports effective review processes. The question of appeal mechanisms is being taken up in the context of the review of RAS guidelines (see Government response to Conclusion 2).
Recommendation 22
2.258 The Committee also recommends that the Commonwealth, in consultation with the States and Territories, develop standard practices and procedures for appeals.
Government Response
Accept
See Government response to Recommendation 21.
Conclusion 28: Farm inspections
2.264 The Committee considers that on farm inspections are preferable when RAS authorities are assessing applications, notwithstanding costs associated with this practice.
Government Response
Noted
Farm inspections are to be encouraged where appropriate and necessary for effective assessment purposes and will be included in the RAS manual.

The Commonwealth considers farm inspections to be worthwhile in principle but in certain cases the costs may outweigh potential benefits. Several States already include farm inspections in the assessment process for RAS clientele.
RURAL DEBT AND ITS CONSEQUENCES
Conclusion 29: Rural debt

3.36 The Committee considers that, although rural debt is estimated to be $17 billion, this debt is a symptom rather than the cause of more fundamental and deep seated problems in rural Australia. The Committee believes that responses and solutions should be directed to the source of these problems rather that their repercussions.
Government Response
Reject

The Government does not accept that the extent of adjustment problems in rural Australia can be described simply in terms of aggregate rural debt. While the level of debt may, in part, reflect the severity of international commodity trading conditions, seasonal conditions and other factors external to the individual farm business, it also is a vehicle used positively by farmers to manage risk, exploit commercial opportunities and raise the level of productivity with a view to higher future levels of profitability. Against this background, farm debt should not necessarily be seen as an undesirable feature of the farmer's financial position.

The Government acknowledges the accumulation of debt by some farmers due to circumstances, such as exceptional drought, that are outside their capacity for risk management. The Government is prepared to assist farm businesses in such situations through interest rate subsidies.

The Government is also aware of the importance of a commercial environment which facilitates international competitiveness, risk management and sustainable resource use. A comprehensive range of policies are in place to help farmers achieve these objectives.
RURAL RECONSTRUCTION
Conclusion 29: Rural counselling program

4.12 During the inquiry the committee met with many rural counsellors throughout Australia. The Committee was impressed with their dedication and commitment to the rural communities in which they provided invaluable service. The Committee registers its strong support for the rural counselling program.
Government Response
Noted

The Government has recognised the need to support the rural community through the Rural Counselling Program since 1986, particularly those who are experiencing financial difficulties. It has expanded the provision of the counselling services to meet emerging needs across rural Australia. There are some 81 rural counselling positions throughout Australia with a further 12 new counsellors being established in drought affected areas. Rural counselling services play a vital role in rural industry adjustment.
Conclusion 31: Role of Government—income equalisation deposits scheme

4.25 The most consistent evidence the Committee received during the inquiry was that the Income Equalisation Deposit scheme is not attractive to farmers and needs to be changed significantly. The Committee reiterates the recommendation it made in its report on A National Drought Policy in 1992 that the Commonwealth Government must introduce an effective IED scheme.
Government Response
Noted—action already taken

An enhanced Farm Management Bond (FMB) was announced on 8 December 1994 as part of the Government's long term response to the drought. The FMB is an integral component of the Government's Income Equalisation Deposits (IED)/FMB Scheme. The new FMB increases the investment allowance to 100% of the deposit, removes the 20% withholding tax on withdrawals and increases the maximum deposit limit from $80,000 to $150,000 per taxpayer.
Recommendation 23

4.26 The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth government give detailed consideration to changes to the scheme proposed by ABARE, the New South Wales Farmers Association and the review sponsored by New South Wales Agriculture.
Government Response
Noted
See Government response to Conclusion 31.
Recommendation 24
4.27 The Committee further recommends that the Commonwealth Government authorise major financial institutions to receive and hold IEDs on deposit.
Government Response
Not accepted

The responsibility for administration of IEDs/FMBs is to remain with the Government. The Government will initiate a communication strategy outlining the benefits of IEDs and FMBs and their inclusion in risk management strategies following passage of the necessary legislative amendments to give effect to the changes to FMBs announced by the Government in December 1994.
Conclusion 32: Role of Government—taxation
Recommendation 25

4.35 The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government review income tax provisions that influence risk management strategies such as income averaging, provisional tax and tax loss provisions. In particular, this review should examine carry back of losses proposed by the Victorian government and carry forward of tax credits proposed by the NFF.
Government Response
Noted—action already in train

The Government is aware of proposed alternatives to the current income averaging scheme. The Treasury and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy will jointly review the current scheme and alternative options in 1995. A considerable body of research work relevant to the Review has been completed already by the Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management. The Government is not currently considering any changes to provisional tax arrangements or tax loss provisions affecting primary producers.
Recommendation 26

4.36 The Committee also recommends that the Commonwealth government examine whether the capital gains tax should be imposed when farmers dispose of off-farm assets in response to exceptional circumstances.
Government Response
Not accepted
The Government sees no need to review this policy at this time.
Conclusion 33: Role of the financial sector
Recommendation 27

4.58 The Committee is aware that in some cases a financial impasse between farmers and creditors develops which may require negotiation and mediation. The Committee strongly supports the concept of farm mediation and recommends that the Commonwealth government, in consultation with the States and financial institutions, examine the feasibility of establishing a farm debt mediation service and if so under what circumstances and conditions banks and their clients should be required to use it.
Government Response
Not accepted

The Government's Rural Counselling Program provides support to farmers and their families in their discussions with financial institutions. The Government is aware of the New South Wales Government's recent farm debt mediation initiative and will monitor the impact of this program. The Government is also aware that the National Farmers' Federation and the Australian Bankers Association jointly manage `Farm Assessment Scheme', which includes a mediation process, together with the provision of advice on farm management.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —This response from the government, which has come along at long last—I believe it has taken longer than it should have—follows a period of rapid and painful change that has permeated every facet of life in the bush. In response to many representations from organisations and individuals in rural Australia, I moved and this Senate agreed in March 1994 to initiate an inquiry into the adequacy of the rural adjustment scheme.

PARA.TAB: That decision was made on 24 March 1994. The committee tabled this report in December 1994. Over a period of eight months, the committee—and I must recognise the significant contribution of the former chairman, Senator Burns—embarked on an exhaustive inquiry in order to present itself with the evidence and facts on which credible conclusions and recommendations could be made.

The committee received something like 290 submissions. We held something like 17 public hearings throughout the country and took evidence from 262 witnesses. As I indicated earlier, the committee report tabled in December 1994 makes 27 recommendations and draws 33 major conclusions. Given that the government has taken nine months to respond to this report, I anticipated that what we would have in front of us today would be a detailed response to the report, providing a blueprint for rural Australia to readjust and revitalise. Obviously, the government or the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) has run out of ideas of trying to fix up the problems of readjusting and revitalising rural Australia.

As chairman of the committee, I note the minister congratulates the committee on its thorough approach. I welcome that statement. I also welcome the statement that the government supports the thrust of the committee's report. However, when we go into detail in this document we find that for nine months the government has been sitting on its hands and that many of the fundamental and vital issues raised in the committee's report have been put into the too hard basket.

The minister's response indicates that a number of the committee's recommendations have already been implemented or are under active consideration. One would have thought that after nine months active consideration he would have given way to a much more positive policy implementation.

Some of the things put to us at the inquiry were absolutely horrific. There were people from the Darling Downs in Queensland who had missed out on four years of cropping, which is eight crops for them. They have now missed out on another crop. They have had problems with mice, drought, frost and the problem of a government that has given lip service—the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) went up there and had a look around—but has not got to the guts and the gist of what needs to be done.

There is no doubt that members of the committee would welcome the enhanced farm management bond scheme. We do. We welcome the removal of the link between re-establishment grants and the jobsearch allowance, and the new funding approach to regional adjustment. Yet it must be realised that these were the easy issues.

A reading of any transcript of evidence from the committee's inquiry indicates that these responses were necessary and obvious. But what about the hard issues? What about the hard things that go to the core of what rural adjustment is all about: the opportunity for people to get out of agriculture or into agriculture; the capital gains tax and the problems that creates for people in rural communities and the problems with rural adjustment? In his response, the minister says:

SPEECH.PARA: The issues surrounding re-establishment, training, exceptional circumstances support, farm business plans, orderly exit, young farmers and appeals mechanisms raised in the report have been under active consideration. A revised set of RAS guidelines are scheduled to be completed soon.

The committee said that it was convinced that sound financial and management skills were the key to a robust, flexible and profitable farm sector and recommended medium- to long-term skills enhancement, the other things I have just mentioned, and especially education, training and access to professional advice as very important.

PARA.TAB: Another report of ours—the Austudy assets test report which I will be talking about in a moment—exemplified how necessary it is for farmers to have access to education and to have training so that they can continue as farmers, so their sons can come back on to the farm, or so they can adjust off the farm. There was a negative response to that report too, but I will talk about that in a minute.

The minister's response rightly recognised the committee's report and identified several major policy issues. They include: whether interest rate subsidies are an effective instrument to facilitate structural adjustment; whether the principal mechanism to deliver outcomes should be skills enhancement rather than productivity enhancement; and, most importantly, whether exceptional circumstances should be removed from RAS and included in a separate Commonwealth-state agreement.

You only have to go to the central west of New South Wales and talk to the people who live between Mudgee and Bathurst, or go to the Hunter Valley and talk to the people who live there to understand the problem people have getting recognition of the fact that they are in exceptional circumstances. I have spoken quite often in this place about the problem with RASAC.

RASAC was instituted for adjustment purposes. It advised the minister whether exceptional circumstances—from long and severe drought or substantial commodity price falls—existed in the rural sector, and whether changes should be made to the funding arrangements for RAS as a result. As I have said in this place before, I do not believe that RASAC has been doing as good a job as it should.

We wrestled for nine months with the major issues and recorded our unanimous views. For nine months the minister has had the benefit of those views. It is not often you get a report where all members agree that something has to be done. Yet the government has sat on its hands for nine months and we are still waiting for changes to be made.

Given the parlous state of rural Australia, will this review be conducted, as the minister tells us, in the next month or two or by the end of the year? The response from the minister tells us that it will be part of an evaluation to commence early next year and to be completed by 31 December 1996.

I would say to the minister, and I am quite sure he will read the message I am trying to get to him on this one, that I do not know whether by the end of 1996 there are going to be that many farmers in a position to be readjusted because of the parlous state of different areas of Australia at the moment—in particular, some of those areas that I have mentioned in the Hunter Valley, the Darling Downs in Queensland, and in that area between Mudgee and Bathurst, that fine wool-growing area.

So I basically say, Minister—and I do have some respect at times for Senator Collins, but in this particular case I believe that he has to move his department a lot quicker than he has been doing and he has to move his own legs a lot quicker than he has been moving them—that I am disappointed in your response. I am disappointed that a unanimous report by a Senate committee did not provide a platform from which you could project a blueprint to revitalise rural Australia. Rural Australia cannot wait until 1997 for a coordinated, consistent and effective policy to be put in place.

I trust that the election comes on quickly so that the Liberal and National parties, as a government, can actually take on board the suggestions that have been put in this document that has now been replied to by the government—the Rural adjustment, rural debt and rural reconstruction report by the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee—because basically it is a blueprint to help any minister get things right. So I say to this minister: try to get it right as quickly as you can. If you do not, we will do it in government. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee entitled Impact of assets tests on farming families' access to social security and Austudy—first report: Austudy assets test. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO SENATE RURAL AND REGIONAL AFFAIRS AND TRANSPORT REFERENCES COMMITTEE INQUIRY INTO THE IMPACT OF ASSETS TESTS ON FARMING FAMILIES' ACCESS TO SOCIAL SECURITY AND AUSTUDY

The issue of assets tests' impact on farming families' access to Social Security benefits and to AUSTUDY was referred to the committee on 30 June 1994 and 24 August 1994 respectively. On 31 August 1994, these references were combined. The committee's First Report deals with AUSTUDY.

The Inquiry was conducted through late 1994 and early 1995 at the worst point of the drought. Submissions were invited before the announcement of the Government's Drought Relief Package on 24 September 1994 and the Package came into effect just before the committee's main public hearings in October and November 1994.

The committee concludes that ". . . the assets test applied to farming families in order to determine eligibility for AUSTUDY is an inappropriate policy instrument that does not take into account the nature of farm assets and their relationship with income. In essence, the current assets test does not acknowledge that some farmers are assets rich but income poor and that farm assets cannot readily be liquidated without diminishing the viability of the farming unit. . . ". Four key considerations are cited. These are: evidence from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy that an estimated 5400 students from farm families are excluded by the assets test; the low retention and participation rates of rural students; evidence and submissions to the Inquiry about how access to AUSTUDY impacts on children's education; and the national interest of facilitating a well educated rural sector.
The majority conclusions are misplaced.
There are important features of, and concessions in, the assets test to take account of compassionate individual circumstances. These include:

assets are taken into account at net current market value. If the market value of farm assets declines this is reflected in the amount of assets for the assets test. If debt increases, the net value of the assets decreases commensurately;

the 50% discount on farm/business assets. The discount differentiates between assets used by a person for his or her livelihood and those held chiefly for investment or wealth generation. AUSTUDY is intended to overcome financial barriers to education, not to subsidise families' investment choices. The discount reflects the intention that families should not be forced to sell their livelihood to support children in education;
the availability of reassessment of eligibility at any time when assets values diminish because of drought, economic downturn or debt burdens;
on this basis, current rules exclude only those farmers who, in the middle of the current crisis, have $750,000 or more of debt-free assets;
making provision for disregarding the value of curtilage;
waiver of the assets test where the families' need has clearly been established; that is, when a parent is getting a Commonwealth income support payment;

concessions for specific circumstances of need. The Government's Drought Relief Package introduced 1 October 1994 gives families in "exceptional circumstances drought affected areas" exemption from the assets test if they get Drought Relief Payment Scheme (DRPS) benefits, or a 100% disregard of on-farm assets if they are not eligible or choose not to apply for DRPS;
the Drought Relief Concessions were only newly introduced at the time of the committee's investigations.
The grounds cited by the majority of the committee do not justify the blanket disregard of on-farm assets.

While it is accepted that farming often is a capital intensive business, evidence as to farm asset values from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE) and the ABARE Australian Agriculture and Grazing Industries Survey (AAGIS) (pg 39 et seq) does not establish that the current test ceiling is below the level at which farms are viable. The assets test does not exclude farmers per se, only wealthier ones.

The committee's findings that around 5,400 students from farming families are excluded from AUSTUDY by the assets test does not of itself justify changes to the test. These exclusions are consistent with the intent of the test and the objectives of the program.

The argument that farm assets must be held intact is likewise unproven. Many families who fail the asset test because they have assets worth more than $375,000 (non-farm) or $750,000 (farm assets), net of debt, may not need to sell up assets at all, but rather to borrow against this equity. Where this is not possible, the family's assets are not limited to relatively `indivisible' land-holdings, improvements and fixtures, but will normally include many stand-alone assets (non-essential equipment or stock, or investment or personal assets) that could be cashed up without ruining the farm, if the family so chose. This may involve sacrifice. However, it is no more harsh than requiring a non-farm family to reduce its wealth, or forgo future financial gains, to self-provide for children's education.

The committee also claims that, means-testing issues aside, there are compelling reasons to direct additional education assistance to farming families to overcome low retention and participation rates among rural students and ensure a more educated rural/farming population.
This is the intention of providing student assistance.

However, it remains conjectural whether access to AUSTUDY alone will achieve these objectives, or that the problem lies specifically with those families excluded from AUSTUDY on assets grounds. The committee itself recognises that "there may be various reasons for this, not the least being distance" (Conclusions, pg xi).

The committee has not tested the underlying reasons for the claimed decline in rural education. These are likely to include issues of distance and the perceived value and relevance of education to the industry.

Notwithstanding the Government's recognition of the special circumstances of farmers and the premium to be placed on education, the practical effects of relaxing the AUSTUDY assets test would be limited. The winners from the exemption of on-farm assets would be more wealthy families, including those with significant (up to $375,000) off-farm assets.

PARA.EMPHASIS: RECOMMENDATIONS PRESENTED AND THE GOVERNMENT RESPONSE
farm assets be excluded from the AUSTUDY assets test;

SPEECH.PARA: the current discount of 50 per cent be increased substantially; and
the AUSTUDY Supplement include a category of dependent students who meet all other AUSTUDY eligibility requirements, except the assets test.

A Dissenting Report has been made (following pg 23). Dissenting Senators Burns, Forshaw, Murphy and West consider "the original reasons for the introduction of the AUSTUDY assets test are valid and, therefore, disagree with the committee's recommendation that farm assets be excluded from the AUSTUDY assets test." However, there is qualified support for the second recommendation of the main report, viz:

PARA.EMPHASIS: the level of discount allowed on farm assets for the AUSTUDY assets test should be

SPEECH.PARA: re-examined.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (a)That farm assets be excluded from the AUSTUDY assets test.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Not supported.
The AUSTUDY assets test reflects the Government's intention that families with access to financial resources in the form of assets will normally draw on these before calling on AUSTUDY.
The assets test takes into account the special circumstances of farming families in a number of important ways. Asset values are calculated based on current market conditions and net of debts.

A 50% discount applies to assets used in the conduct of the family farm (or business). This means that families can have up to $751,260 worth of farm assets net of debt before AUSTUDY ceases. To expect such families to self-provide for children's education is not unreasonable compared with those wage and salary and pensioner families at whom AUSTUDY is targeted (cutting out at joint parental incomes of around $32,000 pa, that is, parental per capita earnings of less than average weekly earnings.

In recognition of the special circumstances of drought-affected farmers, on 24 September 1994 the Prime Minister announced further concessions under the Drought Relief Package. Families in "exceptional circumstances drought affected areas" are exempt from AUSTUDY assets (and income) tests, while they are getting assistance under the Drought Relief Payment Scheme (DRPS), or can get an exemption (100% discount) for the value of on-farm assets, if they are not eligible or choose not to apply for the DRPS.
Additionally, families can seek confidential valuations which fully take into account any downturn in economic conditions, for AUSTUDY purposes.

In these ways, the Government has acted to address the needs of farming families. The Government remains committed to the principle of assets testing of AUSTUDY benefits; AUSTUDY should continue to take into account families' full financial resources, including resources held in the form of assets.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (b)That the current discount of 50 per cent be increased substantially.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Not supported.

The Dissenting Report lends qualified support to this recommendation, suggesting the discount be "re-examined". However, neither the majority nor the dissenting Members offer a recommendation as to what discount should be allowed.

Even a comparatively modest increase in the discount (to say, assess on-farm assets at 33%), would take this over the one million dollars mark. DPIE evidence to the committee suggests an average net assets value for disqualified broadacre and dairy farms of around $1.4m.

Notwithstanding arguments about the special nature of farm assets, major difficulties would arise in being seen to continue to pursue tighter targeting of AUSTUDY to those in greatest need, while allowing some families with assets of over a million dollars to get assistance.

PARA.EMPHASIS: (c)That the AUSTUDY Supplement be extended to include a category of dependent students who meet all other AUSTUDY eligibility requirements, except the assets test.

SPEECH.PARA: Response: Not supported.

The Government notes that comprehensive concessions exist to ensure that the AUSTUDY assets test does not unfairly penalise families in genuine need. The Government does not propose to introduce supplement loans for families with assets outside allowable limits. This is consistent with the Government's decision, announced in the 1995 Budget, to abolish Category 2 Supplement loans to students whose parental incomes are over AUSTUDY cut off but less than $50,850.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I happen to also be the chairman of this inquiry on the impact of assets tests on farming families' access to social security payments and Austudy. This one was not a unanimous report, but the majority report, which came from those of us on this side of the chamber, basically set the formula right from the evidence that we received.

PARA.TAB: Again, I am disappointed with the government's response, but I am hardly surprised that the government has taken the line it has in response to this committee report entitled Impact of assets tests on farming families' access to social security and Austudy. Given that the Labor Party senators on the committee put in a dissenting report, I believe that has to be expected. Basically, if you listened to the evidence and if you listened to what people were telling us, the other members of the committee would have realised that we were actually putting to the Senate the problems associated with the people getting access to education in country areas.

What is really disappointing, I believe, is the government's lack of understanding in its reasoning for rejecting the committee's findings. The majority report, in my view, quite accurately reflects the overwhelming evidence and must be the basis of any committee consideration. I would argue that the inflexibility in practice of the assets test militates quite strongly against farm families and their access to rural education, and the figures demonstrably show that.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins) suggests in his reply that, if a farmer has assets of over $750,000-odd, obviously he can afford to send his children away for tertiary education. That implies that, if things get a little tight, they can chop an acre or so off the back paddock and realise some assets. I would have to say that this is probably the only disagreement I think I have had with Senator Burns on our committee. He just cannot quite get the grasp of selling off an acre from the back of the farm, but I am quite sure he will say something in a minute or two about this particular matter. We have to remember that with farm families it is not only a case of tertiary education fees, but also a need for accommodation and board. So it is not a case of them just getting one thing.

Given the government's totally misplaced understanding of the rural sector, I am not surprised that it has rejected the exemption from the assets test, but I cannot accept in any manner the claim that the current 50 per cent discount should not be increased. Again, there is this misplaced thinking that, if farm assets are worth X dollars, the children should be penalised and the parents are obviously able to afford the education. Of course, the government says to these families that they have curtilage—maybe two hectares and a house—which is not part of the assets test. But people who live in the city and get less than $20,000-odd in income can get Austudy. It does not matter what their house is worth because that is their home.

In a time of major adjustment in agriculture and with the need to increase educational opportunities for farm children, particularly in non-agricultural related areas, it mystifies me that the government is saying that assistance cannot be given. Look at the evidence we received at the rural adjustment scheme inquiry, which I made mention of a little while ago. We have to have better educated people on the farm, and we have to give people the opportunity to get their sons off the farm so that not so many people are looking for income from whatever acreage they happen to have. The rural sector has to adjust. There is no doubt about that. But, while the government mouths platitudes about adjustment, it does not provide the mechanisms by which the adjustment procedure can occur. Not allowing the removal of farm assets in rural situations to allow rural children equal access to education is an indictment on this government.

The overwhelming opinion expressed in evidence to the inquiry was that farm assets should be excluded from the assets test. The view was firmly based on the proposition that the assets test is not an appropriate indicator of the wealth of a property. Lots of properties, as everyone would know from looking at ABARE figures or whatever, have received income well below $20,000-odd. Why we have to condemn children whose parents have an asset in excess of $750,000 and an income which is nil to not having the same access to education as everyone else in the community absolutely mystifies me.

I refer the government to the evidence from not only farmers and farming organisations but other groups with genuine concerns about equity and access to education and the survival of the rural sector in Australia. One of those groups was the Catholic Women's League of Australia. They were emphatic that the farm should not be classed as an asset under Austudy criteria. The league stated that the farm is not a negotiable commodity which will pay for the education of children. It is basically a tool of trade.

The Tasmanian Rural Counselling Association—I notice Senator Calvert, who is from Tasmania, is in the chamber this afternoon; he would understand this—told the committee that our society has acknowledged the need for the young to achieve the best education at their disposal, but due to the assets test for Austudy a direct effort is being made to make further education for rural families a dream and not a reality. I think those are pretty fair words in the evidence we received.

Australian Women in Agriculture emphasised the importance of education and its future significance for the farming sector. They rightly maintained that the younger generation on the farms need the opportunity to access education so that moving in are not only young farmers, but young farmers better educated than the generation before. That is what I said a little while ago. Young people have to have the opportunity to get off the farm so that farmers can readjust. If you lived in Sydney, Mr Acting Deputy President, your kids could get Austudy if you were getting less than $20,000-odd, but these kids out on the farms cannot. Education is a basic right—not a privilege. We want everyone in Australia to be better educated, but young people in country areas are definitely being discriminated against.

My disappointment with the government's response to this report is heightened by the fact that its whole approach to rural Australia is now patently inconsistent. People have been talking about it today. I think the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) said here today in his speech on the debate to take note of answers that our real interest rates are not high. They are high, for God's sake.

Costs and charges on the farming sector are absolutely horrific when you look at other countries in the world. Killing costs for livestock in New Zealand are $100 per beast less than they are here. On the one hand, we are told that it is imperative for farmers to be better educated and to be better managers, better scientists and better technologists. Yet when faced with the opportunity to realise that goal through Austudy, the government has failed to meet its responsibilities, as was recognised in the report. Education is a right; it is not a privilege.I think those on the other side of the chamber had better think about that. They should think about it every time they go out to people in country areas who have been denied decent education.

One of the government's own departments, the DPIE, has demonstrated that 5,400 students who would otherwise have been eligible to receive Austudy on the basis of income alone would have been excluded because of the assets test. We were advised that if these young people were provided with the opportunity for further study the cost to government would be in the order of $15 million. That is not much more than those opposite waste every day, I would say. That is nowhere near what it is costing us to service our overseas debt.

It is in the national interest for young people from farming families to have access to educational opportunities in order for this productive sector to remain competitive and technologically innovative. It is not in the national interests for rural kids to be denied their right to a decent education, which those on the other side of the chamber are denying them this very day and this very hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that in announcing tax reforms in 1985 the then Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that his aim was to relieve the tax burden on middle-income Australians;

(b)expresses its concern that a study of Australia's taxation system by Access Economics shows that, 10 years after the then Treasurer Keating's so-called major reforms were announced, all persons earning less than approximately $60 000 to $70 000 per year are now paying a higher proportion of their income in tax than they were ten years ago when compulsory superannuation contributions are included;
(c)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the only people who are better off under this Government's taxation policies are high income earners, those earning 2.5 times the average weekly earnings or more, and that those who have been most disadvantaged by this Government's taxation policies are middle-income earners, on approximately average weekly earnings, and

(ii)when the compulsory superannuation guarantee charge is taken into account, as conceptually it should be, Australia's tax rates by international standards are not low, but rather are middle of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development's field, and are very high by regional standards; and

PARA.TAB: (d)condemns the Government for deliberately pursuing taxation policies which have widened the gap between rich and poor, and which have devastated middle Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1985 the then Treasurer, now Prime Minister (Mr Keating), introduced a series of taxation reforms which were, according to him, designed—and this was a promise on the government's part—to relieve the tax load on middle income Australians. The clear situation that has emerged 10 years later is that Australia's tax policies over that period have utterly failed to achieve that goal.

PARA.TAB: We have had the release this week of a report commissioned from the very reputable and highly respected consulting firm, Access Economics. That firm has done a study of Australia's tax system 10 years after the so-called major tax reforms were introduced. That study shows that people today on average weekly earnings, without any adjustments being made, are paying just $4 a week less income tax than they were 10 years ago when the so-called reforms to reduce income tax were announced—and those reforms, I remind the Senate, were designed or said to be designed primarily to ease and shift the tax load off middle income Australians. To gain just $4 on the unadjusted calculations after 10 years is a miserable result indeed, as I am sure everyone in this place would agree.

But it is even worse when you make the necessary adjustments taking into account the compulsory superannuation contributions that have been introduced into the system since then. When you make the necessary adjustments to include those contributions—and of course they should be included because workers have traded wage rises and tax cuts in order to obtain them—then those on average weekly earnings today are paying almost 20 per cent more tax as a proportion of their income than they were 10 years earlier. So much for the claim by the government at the time of the introduction of those reforms in 1985 that it was going to lift the tax burden; indeed, quite the opposite has occurred as far as middle income Australians are concerned.

All Australians on half average weekly earnings, or average weekly earnings or up to twice average weekly earnings—and that, of course, is the overwhelming majority of income recipients in Australia—are worse off now in terms of tax paid than they were 10 years ago. The only income group in Australia that is paying a smaller proportion of its income in income tax than it was 10 years ago is the high income earners—that is, those earning more than $70,000, or thereabouts, or more. Why is that so, from a government that purported to be on the side of middle Australia? Look at what it has done in relation to all the other imposts and charges that have been imposed on Australians and the unemployment that has occurred as a result of the recession in the last few years of Labor's reign.

I remind the Senate that in this financial year the government will be levying $80,000 million more taxes and charges on Australians than was the case in the last year of the previous coalition government. This year the government will levy taxes and charges of $125,000 million on Australian taxpayers, and that is just at the Commonwealth level. In the last year of the Fraser coalition government, 1982-83, the government levied taxes and charges totalling $44,000 million. So there has been not far short of a threefold increase in the tax take by the federal government during the 12 to 13 years of the Keating and Hawke Labor governments.

Indeed, if you believe Mr Keating, it has been a Keating Labor government right throughout that period. He was the Treasurer before he was Prime Minister. Of course, he boasted that he pulled all the levers of economic policy and made all the major economic policy decisions during the time of Mr Hawke's prime ministership. So, really, during 13 years of Keating domination of government in Australia, the tax bill has gone up by an unbelievable $80,000 million. No wonder not only middle income Australians but virtually all Australians, other than the very high income earners, have suffered mightily under the tax policies of this government.

It was only two years ago, at the time of the 1993 election, that Prime Minister Keating, fighting his first election, absolutely conned the Australian public with promises of tax cuts. In that election campaign in 1993, Paul Keating promised the taxpayers of Australia tax cuts totalling $14 billion—$14,000 million. The result has been that, since the election, the Prime Minister has far from delivered tax cuts; he has delivered $18,000 million of tax rises instead.

In this year's budget alone, the Prime Minister broke his promise to lower the company tax rate to 33 per cent. What did he do? He increased it to 36 per cent. That is an increase of three percentage points on the proposed rate of 33 per cent; it is an almost 10 per cent increase. He broke his promise not to increase the Medicare levy. He increased it from 1.4 per cent to 1.5 per cent. He broke his promise to pay the second tranche of the l-a-w, law, personal income tax cuts—a promise on which he arguably won the 1993 election.

After the 1993 election, the Prime Minister started working on how he could break his promise. He and then Treasurer Dawkins are on the public record the very week after the 1993 election as saying that they had started working on how to break that tax promise. In the 1993 budget, the Prime Minister started off saying that the introduction of the tax cuts would be deferred from 1 January 1996 until 1998. Now he has abandoned those tax cuts altogether. Instead, what he has done is to try to make the absolutely spurious claim that he is delivering them by another route; that is, through superannuation contributions.

Everyone knows, including the Australian public, that that is quite simply a lie. No-one is going to get any benefit from those contributions for very many years. Someone entering the work force now as a young person would have to wait until something like the year 2040 before they could get the maximum benefits that are promised. How on earth could anyone believe a promise that Mr Keating made to deliver something in the year 2040 when he cannot even keep his promise to deliver something within a period of 12 months? So the Prime Minister's argument in that regard is a total sham.

Following the 1993 election, the Prime Minister broke his promise not to increase indirect taxes. Remember when he said that he was not going to increase indirect taxes?
