So what did he do in the very first budget after the 1993 election? He increased sales tax by two per cent, and now there is an extra five per cent sales tax on cars. That two per cent increase on a sales tax rate of 10 per cent is an increase of 20 per cent. A two per cent increase on goods which are levied at a sales tax rate of 20 per cent also results in a high figure. In fact, it is a 10 per cent increase. There have been very steep increases in sales tax. The sales tax take estimated for 1995-96 is about 50 per cent higher than it was just three or so years ago.

The Prime Minister also broke his promise not to try to expand the indirect tax base. He made two promises: firstly, that he would not expand the tax base and, secondly, that he would not increase indirect tax rates. In the 1995 budget, he proposed a major expansion in the indirect tax base, with the proposal for a new tax on building materials at 12 per cent. All of these increases were part of Labor's quite disgracefully deceitful 1993 re-election campaign.

There is no doubt at all that this Labor government is a very high tax government, not just for middle income Australians but for all Australians. The rates of increase in real revenue this year, 1995-96, and last year, 1994-95, are 8.9 per cent and 7.9 per cent respectively. They are the highest growth rates recorded in consecutive years in terms of increased taxation since the quite infamous and totally economy destroying high taxing Whitlam budgets of 1973 and 1974.

Not only is the government taxing in this massive way but it is also doing it in a quite deceitful and untruthful way. It promises lower taxes but it delivers higher taxes. This promise of one thing and delivering quite the opposite has become the trademark of this government and, in particular, this Prime Minister.

In the 1993 budget—the budget of Treasurer John Dawkins, who was put in there by Prime Minister Keating; I remind the Senate that this budget was after the 1993 election—the government increased sales tax, despite a promise to the contrary, it deferred the much vaunted personal income tax and it massively raised petrol excise. Over four years these extra imposts alone have increased the total tax take by over $11,000 million. The result of all this is that today in Australia we have amongst the highest income taxes of all OECD countries. The OECD studies and the surveys done by the highly respected journal, the Economist—those surveys were taken earlier this year—show that Australia ranked as the fifth highest taxing country of average income earners after taking account of family benefits. An Ernst and Young survey carried out earlier this year has also shown that in eight out of nine scenarios examined by that company, Australians paid more income tax than their American, Japanese or British equivalents.

It is worth reminding the Senate just what this government has promised to the Australian people and what it got its latest mandate—that is, the winning of the 1993 election—for and as a result of. Prior to that election, the Treasurer said, `We will not be introducing new taxes.' The Prime Minister said, `What I'm promising is not to put up tax.' The finance minister said, `We do not intend to increase the overall burden of taxation.' The Prime Minister also said, `I don't think the incidence of taxation should rise.' Those commitments are just some of the very worst examples of contempt ever played out on the Australian people.

We have seen an increase in the ratio of tax to GDP, we have seen tax rises far outstripping inflation, we have seen tax rates increased on a whole range of goods in Australia and we have seen the abandonment of the much vaunted l-a-w, law tax cuts. As a result of all these things, today we find an Australia that is a much more unfair Australia and a more unequal Australia than we had before this government came to office.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had a top rate of 60c in the dollar.

—Top income tax rates? Have you seen what you have done to virtually every Australian? As I said, you have given some benefit to the high-fliers in Australia, the high income earners. With regard to the 98 per cent of people who earn less than $70,000 a year, you have clobbered them, you have hit them to leg, with the massive income tax increases and also a whole raft of indirect tax increases.

PARA.TAB: Since Labor came to office in 1983, the earnings of the least well paid 10 per cent of workers have actually declined in real terms by just on one per cent. Over the same period, the earnings of the highest paid 10 per cent of workers have increased by 17 per cent. So you have increased the well-being of those at the top and you have worsened the situation of those at the bottom. There has been a massive widening of the gap between rich and poor in this country and you have developed what is in grave danger of becoming a permanent underclass in this country. For a government that espouses social justice, equity and a fair go for all Australians in an egalitarian Australia, everything that you have done has been in absolute defiance of the rhetoric that you mouth on those matters.

Of the 12 nations surveyed by the OECD on these types of matters, only three—that is, Australia, the United States and Canada—experienced a real decline in the earnings of the least well paid 10 per cent of workers in the last decade. The fall in Australia was larger than that in the United States. In the United Kingdom, the earnings for this group—that is, the bottom 10 per cent—actually increased by 11 per cent. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has shown that the share of income which goes to the bottom 10 per cent of income units fell between 1981-82 and 1989-90. However, the share going to the top 10 per cent increased by two to three percentage points over that period.

One can go on and on quoting these figures, but they all add up to one thing—the widening of the gap between rich and poor in this country and the deliberate pursuit by the government of taxation policies which have caused this gap to widen, which have devastated middle Australia and which fly absolutely and totally in the face of the rhetoric and promises that have been mouthed by this government over its period in office. They are promises which have only been honoured in the breach. As a result, virtually all Australians have suffered a fall in their living standards because of the deliberate policies—it is not an accident—and the economic mismanagement of this government.

I believe that the government stands condemned for its economic management record. I am very confident that that view is shared by the overwhelming majority of Australians. I am also very confident that that feeling of disgust amongst average ordinary Australians at that type of behaviour—that a government can promise so much in order to buy its way into government and then break every promise that it makes to do that buying into government—will well and truly be reflected in the voting and the outcome at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we are debating a motion standing in the name of Senator Short which reads in part:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that in announcing tax reforms in 1985 the then Treasurer (Mr Keating) said that his aim was to relieve the tax burden on middle-income Australians;

SPEECH.PARA: I do not wish to read the whole motion at the moment, but the fact of the matter and the essence of the motion are that, as Senator Short has just said, 95 per cent to 98 per cent of income earners earn under $70,000. Sadly, it is those very people who have been disadvantaged the most in the 10 years since that statement was made by the then Treasurer.

PARA.TAB: Last Tuesday marked the 10th anniversary of that tax summit in 1985. The summit was more or less a forum, I suppose, for the Labor Party to decide upon its tax policy, albeit, I might note, after the election. There was no policy that the Labor Party went to the election with, and they now have the audacity to ask what our policy is for the next election. Well, we've got news for the Labor Party—you are not going to be invited into the dining room yet. You can wait as long as you like, but we are going to release our policies at a time of our choosing. The fact of the matter is that it will be very different to the performance of the 1985 Labor government victory when you announced it after the election. We will not be doing that.

The linchpin of that same summit was supposed to be a consumption tax. Who put that forward? No-one other than the current Prime Minister, Mr Keating. At that forum, the capital gains tax and the fringe benefits tax were also born. Both taxes have been an unmitigated disaster for many areas of small business and individuals, but that does not seem to worry this government. Both taxes are now in dire need of reform, with the latter in particular affecting many middle income Australians quite significantly.

But we are yet to see any proposal by the Labor government of any area of reform, particularly in the area of fringe benefits tax. The area of fringe benefits tax is costing an enormous amount of jobs. It is also costing a lot in terms of the income attributed to a company, which then takes away that money that could subsequently be spent on further employment.

Since the inception in 1983 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which has now had 2,500 pages of amendments added to it, it has become the most complex document—a minefield—that anyone could wish to imagine. In an effort to supposedly help the taxpayers, the government puts out a thing called the Tax Pack every year. We find this year that those average income earners who try to save a bit of money and do their own tax returns have again been led down the wrong channels by the government in the Tax Pack.

The problem we have is that this government shows little or no respect for the very people that it claims to represent. This government no longer represents the middle income earner of Australia or, in fact, the low income earner of Australia. This government has been prepared to put a million people out of work. The latest figures that the ABS can provide are the 1992 figures, which are sadly out of date and very much underestimated now. But at that time, 24 per cent of all families had no family member employed and 17 per cent of children—in other words, 700,000 children—lived in a family where neither parent worked.

This is what the government has done to the middle and low income earners. That does not seem to worry it at all, and at the same time it has been putting up taxes. I might add that we need to remember that this is the government that promised no extra taxes. As I was saying in an earlier debate today, we have seen taxes rise, rise and rise—particularly, but not only, since the 1993 commitment of no extra taxes.

The extra 2,500 pages of amendments that have been added to the Income Tax Assessment Act certainly have not served to relieve the burden of taxation. Quite the reverse: they have added bit by bit to the income pressure on most average households.

Of course the cost of compliance with these extra measures has also exploded with Australians bearing a compliance cost of about nine per cent compared with our Canadian and British counterparts, for example, who face compliance costs of about two per cent and three per cent respectively. For small business—an area where many average or middle income Australians make their living—this is a hefty burden consuming valuable resources and time and limiting their scope for expansion and further economic contributions.

To alleviate that burden, the coalition believes it is imperative that tax laws be simplified and compliance costs for individuals and businesses be reduced. At every election we have put forward policies to do just that. At the last election the examples were just so crystal clear of how those policies could be misrepresented and lied about to the point where yesterday this parliament had to pass legislation to oblige you, the Labor Party and everyone else, but specifically the Labor Party from past experience, to tell the truth in advertising during election campaigns. Had our policies not been so badly misrepresented and lied about, that type of legislation yesterday would have been totally and utterly unnecessary.

One area where middle income Australians are hard hit is at the bank. Not only are they hit by bank transaction fees, but they are hit by tax on the interest they earn, as well as having been taxed initially on their income. There is no allowance for inflation. All in all it is a pretty sorry scenario. A recent EPAC report agreed, having found that tax on the bank accounts of Australians was imposed at a rate much higher than Asian nations for example.

That report also noted that the tax imposed on average incomes in Australia was higher than the OECD average. The difference—52.4 per cent as opposed to 41.5 per cent—is considerable. Yet this government says we are leading the world. That is sheer and utter arrant nonsense. A recent report from Access Economics shows Australians are paying more in tax now than they ever were in the past decade. Who is bearing the burden of that increase? Low and middle income earners—98 per cent of people who earn less than $70,000 a year. We are so bogged down in our taxation system that really the whole thing should be torched and started again.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that your policy?

—You will just have to wait for our policy. Senator Sherry, we will at least release it prior to the election, not like what you did in the eighties. Even today we could not get Senator Cook to tell us when your tax policy is going to be released. He would not even give us a commitment whether or not there would be new taxes or increases of current taxes. So don't you sit there and flap your gums and ask when our policies will be released. We will do it of our choosing but at least it will be before the election, not the way in which you operate which is after the election. I am glad you have decided to keep quiet on that issue because it is about time you decided to zip the lip in as much as you do not tell the people honestly what you are going to do prior to an election; you do it all afterwards.

PARA.TAB: The way you have increased taxes right across the board is something that middle income Australians cannot absorb. They are not getting increases in their income the way in which you are increasing their taxes. Yet you do not seem to worry about that. Ideally tax legislation should go back to the basics. You refuse to go back to the basics. You just keep amending the tax legislation. As I said, with 2,500 pages of amendments, you just make it more complex and more difficult for them to handle.
In the Australian Financial Review on 14 January this year, David Castle, national chairman of the Barker Gosling Legal Group, wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: Ideally tax legislation should go back to basics and have the sole objective of raising revenue fairly.

He went on to say that it was time to pressure the government on this issue `with strict instructions that tax legislation should be designed only to raise the necessary revenue and not to serve a multiplicity of other purposes'. One of these days you might listen to some of these suggestions that have been put to you. They are not gratuitous suggestions or advice. They are some very sound, logical measures that could be taken so we would not see so many people disaffected by your increases in taxes and the increases in complexity.

PARA.TAB: It was a point well made, particularly stressing that taxation legislation is not fair. It is certainly not fair to those paying the highest proportion—the low and middle income earners. I am sure that middle-income Australia would be ecstatic to learn that the burden of taxation upon them has been relieved, which is the line that this government continues to push. If only that were t-r-u-e but it is not. People know that it is not. They know they are paying more taxes now than they were.

Just look at sales tax, a tax which is hidden in the price of every item we purchase and a tax which has been steadily creeping up under the Labor government. Fuel tax has gone up 7c a litre since the government won the last election. Since it last promised at the polls that it would not increase taxes, fuel tax has risen 7c a litre. We can only presume that that has added to the cost of everything else. It has. Added to that, the government has put up sales tax and a whole range of other taxes as well.

Middle Australia is ripe for the picking in terms of taxation dollars. The Labor Party knows it and they continually celebrate the harvest with great glee and gusto because every time they bring down a budget that is the area that is most heavily hit. This travesty of justice has seen the gap between rich and poor widen significantly over the past decade. Social studies show that the economic gap has widened considerably. So much for the myth that the Labor Party is concerned about equality amongst Australians.

If the Labor Party has presided over a government that has intentionally widened the gap between rich and poor, they deserve to be dismissed. They will be dismissed at the next election because middle Australia can no longer afford this government. They cannot make ends meet, they cannot afford to be out of work, and they cannot afford their families.

As I mentioned before, way back in 1972 there were 700,000 children none of whose parents had a job. Just imagine what the figure is today. The cold, hard reality is that since 1983 real incomes have fallen. When you add the forthcoming tax burden of compulsory superannuation contributions, real incomes will fall further still.

Media reports on the widening economic gap are a regular occurrence. I have a handful here, headed by such bleak phrases as `Life gets tougher on the wrong side of the tracks', `The search for social equality', `Have-nots see social gap widen', `Traditional families suffer in the 90s', and `The rich continue to grow richer'. That is just a small selection of the headings that reflect the cornerstone of this government's policy which has widened the gap between rich and poor. That, we would contest, is simply not fair.

It does not reflect the supposed intentions of the government not to tax middle Australia to the hilt. Quite the opposite: it tells a sad story of Aussie battlers, many of whom, I expect, will turn their backs on the Labor Party at the next election.

It was stated in April that the income gap between the top and bottom five per cent of households almost doubled between 1976 and 1991, producing a gap of $20,144 or 92 per cent. That data came from a study by Reserve Bank board members and an academic from the Australian National University. The report also said that the study served as a reminder to the Prime Minister that it was traditional Labor voters who had suffered the most over the past 12 years.

The fact, as the study showed, that incomes of people in the average to poorer suburbs had fallen 23 per cent while those in the richest areas had seen their incomes grow by the same amount, is quite disturbing. That was before the budget, which delivered more tax hikes at all levels. It pushed personal taxation up 13.6 per cent, making Mr Keating the highest taxing Prime Minister in Australia's history. If that is a record of which you wish to be proud, good luck to you, because the Australian people will tolerate it no longer.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to point out some of the key elements of Senator Short's motion that we are debating here today. There is a reference to the Access Economics report, which I will deal with in some detail a little later. There is a comment in respect of compulsory superannuation contributions. I will be touching on that area, but I think one of my colleagues will deal with that in more detail and develop some of the issues there. There is also a reference to our tax rates being in the middle of the field of the OECD and very high by regional standards, and I will be making some comments about that as well. I will also be making some reference to the contributions of opposition speakers Senator Short and Senator Knowles as I go through my comments this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: I welcome this debate and the motion that Senator Short has moved, because I am proud of what we have accomplished in the general areas of taxation, social security and Medicare over the last decade since we have been in office. I am proud of it, and I do not shy away from our record. If we look at it in totality—rather than make the narrow and very glib and superficial analysis that has been made by Senator Short and by Senator Knowles on these issues—if we look at the total income receipts of people in Australia, their total service delivery in the areas of superannuation and Medicare, and if we compare where we are with our Asian neighbours and with countries of the OECD, this country is one of the best in the world to live in.

Dealing with the Access Economics report, which has been referred to in the debate and also in the motion, we see a number of deficiencies in the report. We reject the allegation that, compared with 10 years ago, there has been an increase in the Australian tax burden. We reject the analysis that the indirect taxation system remains narrowly based. Presumably that is saying, `Well, we should have a GST.' We will not be subscribing to a GST. It also says that Australians would be paying less tax under Fightback—that word the opposition never want to mention any more.

How times have changed. I do not want to reflect too much on the past, but I can recall debates on these sorts of issues three years ago. Opposition members had this big document, a couple of hundred pages thick, called Fightback. Every time we came in here to debate an issue, they were flashing the Fightback document in front of us and boasting about it. It was almost like a bible really. The evangelical opposition were holding up their bible of policy about what they were going to do to Australia. Now have they gone in the opposite direction. Not only are they trying to forget Fightback—never mention it again—but now they are boasting, `Let's not have any policies. Let's go to the election campaign and not have any policies.' I think the Australian electorate is a little bit smarter than that.

The Access Economics report is based on a selective and a misleading interpretation of taxation statistics. I know we all quote statistics to support our cases, but the use and abuse of statistics has really reached an art form in the opposition's contribution in this and other policy debates.

In respect of the personal tax regime, we have made extensive reform of the income tax system over the past decade. That has been targeted not just at higher income earners, as the opposition allege, but at lower and middle income earners. Over the past decade, the marginal rate of tax for middle income earners has been cut from 46c in the dollar to 34c in the dollar. That is indisputable fact; it is fact. There is no mention of it by any in the opposition.

The bottom marginal tax rate has been cut by one-third, from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. That is fact. It is irrefutable fact. The effective tax-free threshold, taking into account the low income rebate, has been boosted by more than a third. Again, that is fact, but we hear nothing of it from the opposition. Total income tax revenue raised from individuals has declined from 13.5 per cent of gross domestic product in 1984-85 to 12 per cent in 1994-95.

How do we reconcile this set of facts with, for example, Senator Knowles statement that income tax receipts in the last budget increased by 13.6 per cent? There is a very simple explanation. The reason why income receipts are going up is that employment is going up. It is not because income tax levels are going up but because employment is going up. More people are employed, so therefore the tax receipts of government in the income tax area go up. That is why in the budget the total receipts from income tax have increased by 13.6 per cent. That is a testimony to the government's success in boosting employment—not a testimony to the government increasing the tax burden. That is a very good example of how the opposition misuse statistics in this debate.

Returning to the Access Economics report: the conclusion that Australians have experienced an increased tax burden is based on a false premise. I have already referred to one of the false premises, but another is that the Access Economics report is including compulsory employer superannuation contributions.

TALK.START.PARA: —And quite rightly so.
—No; employees do not pay the superannuation contribution. Employers pay it. It is currently four per cent or five per cent, depending on the level of—
—It is still a tax.

—It is a tax, but it is not the employee who pays it. Really, be honest about that. We do not resile from our reforms with superannuation, because without superannuation how are we going to pay for pensions in 20 or 30 years time, when a proportion of people will not be paying tax because they are over the age of 65, 60 or whatever age they want to retire at?
—I have no argument with that.

—You do. You opposed the superannuation contributions when they were introduced. My colleague will make some further comments about the necessity of and equity in those contributions. We are about equity. We are preparing for 20 or 30 years hence, when these issues will need to be addressed. It is no good saying in 20 or 30 years time that we need to increase pension contributions. It is no good doing that in 20 or 30 years time, when we will have a significant increase in people at retirement age. We have to start doing something now.

PARA.TAB: I think that is one of the highlights between our approach to policy and the opposition's. Our policy in the area of super plans for 20 to 30 years down the track. You do not plan anything for two or three years down the track, let alone 20 or 30 years down the track. Show us your policies so that the electorate can judge. It is incorrect to claim that employer contributions in the superannuation area are taxes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is that?

—The revenue does not come to the government. The revenue from superannuation contributions is locked away in private sector superannuation, just as the contributions where employees voluntarily put money into superannuation funds are not government revenue. That is locked away for the employees' benefit, for their future income. This is the reason the OECD excludes contributions under Australia's superannuation guarantee in its calculation of Australia's taxation revenue statistics. That is a very important issue.

PARA.TAB: The Access Economics report says that Australia is a low taxed country by OECD standards because compulsory superannuation contributions are excluded for Australia but included for the other countries. There is no doubt that that statement is misleading. The contributions are included for other countries because they are collected by government for the payment of social security benefits—not just pension payments, which are certainly one of the major social security benefits. But they are paid out by government in these countries.

The tax reforms introduced by the government over the last 10 years have significantly improved the efficiency and equity of the tax system. I can recall when we came to office there were significant perks enjoyed by a small section of the community. Superannuation was certainly one of them. The higher income earners in our society were getting significant tax breaks for superannuation. Less than 40 per cent of the work force—and they were higher income earners; and including public servants, I might say—were getting very significant superannuation, but the lower to middle income earner generally was getting no superannuation at all and not, therefore, deriving any tax benefit. We have changed all that, fortunately.

What about areas such as free motor vehicles, the free meals and the variety of other perks—lower loans through financial institutions and free air travel? They were the sorts of perks that generally—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are talking about the trade unions.

—The average trade unionist did not get those sorts of perks. I represented workers in the hospitality industry and the only perk I can recall was the free beer allocation to brewery workers. That was the only perk they got. Frankly, I always thought that was a bit dubious from the point of view of health. But the only perk for the workers I represented was that free beer allocation. Workers across the hospitality industry and the beverage industry did not get any perks. It was generally confined to high income earners.

PARA.TAB: We introduced the fringe benefits tax. I remember the debate at the time. The opposition, of course, opposed the fringe benefits tax outright. They have moved a little since then. They are now saying that they are going to reduce the administrative cost on small business, whatever that means. I think that was as near as a policy announcement John Howard got at the MTIA conference yesterday. We saw speaker after speaker from the opposition making generalised statements, but that was about as near as they got: we are going to reduce the administrative costs. How?

TALK.START.PARA: —You'll hear it.

—You can wave your hand, but I am sure the electorate would like to know how you are going to reduce the administrative cost. When any opposition party wants to get into government, they talk about saving money through administrative efficiencies. We do that too. Let's be honest; we have done that. Oppositions do that. When they get into government and they have to find $3 billion or $4 billion in revenue, it is not quite so easy to find those administrative efficiencies, but apparently in the area of fringe benefits tax that will happen.

PARA.TAB: I can recall when the FBT was introduced. There were rallies around the country prompted by opposition speakers. I can recall John Howard speaking at one. The hospitality industry was going to be destroyed overnight by this tax. What happened? We have double the number of jobs in the hospitality industry today than we had in 1983. That was one prophecy about the destruction of the small business sector and the hospitality industry by the FBT. We do not hear that from the opposition any more.

TALK.START.PARA: —`There shall be no FBT in 1984.' Remember that?

—That was not what we said in 1984. The exaggeration we had at the time! But now the opposition has accepted that the FBT will stay, `but it is going to be improved administratively', whatever that means. We will find out the detail about that.

PARA.TAB: The important point about it is that it has improved the equity of the tax system. Generally, it was the higher income earners who benefited substantially from the reduction in the top rate of income tax from 60c down to 42c. They have benefited. They should pay tax based on a fair assessment of their income.

The FBT is an important equity issue. I know the same can be said about the capital gains tax. These two measures have ensured that all major forms of income are subject to tax, irrespective of how they are earned. Revenue from these measures has allowed reductions in the marginal tax rates. This is a much fairer and more equitable system. That is why I say, quite genuinely and quite sincerely, I am proud of the reforms we have made to the tax system in the last 10 years of this government.

I do not want you to think that because I am winding down a little in my contribution I am going to finish. I have another 15 minutes to go. I made a half-an-hour contribution last week on this subject.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will move an extension of time.

—We will have to see what the opposition says about that. I have a lot more to add to this debate about tax. Senator Panizza was here last week. I am not going to talk about the port of Burnie again. I think you got a little weary about that contribution last week. I wanted to put our port reform in perspective. That was important. I actually live in the port of Burnie. That is another issue. I will admit it is off the subject that we have to discuss today.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the area of indirect taxation. Again, we have not heard the full story. The figures presented in the Access Economics report suggesting that Australia's indirect taxation system is narrowly based do not stand up to scrutiny. We should not accept the theme of the Access Economics report. I noticed, increasingly, business commentators and others saying we need a GST. We are not going to be introducing a GST.

There are a number of factors affecting the share of indirect tax revenue in total revenue collections. The increase in the share of indirect tax revenue as a proportion of non-income tax revenue reflects a decline in other sources of revenue. A couple are important to highlight. Firstly, this government handed over debits tax to the states. We do not get any thanks for it. All they do is complain. They want more and more; spend more and more; and complain more and more. If you get into government—I see Senator Campbell smiling—wait and see the troubles the state governments give you. You must admit that the state governments really do want it both ways. They do not want to collect the revenue by taxes, but they want the money. They want to be able to spend it as much as they can.

TALK.START.PARA: —They want some certainty.
—They certainly want certainty. They want certainty of an increase in revenue. They get all the credit for expenditure if they can do it.
—They have been cutting their spending while you have been putting yours up.

—I do not think that is true. There have been cuts in areas of expenditure in some areas by some states. I will admit, on the public record, that some of the state Labor governments were less than competent in handling their budgets. I will accept that as a valid criticism. I would like to hear you accept a valid criticism on occasions. We handed over the debits tax to the states.

PARA.TAB: One other important area which is often forgotten is our review of tariffs in this country. Again, it is a tribute rather than a criticism. I do not have the figures in front of me, but I got quite a shock at the level of government revenue that tariffs contributed. It was billions of dollars 10 years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sid wants to bring it back.

—Yes, Sid wants to bring it back. That was a very substantial indirect tax. Because we have reduced tariffs there has been a significant decline in government revenue in this area. That feeds through the cost structure of goods in this country. It has led to lower costs than would otherwise have applied. It has had a number of other beneficial effects. I am a supporter of tariff reforms. There has been some debate on this issue in the government and in the opposition. We have carried out that fundamental reform.
—Very good reforms.

—You are on the record congratulating us for something. Thank you very much. I really had to wring it out of you. We have been responsible for the tariff reforms in this country. It has been to our cost in the revenue area. A lot of people forget that.

PARA.TAB: The suggestion that excise revenues are declining fails to recognise that some of the excise revenue which was collected as crude oil excise is now collected as petroleum resource rent tax—a direct tax. Whilst on this issue of indirect taxes on petroleum, we were criticised in the budget 2 1/2 years ago for increasing the petroleum excise.

Tax measures are not just there to raise revenue; they do serve a range of other purposes. One of the reasons for the increase in the excise on leaded fuel was as an environmental measure. It serves an important purpose. Again, I cannot give the figures to the Senate, but I have looked at the consumption figures for lead petrol vis-a-vis unleaded petrol. I think last year for the first time we were consuming more unleaded petrol than leaded petrol. I was at an industry conference held here in Parliament House where industry accepted that, if we were to phase out leaded petrol, we had to have a price differential between leaded and unleaded petrol. That is one of the other reasons for restructuring the tax system.

The Access report suggests that more tax revenue is being collected now than would have been collected under Fightback. But unlike Fightback, the current wholesale sales tax is a selective tax, which is very important—and some people criticise it because it is a selective tax; I do not. It provides exemptions for a range of necessities which would have been taxed under the GST. We could debate the GST and its inefficiencies in terms of administration—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, let's not.
—No, you certainly do not want to, Senator Campbell. My time is flying—only 10 minutes to go and I have such a lot I want to say.

PARA.TAB: I want to compare Australia with other countries in the OECD. I think it is very important for us to have a look at this issue. The August 1995 release of the annual publication Revenue Statistics of OECD Member Countries shows that, in 1993, Australia had the second lowest ratio of total tax revenue to GDP in the OECD. We were the sixth lowest in 1985, the third lowest in 1990 and the second lowest in 1991-92. Australian tax revenue in 1993 was 28.7 per cent of gross domestic product compared with an OECD unweighted average of 38.7. This is marginally higher than the equivalent figure for 1992, when Australian tax revenue was 28.6 per cent of gross domestic product compared with an OECD unweighted average of 38.4 per cent.

I am just getting wound up in this debate. I think I will need that extension. Senator Panizza is not looking at me very hopefully, though I think the Burnie debate of the last sitting fortnight might have scared him off giving me extensions.

I have to say, I do get a bit boring reading out the figures and the statistics. But they are sound statistics that support our case. Really, to sum it up in a nutshell—and I am not going to conclude—we are a very low taxed country by OECD standards, yet we provide a range of comprehensive social security safety net measures such as a sound education system, a sound health system and a sound retirement superannuation pension system.

I think by international comparison those measures stand up very well, that is, with countries with which you can make a valid comparison—the OECD, the advanced economic countries. One of the reasons we are able to do that is because we are one of the most rigorous countries in the world when it comes to means-testing. If you were to go to the United States and say, `We are going to target social security payments and take them away from upper and middle income earners,' there would be a massive reaction to that sort of proposal. In many of these countries they are paying social security payments to people who have high incomes. That is something that we do not do in Australia, and that is one of the reasons why we have been able to have rational, more efficient, more equitable systems of tax and social security.

The OECD publication contains preliminary data for 1994 for Australia but not for the USA or Japan. This data shows Australia's tax to GDP ratio increasing slightly in 1994. However, it is still likely that Australia has retained its position very near the bottom of the OECD tax to GDP ratios. On the basis of the figures published for 1993, Australia's tax base remains very similar in its broad aggregate to that of other OECD countries. It is wrong to conclude that Australia's tax base is relatively narrow simply because in 1993 taxes on incomes and profits contributed 53.7 per cent of all tax revenue, compared with the unweighted OECD average of 36.7 per cent.

If social security contributions and payroll taxes are added to taxes on incomes and profits, the contribution in 1993 to total tax revenue from these taxes in Australia is 59.8 per cent. It was well below the unweighted OECD average of 63.2 per cent. Taxes on goods and services generated 29.8 per cent of Australia's total tax revenue, just below the unweighted OECD average of 30.1 per cent. Property taxes accounted for 10.4 per cent of total Australian revenue in 1993, compared to the OECD unweighted average of 5.7 per cent. Who levies property taxes in this country? Not this federal Labor government, but the state and local governments. We can hardly be blamed for the higher than average revenue in the area of property taxes.

I do not want to bore you with statistics, but in the total personal tax area: Australia, 11.7 per cent of gross domestic product; Britain, 11.5 per cent; Japan, 11.2 per cent; and the United States, 13.6 per cent. We all tend to think, with the so-called compact with America and the revolution going on in the United States in the tax and budget area, that the US is a low taxing country. It is not, interestingly. The OECD average is 14.7 per cent. In relation to goods and services: Australia, 8.6 per cent; Britain, 11.9 per cent; Japan, 4.2 per cent; the US, 5.1 per cent; and the OECD average, 11.6 per cent. So, in broad comparisons, Australia does well, particularly when you look at the services we deliver.

Unfortunately I have only five minutes left. I would have liked to have contributed for a little longer. This is only the second time in my five years in the Senate that I have spoken for the full half an hour. The first time was my famous port of Burnie speech a fortnight ago. You might have been fortunate enough to sit through that. I did not even speak for the full time allotted in my first speech.

Let us compare Australia with our regional neighbours. Certainly our tax levels are higher than countries such as Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore and Hong Kong. We own up to that. I want to raise a matter with the Senate and the people in the public gallery—I was also going to say the public, but we are not on broadcast today, which is a great pity. The last time I made my full half hour contribution, which was on the port of Burnie, we were not broadcasting. I seem to get the non-broadcasting days. But I say to the 10 or so people here, including the attendants: we should be proud of the fact that we are taxed more highly than Indonesia, Malaysia, Singapore and Hong Kong. Frankly, if you wanted to live on their health systems or on their pension payments—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you pay more for a hamburger in Tokyo?

—You do; we pay much more than here. But if you look at the social security systems of these countries, you will see why their tax systems are so low. If you want effective government services—such as pensions, a decent health system and a decent education system—you have to pay for it, and you pay for it through your tax structure. The social security systems in the Asian countries are systems based on the extended family, and that is not the culture of Australia. That is the fundamental flaw in this continual analysis of Australia and our Asian neighbours. We can have tax rates equivalent to our Asian neighbours, but you will get Asian standard services, and they are pretty poor and pretty low.
—Stop attacking our neighbours.

—I am not attacking our neighbours. They have chosen to go a different way. Corporate tax rates in Japan are 51.6 per cent; in Australia, 36 per cent; China, 33 per cent; Indonesia, 30 per cent; Malaysia, 30 per cent; and Singapore, 27 per cent. My source is the Economist intelligence unit, which I know Senator Campbell reads. I have been an avid reader of the Economist for a couple of decades. If you want tax revenue equivalent to Asia, you have to provide government services equivalent to Asia—and it is pretty much zilch in Hong Kong and Singapore. I am in my last minute of contribution. I am a little sad about that. I am equally sad that anyone who was in the public gallery has left—and I spent four or five hours in here today. My speech has not attracted the throngs, but I wanted to make a contribution to put this tax issue into full perspective. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have thought Senator Sherry would have learnt something since he spoke in the debate on the Radiocommunications (Transmitter Licence Tax) Amendment Bill and associated bills this morning. But it looks as though he knows even less about economics than he does about radiocommunications. In his contribution, Senator Sherry quoted from the Economist. I also have with me an article from the Economist which contains a graph of income tax as a percentage of gross earnings in various countries throughout the world. The section headed `Personal income tax' reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The chart, based on an OECD study, shows income taxes (to central, state and local governments) paid by a two-child family earning average manufacturing wages.

According to this article, Scandinavian countries are at the top. We are the fifth highest taxing country in the world in the case of a family on average wages with two children. There are countries that are far less taxing than we are with which we have to compete. We pay more tax than Norway, Ireland, Italy, Britain, Canada, Belgium, the United States, Holland, Germany, Switzerland, Austria, Spain, Japan, Portugal, France and Luxembourg. Those figures speak for themselves.

PARA.TAB: It is a pity that the proceedings were not being broadcast while Senator Sherry was carrying on. He would have lost some votes in Tasmania after the way he carried on. Senator Sherry continually talked about personal tax. He never mentioned the massive increase in sales tax by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). He never mentioned the increase in the fuel levy. He never mentioned a heap of other things. He never mentioned the blow-out in the fringe benefits tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did mention that.

—No, you did not mention the blow-out. You also did not mention the blow-out in capital gains tax. We were told that the fringe benefits tax was not going to be around in 1985, but the net has been widened like a creeping cancer. We have had increases in the KST, the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax. Let us look at the whole picture which you never mentioned, Senator Sherry.

PARA.TAB: Paul Keating claimed that his tax reform package, now 10 years old, was an historic achievement—and he still does for that matter. Government speakers parrot off, as has Senator Sherry, about the number of jobs they have created from this system. I can tell you that any creation of jobs in Australia over the last couple of years has been as a result of the state Liberal governments that have sprung up in the last few years. For instance, in Western Australia 90,000 new jobs have been created since February 1993. When you have a better managed government, more jobs are created. The state Liberal government started projects such as the gas line into the north-west. My friend on the other side could not decry that project. They have also been responsible for various other projects.

In South Australia only 27,000 jobs have been created since January 1993 because the Liberal government came in at a later stage. Victoria has created a massive 140,000 jobs. If jobs have been created in Australia, it is because of the state Liberal governments which provide better management. I do not need to mention what happened in New South Wales and in your state of Tasmania, Senator Sherry. Let Mr Keating explain to the people who are still unemployed what his great historic event of 1985 has done 10 years down the track. It has not brought good news to those who are still unemployed. I will come back to that issue later.

I refer to an article in the Australian Financial Review of Tuesday, 12 September 1995 headed `Burden of income tax too heavy'. The Financial Review has not been a great friend of the coalition for a very long time, but I will quote what they had to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The latest OECD study on taxation, which ranked Australia as the second-lowest taxed country in the Western world, serves to underpin once again the validity of that often heard claim that there are lies, there are damn lies, and there are statistics.
That is what it said. It continues:

PARA.TAB: For while the statistics used by the OECD study—

TALK.START.PARA: —But no opposition policies.
—Wait a minute.
—There are policies, there are government policies, but there are no opposition policies.

—Just as Senator Cook said, `You will see them when the election comes', you will see ours when the election comes. We will not give you a chance to lie about them like you did in 1993. They will be there. Senator Cook spelt it out yesterday. I will get back to the article:

PARA.TAB: For while the statistics used by the OECD study are no doubt correct, they are notable as much for what they don't reveal as for what they do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly like opposition policy; it doesn't reveal anything.
—And government policy, which has remained hidden. The editorial says:

SPEECH.PARA: Further, what has remained hidden has more relevance for future policy-making than do the comparisons that the study has highlighted.

PARA.TAB: Rather than providing a reason for complacency about Australia's existing tax system, a more comprehensive examination would have quickly highlighted a number of crucial tax areas that are in urgent need of reform.

In the case of the specific details of the OECD study, its most basic oversight is its failure to take proper account of the way in which Australia's compulsory superannuation system operates as a de facto social security tax, along the lines of those imposed by most other OECD countries.
Past studies have shown that once appropriate account is taken of the impact of the superannuation contributions, Australia ranks in the middle of the pack, not as one of the lowest-taxed countries.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite this, there is little doubt that it needs to be factored in when calculating our tax burden relative to other OECD countries.
There is a lot more that I could quote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you quoting from the Financial Review?

—Yes, and I will quote more at your invitation, Senator Sherry. The article says that the equation is much less flattering. When you compare it with Asian countries and the OECD, it is certainly less flattering for Australia. What happened the next day? Mr Willis, our Treasurer, then went in to defend the government.
—And a good one too.
—Well, we will see what his results are in the long run. We have seen all that now. Mr Willis took on the editorial in a letter to the editor, in which he wrote:

PARA.TAB: Your contention relies on three points: the OECD should include employer superannuation contributions under the Superannuation Guarantee as tax . . .

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say:

PARA.TAB: Employer contributions to superannuation funds under the Superannuation Guarantee are not included in taxation revenue figures for Australia because the OECD defines taxation revenue to include only social security contributions . . .

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Willis went on to say:
Contributions under the Superannuation Guarantee are paid to private sector superannuation funds . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —Exactly my point.
—You made that point.
—They get it back, don't they?
—Yes, they get it back instead of a pension. What is the situation with Medibank Private? What is the situation there?
—It depends.
—What depends?
—It depends whether you are sick or not.
—How do you compare it then? Mr Willis went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: These contributions are not available for the Commonwealth Government to use for its own purposes—
I know they are not—
and are therefore, appropriately,—
in his description—
not defined by the OECD as taxation.
Then he went on to say:

The social security contribution schemes of other countries that you allude to are paid to government for the purposes of government providing social security benefits, on a pay as you go basis. They are no more than hypothecated tax, and are rightly treated as such by the OECD.
The point is, as I said the other day, that these contributions are forced upon you by law. We have passed laws to take money out of people's pockets. So how can you tell me it is not a tax?

TALK.START.PARA: —But the government doesn't get it—the people get it.
—Senator Sherry, you have shown you know very little about taxation measures in the last half hour. But if it is not a tax, why is it handled by the Treasury? Why isn't it handled by Social Security?
—It goes to private sector superannuation.

—Yes, but I am talking about the guarantee levy. If the employer does not pay it or does not pay enough, who collects it? Treasury collects it. If you say that, it should be collected by Social Security.
—No it doesn't, I am afraid.
—Yes, it does—it should be collected by Social Security, if the employer does not pay. The guarantee levy goes to the tax department.
—No, it doesn't.

—Yes, it does. So it must be a tax. Anyhow, that is a small point. When you go past that, what the government is doing with superannuation is privatising it and virtually contracting it out to funds, because you can contribute to quite a few funds other than the union controlled funds; you can go wherever you want to go. Of course, a bit later on, various other funds could be opened up. But at present we have quite a few. That is all the government is doing—they are taxing employers. But the amount that comes from employers is only forgone wages. A union person, as you were Senator Sherry, should know that—they are forgone wages.
—Which you were going to pay!

—Whatever was going to be done, it is a tax that is collected by coercion, by laws passed in this place. It is privatised out to those funds to invest. You could not really trust a government fund because the funds would be mismanaged, like a lot of other things that this government does. It is privatised out so that when people retire, it is there for them to collect. It is no different from having a tax on Social Security. I have already mentioned the article relating to the OECD in the Financial Review. As I said, they are not very friendly to us.

PARA.TAB: Let us get back to the employment which this tax package is supposed to create. As I said before, let Mr Keating tell the unemployed what he has done with this tax package. People could be forgiven for thinking that the underemployed are not real. There are three categories in Australia—the employed, the unemployed and the underemployed. The underemployed are never mentioned by those on the government benches. Anyone who works for an hour a week is regarded by this government as employed.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't want to know.

—When did Senator Sherry or Senator Jones ever mention the underemployed? Let us look at the figures, because the government ignores them. With regard to the reduction in unemployment, people go into training schemes; they prefer to be in a job, so that helps to cut the figures. Perhaps these underemployed are just a figment of the opposition's imagination. It could be said that they are a figment of anyone's imagination, but they are real, and the statistics show where the current government has failed.

PARA.TAB: I have some statistics here. The Australian Bureau of Statistics collects precise figures on the number of employed, unemployed and underemployed every month. It was doing this long before the famous Keating tax package of 1985. What he said in 1984 in that tax summit changed a lot between then and 1995. I can remember vividly him saying in the 1984 election that there would be no FBT. Anyhow, that is history now. We have got it and it is a growing cancer.

These figures come out every month, and every month the government quotes them for the employed and the unemployed. But the underemployed are never mentioned. The Australian Bureau of Statistics precisely defines the underemployed as those part-time employed persons who prefer to work more hours, plus full-time employed persons who work less than 35 hours a week. In other words, they are the ones who are partly employed but would like to work full time. So the underemployed are those who have some work, as I said, but not always as much as they would like.

To test the true impact of the Keating taxation reforms, you have to go back to 1985. It was recorded in 1985 that there were 607,600 unemployed, or 8.4 per cent of the labour force. But it was also recorded in 1985 that there were 225,000 underemployed, or 3.1 per cent of the labour force. So you have to add those figures. This meant at that time that 11.5 per cent of the total work force were either unemployed or underemployed.

We can look at the comparable figures for June this year, exactly 10 years later, to see how much this government has come forward with the famous tax package of 1985. The present Bureau of Statistics figures for June this year show that there are 724,800 unemployed. That is down on the massive unemployment figures of the recession we had to have, but a rise of 117,200 on the figure 10 years ago. Okay, you can tell me that there is more population and all that sort of thing, but unemployment has gone up to 724,000 in 1985, a rise of 117,000 in 10 years. This represents 8.1 per cent of the work force, or a fall of only 0.03 per cent on the 1985 figure.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are broadcasting now.
—Are we? That will really wind me up.
—Can I speak again?

—I will not give you leave to speak again. The underemployed figure has skyrocketed to 597,000. It has skyrocketed from 225,000 underemployed in 1985, the figure I quoted before. There are now 597,000 underemployed, and the government stands condemned by those figures. The number has increased by almost 200 per cent over those 10 years, with an additional 372,000 people forced by Keating-created economic policies to accept less than they are prepared to work for. That means that in June a combined total of 14.7 per cent were unemployed or underemployed. This is Keating's economic failure.

PARA.TAB: We do not hear these figures from anyone across that side of the chamber and we do not read them too much in the press either these days. It does not matter what senators say on that side or how the government puts these figures or what the government may claim to have done in the last 10 years: the bottom line is that since 1985 Mr Paul Keating has allowed an extra 489,200 workers to fall behind as either unemployed or underemployed workers. This is nearly half a million people. I noticed that Senator Sherry has gone very quiet on these figures. In summary, there are now an extra half a million unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have spoken for half an hour.

—I know but I have got to repeat it so that it will sink into the minds of those four government senators in here and into the rest of Australia. I will repeat the figure that this famous economic package of Keating of 1985 has created: it has gone backwards and allowed an extra 489,200 workers to fall behind what they were. The government stands condemned for this and, in time, they will pay heavily for it at the next election. I have another article here on our famous Treasurer, Mr Willis.
—Which newspaper is this from?

—The Financial Review again, one that is not very friendly to us. I could have picked a newspaper around Australia that is favourable to us but I picked the Financial Review. The article headed `Exodus from PAYE "blow to tax system"' states:

SPEECH.PARA: The income tax system is being undermined as changing work practices allow a growing stream of people to slip through the PAYE tax net, according to the Federal Treasurer, Mr Willis.

PARA.TAB: Mr Willis said the exodus from the PAYE system as more workers moved into self-employment, contracting and piece work was one of six major challenges the tax system was likely to face in the next decade.

SPEECH.PARA: Do you know of any people in self-employment, contracting or piece work that have been given tax-free status? If any senator opposite can tell me that, then some of us may be able to make use of it. But the fact is that Mr Willis is wrong again, because you still have to file a tax return and pay tax. If you are self-employed you pay provisional tax and contracting work is picked up by prescribed payments, particularly around the building industry. What is Mr Willis talking about—another smokescreen? All those employment opportunities going out into private enterprise, which is a good system as far as I am concerned, are still taxed. What is he crying foul about?

PARA.TAB: We had a misrepresentation from Senator Chris Evans the other day on what Western Australia is doing with enterprise agreements. I told him about it and I will answer him during the adjournment debate next Monday. I did not use my full time, as I could have quite easily used it; I will let my colleagues use the remaining time. In conclusion, Mr Keating and his government stand condemned for these underemployed. They also stand condemned for the statements they make claiming Australia to be a low taxed country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have sat here and listened to Senator Panizza speak for about 25 minutes. I am glad he did not speak for 30 minutes, because it was really getting heavy at the end. It was pretty hard just continuing to cop the diatribe that Senator Panizza came out with. He was wandering all around the topic making a lot of ridiculous assertions—none of which, of course, are borne out by the facts.

PARA.TAB: I want to bring the Senate back to looking at some of the facts that relate to this motion moved by Senator Short. First of all, I would like to remind Senator Panizza that this motion seeks to criticise the government with respect to taxation policy and superannuation.

The last people in this country who should ever be getting up to criticise anybody, any government, this government, about taxation or superannuation are the people sitting opposite. When you lost office in 1983 we had the greatest tax avoidance industry in this country. In fact tax avoidance was the only industry in this country that was going forward. That was your industry policy—tax avoidance. Of course you had the most pathetic, woeful approach to superannuation in the history of this country.

Less than 40 per cent of the Australian work force had access to superannuation. Superannuation in the days of the coalition government, which was a long time ago—it will be even longer, if ever, before they get to the treasury bench—was nothing but a privilege for a very small minority. Superannuation was available to those people in high paid jobs, in industries with industrial strength, such as the oil industry, or in the Public Service. It was available to them because of the benevolence of the employer. It was not an industrial right. It was not an award entitlement.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a package.
—It was not a package at all. It was simply a benefit—
—A lurk.

—For many in higher paid jobs particularly, a lurk. It was a benefit that very few in the community had access to. Of course one of the great advances of the Hawke and Keating Labor governments that will be looked on in years to come as having changed the savings base of this country and the retirement incomes entitlements of this country will be the great advances made in the area of superannuation. It will be looked back on in years to come as one of the most significant social and economic advances ever achieved in the history of this country, and it took a Labor government to do it. What it did was guarantee present and future Australians a right, an entitlement, to a better and a secure retirement.

PARA.TAB: As I said, back in 1983 less than 40 per cent of the Australian work force received superannuation. Today that figure is in excess of 90 per cent. The entire work force in this country will eventually be entitled to a decent superannuation scheme. Today, more importantly, superannuation entitlements extend to low and middle income workers. Why is that the case? In 1983 and subsequently, the Labor government, in conjunction with the trade union movement in this country and very few but some enlightened employers, recognised that superannuation had to become an industrial award right.

I recall and I know that Senator Sherry will recall—and it is true, Senator Panizza, as you have acknowledged—that we were trade union officials in those days. We were out there fighting to get superannuation entitlements for our members and workers in this country. What were your colleagues in the employer peak councils, like the National Farmers Federation, the BCA and the Confederation of Australian Industry, doing? They were opposing superannuation all the way down the line.

They opposed it in the Industrial Relations Commission. They opposed it whenever a union came along to the commission and sought to have that entitlement arbitrated. You, Senator Panizza, are very well aware of the struggle, the long fight, that took place to get superannuation entitlements for people who worked in the rural industries in this country. It took two to three years of ongoing litigation in the Industrial Relations Commission to get superannuation for some of the lowest paid workers in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was paying super for my employees 20 years ago.

—You may have been paying it, Senator Panizza, because you happen to have been a benevolent employer in your own right, but you had thousands of other colleagues in industry that refused to pay superannuation. They had to be dragged screaming and kicking to the table to pay it. It was opposed all the way down the line by John Howard and the Liberal Party. It was opposed by the employer ranks in this country.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza did say that this superannuation payment of three per cent, as it was then—it is now four or five per cent, depending on the particular size of the work force that you are involved in—was a forgone wage increase. That is partly true because the initial three per cent superannuation payment was negotiated as an entitlement to be brought into awards in lieu of a claim for national productivity. So it was in one sense a deferred wage increase.

But what was more important about it was that, rather than just paying another three per cent at that time when wage restraint was necessary and when the union movement and the workers of this country recognised that in the interests of the Australian economy we needed to have wage restraint, it was agreed to pay that entitlement in superannuation because it would be of lasting benefit to the work force of this country and of lasting benefit to the country.

Of course I did not hear any employers in those days, Senator Panizza—and I negotiated with quite a lot of them—saying to us, `We don't want you to have the three per cent superannuation. We want to give you the three per cent wages instead.' No-one was running up to the commission from the employer ranks and saying, `We want to give a three per cent wage increase.' You know that is the case because you know that, whether it was going to be delivered in terms of superannuation or wage increases, you and your supporters in the employer ranks and the employer organisations in this country would have opposed it, as they have opposed every single national wage increase since then, with the exception of one. We used to have to go in there and argue against incapacity to pay cases time and again in order to obtain superannuation entitlements or national wage increases.

Do not stand up here and lecture us about deferred wage increases. If you had your way, every single national wage increase would be deferred forever. Had this been delivered as a wage increase, what would have happened to that three per cent? Anywhere between 20 per cent and 50 per cent of it would have gone in tax, so it actually assisted—by your own strange logic—in reducing the tax burden at the time, and it has gone on doing so.

You make a fundamental mistake in your remarks, as Senator Short does. The Treasurer (Mr Willis) has pointed this out. You cannot logically include compulsory superannuation contributions in these calculations when you look at the proportion of income that goes in tax because, as Senator Sherry pointed out in that brilliant half-hour analysis of the tax system in this country, which could have gone on for at least an hour—it is unfortunate that his address was not broadcast at the time—the contributions are paid by the employer. Originally it was a three per cent contribution; it has now moved to either four or five per cent, depending on the level of salary in the particular workplace, and it will increase eventually to nine per cent. But it does not come out of the employee's income as tax. It is a contribution paid by the employer. In addition, it was recognised that, for employers that were already paying that contribution or more, they were not going to be required to pay it on top.

Since the recent announcements, employees will, I acknowledge, be expected to contribute up to three per cent of their own income over time towards their superannuation entitlements, and the government will match those contributions. But you cannot class the employees' own contributions as income tax. They have never been classed as that in the history of this country, whether they were paid by agreement of the employee into a private superannuation fund or whether they were paid under legislation.

But what do we get from you? You argue across the chamber here with Senator Sherry that, because the tax office will collect this three per cent if some employers do not pay it, it is a tax. That is there as a safety net, a guarantee. It is there to ensure that the contributions will be paid, with the tax office acting as a collection agency for it. It will only be applied to those employers who fail to meet their obligations under the award and under the legislation.

If the decision had not been taken in 1983 to establish superannuation entitlements, if the coalition sitting opposite had managed to retain government—thank God they did not—if superannuation had not continued to be improved and expanded upon since then, I wonder what the situation would be like today for any government endeavouring to look at how you fund future retirement incomes and how you develop appropriate savings and investment bases.

Senator Short, in his speech, said that people will not benefit from this until the year 2040, or words to that effect. That is absolute nonsense. There are many workers now who, since the introduction of superannuation back in the 1980s, have already built decent entitlements in those superannuation funds. That is an entitlement they would not have had if you and your lot had managed to hang on to government back in 1983.

They are a long way in front already compared with the situation they might otherwise have been in—no superannuation guarantee, no superannuation productivity funds—and the situation will continue to improve in the years to come. I am confident that the Australian electorate, when they look at this development in superannuation and at what it means for them in terms of retirement income and establishing an investment base and a savings base for this country, will re-elect a Labor government at the next election.

I want to turn briefly to some other important aspects of this matter because Senator Panizza wandered all around the place like a lost sheep back on one of his farms. We can talk about tax and superannuation but we have to look at the whole package, we have to look at the social wage.And what has been the position? For low income earners, it was this government that increased the tax-free threshold. It has been boosted by more than a third when you take into account the low income rebate.

It was this government that reduced the top marginal rate of tax from 60 per cent to somewhere around 42 per cent. It was this government that reduced the marginal rate of tax for middle income earners from 46 per cent to 34 per cent. It was this government that reduced the bottom marginal tax rate from 30 per cent to 20 per cent. It is this government, through the Accord processes, that has continued to deliver tax improvements for the work force throughout the last 12 years, soon to be 13 years and soon to be 16 years.

It was this government that established the family allowance supplement. I can recall when that was negotiated as part of the Accord process. At the time the family allowance supplement was negotiated, it was said to be the equivalent of giving low income workers a $100 a week wage rise. That is what the family allowance supplement meant.

TALK.START.PARA: —You took away the spouse rebate. You took it out of one pocket into another.
—It was $2 a week; that's what it was.

—Senator Calvert and Senator Panizza, you do not even understand what you are talking about. You are quite clearly confusing the parenting allowance changes, which were announced recently, with the family allowance supplement, which was introduced for low income workers quite a number of years ago.

PARA.TAB: For your own information, Senator Panizza, we have a family allowance payment and there is a family allowance supplement for low income workers. As I said, it was the equivalent at that time of a $100 a week wage increase—something that would have taken years for low income workers to achieve. So, when you look at income tax rates and when you look at wage rates, do not leave out the family allowance supplement for low income workers.

It was this government that established access to decent child care and child-care assistance. It was this government that retained Medicare, which is something that you would have destroyed and something that the people of this country will always support—that is, a universal health service. It was this government that improved access to education and training.

It was this government that actually had to take steps to force employers in this country to contribute something towards training their own employees because of their abysmal, pathetic record over many years in terms of how much they invested in the training of their own work force. I am glad to say that that is something which is improving immeasurably these days as employers and workers recognise that you have to develop a skills base, improve access to vocational training and increase education retention rates, as this government has done.

That is what the future of Australians is about. That is what this government is doing in terms of promoting improved employment prospects and improving the overall lot of particularly the low paid and middle income earners.

Finally, I will just refer to the FBT. Why was the fringe benefits tax introduced? It was introduced to catch all of those tax lurks and tax avoidance, or tax evasion, schemes that existed. People who had access to high paid jobs could get their income by means other than through normal salaries or wages. They had access to cars, holidays, paid school fees, entertainment expenses and credit cards. That is why the FBT was brought in. Wasn't it such a surprise when we actually saw the government's predictions in relation to the amount collected from FBT doubling and trebling in reality because of this tax minimisation that had been going on, particularly for people at the very high end of the wages and salaries spectrum?

In conclusion, I have not heard so much hypocrisy here than I have heard from the opposition this afternoon. As I said, when we look at tax and income tax rates the figures speak for themselves. As the Treasurer said, it is very clear that we are one of the lowest income tax countries in the world. In addition to that we have some of the world's best policies in terms of social security, education and training opportunities, and superannuation and retirement incomes. I remind the Senate that it was this government which stopped the tax avoidance industry, which was, as I said, the only industry that was going forward at the time the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was the Treasurer of this country. It is something I am sure is never likely to happen again.

TALK.START.PARA: —So badly have I succumbed to the Canberra flu that I was not going to proceed with involvement in this debate. But, as I lay on my office sofa an hour or so ago, what happened? Up on the screen came Senator Sherry with half an hour of absolute rambling nonsense. It made me so angry that any thoughts of withdrawing from this debate quickly dissipated and I just had to come down to show what falsehoods Senator Sherry has purported this afternoon in this debate on the motion of my colleague Senator Short relating to the quite accurate findings of a study by Access Economics regarding the fact that over the last decade—a decade that the government claims has been one of tax reform—average income earners in Australia have paid a higher proportion of their income in tax than they previously did. That is the simple fact.

PARA.TAB: Not only is that a fact; the other fact is that, contrary to the government's continuing claims, Australians are not at the low tax end of residents of OECD countries. They are, as the Access Economics report shows, in the middle to higher range of that when we take into account all of the matters that ought to be taken into account in any comparative assessment of taxation rates. In other words, when we are comparing apples with apples we are a high tax country by comparison with our OECD compatriots, and even more so when we look at our near neighbours—those countries with whom we are competing and trading in this region.

But this government simply does not want to listen to that advice. It is not the first time that this sort of study has been done to provide these facts to the government. Earlier this year a report by the accountants Coopers and Lybrand reached exactly the same conclusion—that we are in fact now paying a higher rate of tax than we were when the so-called tax reform process started 10 years ago. I wish to simply refer to that report for a few moments.

The report clearly makes the point that people on average weekly earnings are now paying a higher proportion of their income in tax than they were 10 years ago. According to the Coopers and Lybrand report, in September 1983 a single male on average weekly ordinary time earnings would have paid $4,346 of his $18,824 salary in tax, or 23.08 per cent, but by August 1994 that same person would have been earning $34,310 and paying $8,167 in tax, or 23.8 per cent—a higher proportion of his income now than before the tax reform process began.

One of the other major shortcomings of the Australian tax system relates to what Senator Sherry and Senator Forshaw said. They claimed that the government has cut back the top marginal tax rate from 60c in the dollar to 50c in the dollar. That may well be the case, but they ignore the fact that that top marginal rate cuts in at a much lower level of income than it does in comparable countries.
