In the United States, for example, the top marginal tax rate does not cut in until people are earning an income of $250,000, which is equivalent to about $A336,000. In Germany, the top marginal tax rate cuts in at 120,000 deutschmarks, which is about $A105,000. In Japan it cuts in at Y20 million, which is about $A272,000. Yet here in Australia the top marginal tax rate cuts in at a meagre $50,000. While the government may well claim that it has cut the top marginal rate, the fact is that it cuts in at a much lower income level. Therefore the overall tax burden, even at that income level, is much greater than it has been in the past. So, as that Coopers and Lybrand study of earlier this year shows, we are paying more tax now than we were 10 years ago.

There was also a study done by Terry Larkin and Terry Dwyer in August of this year, as part of the Business Council of Australia 210 project on refocusing micro-economic reform. They reinforce in their study the evidence and the conclusions reached by the Access Economics study, which is the subject of this motion moved by Senator Short. In that study they made the point that the claim that by OECD standards Australia is a low taxed country with only the United States and Turkey taxing less as a share of GDP is one that cannot be taken seriously. We are saying in this debate that that claim is false. It does not include all of the items that ought to be included in the tax basket in determining what the real rate of tax is. What Larkin and Dwyer say is that, even if you accept for a moment the false claim that we are a low taxed country, our tax ought to be much lower than it is, particularly because of our demographic structure. We have a much more favourable demographic structure than many of the other countries in the OECD in terms of the capacity to raise revenue from individuals. Therefore, we ought to have a low tax structure, but we do not.

They also make the point, which is the key to the Access Economics study, that in order to get a meaningful comparison you have to take into account what is provided publicly as against what is provided privately in some other countries. This is where we come to the issue of superannuation. The government continues to deny that the superannuation guarantee charge ought to be included in assessing the levels of taxation. It is included in a number of other countries because it is collected publicly and paid publicly. They argue that because here the ultimate benefit is paid through private schemes you should not include its collection as an item of tax. The simple fact is that it is providing an item that in some other countries is provided publicly. Therefore, if you are going to compare apples with apples, it ought to be included in any assessment of Australia's tax rate.

The other factor that has to be considered is that it significantly reduces the disposable after tax income, because it is removed at the same time as income tax is removed from a person's income. So, quite clearly, it is fair and reasonable when comparing tax rates between countries to include that super guarantee charge within the tax structure. When you make that comparison, you reach the conclusion that by comparison with our OECD fellow member countries we are not at all a low taxed country.

In support of the critique which Access Economics, and Mr Geoff Carmody in particular, gave of the present tax structure, reference was made to the 1985 draft white paper, which identified deficiencies in our tax structure which, a decade later, still have not been rectified. We have had 13 years of this Labor government and we have had 10 years of them having been made aware that we have a deficient tax system that is in need of reform. These deficiencies have yet to be rectified.

It is probably fair to say that the tax burden people have experienced under this Labor government is so much a part of their daily lives, after being bashed around the hip-pocket by this government with year after year and election after election of broken promises with regard to taxation, that it becomes something of a ho-hum issue. There is a revolt out there in the community against this government's tax policies, particularly amongst small business, who, after all, provide 45 per cent of the jobs in this community. People have come to the conclusion that enough is enough as far as taxation is concerned. That is why they are listening to the sort of evidence that Mr Geoff Carmody, through the Access Economics study, is providing to them.

One of the major points the Access Economics study makes is that, as I said a few moments ago, comparisons with other OECD countries which put Australia in the low tax category ignore the impact on taxation levels of compulsory superannuation. Also, the tax cuts which have been realised over that period—I emphasise `have been realised' as distinguished from the l-a-w tax cuts, which were never realised and will never be realised—generated no net gains for ordinary Australians. So even where there has been some tax reform, limited as it may be, there has been no gain for ordinary Australians. In fact, it is only for those on higher taxable incomes that the amount of average income tax plus superannuation guarantee charge is actually lower in 1994-95 than it was in 1984-85.

The rich have got richer under this government's tax policies. It is the high income earners that have benefited from the changes made to our tax structure, rather than the low and average income earners in our community. This has occurred despite the warnings given in that 1985 draft white paper that if nothing was done the result would be not an acceptable outcome. That forecast was realised in 1987-88 and exceeded in 1988-89, some six years ago. Yet very little has been done to change that unsatisfactory tax structure.

We also heard comment from Senator Sherry with regard to the fringe benefits tax and what a marvellous tax reform the introduction of the fringe benefits tax was, but even there the government has mucked up because the way in which the government has applied the fringe benefits tax, which certainly does have legitimacy and does have its place in a proper tax structure, is flawed in the extreme. For employees earning less than $50,000 a year, an FBT rate of 48.4 per cent combined with the grossing up aspect is far too high.

The reality is, of course, that there is no benefit now in an employer providing fringe benefits to an employee who earns less than that because the cost through fringe benefits tax is greater than through the ordinary income tax rate being applied if those benefits are cashed out and paid to the employee as normal cash wages. Because of that, that is exactly what is happening. Fringe benefits are in fact being cashed out and paid as part of normal wages and salaries. To that extent, fringe benefits are being removed from employees with an income of less than $50,000 a year.

Despite that, we see massive increases in the revenue being earned from the fringe benefits tax, which means that legitimate business expenses and legitimate facilities being provided for employees to undertake their work requirements are being taxed as a fringe benefit. That is quite the contrary of a legitimate fringe benefits tax scheme. Yet the government refuses to recognise that. It refuses to recognise that applying the fringe benefits tax to legitimate business expenses is a clear violation of income tax principles. We heard Senator Sherry in here defending the way his government is administering the fringe benefits tax.

We have tried to point out to the government time and time again their violation of the income tax principles but, as I said, they just do not want to listen. They have attacked this Access Economics report quite erroneously and quite illegitimately. In the 10 years since the release of the government's 1985 draft white paper, we have seen a highly regulated tax regime develop under this government which is complex, and the burden of the cost of compliance has affected businesses severely and detrimentally. Therefore, of course, our entire economy has been detrimentally affected.

The Australian Tax Research Foundation study found that personal income taxpayers faced a compliance cost equivalent to 9.3 per cent of tax revenue. This compared with compliance costs in Canada of 2.5 per cent; in the United Kingdom of 3.6 per cent; and in the USA of five to seven per cent. For 96 per cent of Australian companies, compliance costs exceeded the amount remitted in income tax. What nonsense that is! What sort of tax structure and tax administration must we have in this country when, for 96 per cent of Australian companies, compliance costs exceed the amount of money remitted in income tax.

I will come back to the fringe benefits tax issue—and nowhere is this tax issue more relevant than in relation to fringe benefits. This area has become a huge source of revenue for the government but, as I said, it is a largely illegitimate source of revenue. When it was legitimate, it forced businesses to cash out those benefits—now it is taxing legitimate business expenses.

The estimated revenue in 1995-96 from the fringe benefits tax is in excess of $2.8 billion. Compliance costs are estimated to be 10.6 per cent or $300 million for this financial year. That is a remarkable contrast to the revenue of $535 million when the fringe benefits tax was first introduced nine years ago.

In 1990, the then Treasurer and current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced the initiation of a tax simplification study to examine the complexities of the tax system. We have never seen that study, and we might well ask what has happened to it. Is this another one of the broken promises made by the former Treasurer?

Tax complexity and the administrative burden placed on businesses in order to comply raise business costs, and this government persists in failing to do anything about it. Of course, those higher costs mean lower competitiveness, lower job growth and, therefore, fewer jobs and higher prices. So, again, the whole nation loses out.

What is worse still is that the government attempted to hoodwink businesses in order to win the 1993 election. The government announced and delivered a tax rate of 33c, but only two years later this was reneged upon and the tax rate was again increased to 36c. The government's election promise was made under the guise of aligning our company tax rates with those of our trading competitors in the Asian region. It is worth noting that in Singapore, the company tax rate is 27c; in Thailand, it is 30c; and, in Malaysia, it is 34c. Yet here companies are faced with a company tax rate of 36c in the dollar. By combining that with the introduction of quarterly tax instalments, the effect will be an increase in collections to a level higher than when the company tax rate was 39c.

The government's claim that Australians are better off as far as tax is concerned is quite clearly false. The study undertaken by Access Economics, which reinforces earlier work done by Coopers and Lybrand and Larkin and Dwyer, clearly shows that we are a high taxed country in comparison with our OECD partners. Even more so, Australia is a high taxed country when compared to the countries I mentioned a few moments ago in relation to not only company tax but also personal income tax. Countries like Singapore, Malaysia and Hong Kong have rates around 15 per cent.

Senator Sherry said that they have a social security system that is much worse than ours. They have a culture where families look after their own. They have the resources to look after their own because it is not all ripped off them in tax. People are left with more of their own resources, therefore they can fulfil their responsibilities in those areas. Because of their low tax rates, countries like Singapore and Hong Kong have generated much stronger economic growth and they actually have higher average weekly earnings than we have in Australia.

They are better off. They have lower tax and they can look after their own families when they are in need. They do not have this churning process where money is ripped off them in tax and given back to them by the government after a lot of it sticks to the government's fingers due to administrative costs. What we need in this country is genuine reform. We need to get the tax rates down significantly lower than they are now. It will not happen under this government, but it certainly will happen when we have a change of government after the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to make a contribution to this general business debate on the lie that is the tax reform agenda of the Keating government. There is nothing as transparent as the law tax promises of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). He has not failed the Australian people more than in the area of tax reform.

PARA.TAB: Ten years ago the Hawke-Keating government claimed a new era for taxation policy in Australia. A much publicised tax summit was held to listen to all sections of the community. I wish to hell the Prime Minister had done something about some of the things that were being recommended at the time.

As Senator Short says in his motion, the aim of then Treasurer Keating was to relieve the tax burden from middle Australia. Other speakers have pointed out just how badly off middle Australia is at the moment. The Labor government's income tax policies have only benefited the high income earners on about 2 1/2 times the average weekly earnings.

One group that Mr Keating has forgotten about entirely is the rural sector. While he lauds a drought policy that he claims is the most innovative and far reaching of any in recent history, the fact remains that rural Australia, if it were ever middle Australia, is now well and truly in the low income bracket, driven there by high taxes and inappropriate government policies that have prevented them being able to survive adverse weather and market conditions.

Tax collection has been the shining glory of the taxing Hawke and Keating governments—the one crowning achievement in a litany of failures. I should not need to remind the Senate that the government that promised tax relief for middle Australia has increased sales tax from $3.4 billion in 1982 to $14.1 billion in 1995.

In the most recent budget, sales tax was once again lifted by one per cent across the whole range of goods that attract sales tax. Some, like the tax on recycled paper, were added for good measure. The Labor Party wanted to slug the building industry through a tax on building materials and were only stopped by the coalition. This is indicative of the insensitivity of this out of touch of government. Total individual tax has been estimated to have increased 136 per cent since 1983, company tax a massive 370 per cent and indirect tax 149 per cent. Tax increases are set to outstrip the rate of inflation by an average of 9.8 per cent per annum over the 13 long years the Labor Party has been in office.

The cost of collecting the tax is also amongst the highest in the world. In 1994 the cost of collecting tax was about $1.1 billion and it involved a permanent staff of something like 18,000 people. The tax legislation is now spread over 2,000 pages and requires frequent updates for accountants so that they can keep up with the myriad of changes—and this from a government that promised a simplified tax system.

What have they done with petrol, the lifeblood of middle Australia? For a start, they put an extra tax on leaded fuel. But at the same time, as was pointed out in a Sydney Morning Herald article headed `ALP's petrol tax hits the true believers':
Figures from the NSW Roads and Traffic Authority, released exclusively to the Herald, highlight the way in which the Federal Government's new petrol tax will hit the poor.

SPEECH.PARA: So they are hitting the poor all the time, hitting the middle income earners and letting the rich people get off scot-free. That article went on to state:

PARA.TAB: The regressive nature of the tax emerges most starkly from the data which shows that cars using leaded petrol are concentrated in poorer regions while wealthier areas have the largest number of unleaded vehicles.

SPEECH.PARA: It was the middle and poorer sections that were hit hardest by the leaded fuel tax. We see it in that article, and we know that it has been the case—and they are the people who drive around in country areas.

PARA.TAB: In 1984 fuel tax earned less than $2.4 billion for the tax coffers; this financial year it will reap more than $10 billion out of the pockets of every person who drives a car. But for all the tax collections they got from fuel the money certainly did not go on roads. Of $9.7 billion that the government collected from petrol excise last year, only $820 million was allocated to federal road funding. In fact, since 1983 the excise collected by Labor from petrol has increased by almost 700 per cent.

I will quote from the recent National Party publication entitled, This is as good as it gets. That of course is Paul Keating's quote on small business; he said `This is as good as it gets'. He also said on Brisbane radio, on 11 May 1995, `It will never get any better.' I guarantee that it will not get any better under this Labor government. But it was stated in that National Party publication:

SPEECH.PARA: In 1995, government taxes and charges now make up over half the cost of a tank of petrol.
I repeat: half the cost of a tank of petrol. At the moment, every time any person out there fills the tank of their car, they are paying half of it to the Labor government.

PARA.TAB: How is this making life easier for Australians, much less making it easier for middle Australians? It is not making life easier at all. The same publication I have just quoted from has pages devoted to the litany of taxes that the average Australian has been charged by this government—a government that promised to reduce taxation and simplify the tax regime, but instead has used the ordinary Australian to pay for the growing number of unemployed and the successive failure of government initiatives, such as the nearly $100 million it has given to the trade union movement; the absurdly naive superannuation advertising campaign that cost $12 million and which is so misleading that I am surprised the Trade Practices Commission has not objected to the trees which at the moment are growing on television but not growing as money in people's pockets; the money spent it has spent on consultancies for just about anyone and anything; and let us not forget the $10,000 a day that at the moment is being spent in Western Australia for the legal fees of the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence).

My particular area of concern is for rural Australians. Everyone says, `Okay, but they're not making enough income to be paying tax.' However, the point is that when people in country areas travel in motorcars, they have to pay the fuel taxes, they have pay the wholesale taxes. Every time there is transport on or off a farm, or to a country town or city, or away from a country town or city, there are the wholesale taxes on the cost of transport. There are the fringe benefits taxes, which have already been mentioned by other speakers here tonight. Then of course you have a capital gains tax. The poor old farmer who has actually bought a farm since 1985 will be slugged with a capital gains tax. If he leaves the property to his sons and they sell it at some stage down the track, even if the property was bought 100 years ago, they will be paying a capital gains tax. So as far as that is concerned, the government will be whipping more money out of the community as well.

What did the Economic Planning Advisory Council say? They published a report—and this is the government's own Economic Planning Advisory Council—which shows that Australians face the second highest level of taxes on savings in the developed world. They also showed that, compared with the newly industrialised Asian economies—our biggest future trade prospects in that area and our competitors—we are highly taxed overall. We are highly taxed. The government has no commitment, concern or worry about where we are going in the future. Farm profitability is not great. Farmers and people who live in country areas, whether they are paying income tax or not, are still paying these big taxes to the government the whole time.

I will finish with a little story. Once upon a time there was a little red hen who scratched around and uncovered some grains of wheat. She called to her farmyard neighbours, `If we plant this wheat, we will soon have some fine bread to eat. Who will help me?' `Too busy', said the cow. `Not me', said the pig. `Where is the environmental impact study?' said the duck. `Wrong union', said the horse. `Then I will plant it myself', said the little red hen. The wheat grew and ripened into golden grain. `Who will help me harvest the wheat?' said the little red hen. `I would lose my unemployment benefit', said the duck. `Not in my classification', said the pig. `I am filling in forms', said the cow. `I am on retraining', said the horse.

So the little red hen reaped the wheat and then she baked five lovely loaves of bread, which she held up for the neighbours to see. `I want some', said the duck. `I demand my share', said the horse. `No', said the little red hen. `I did all the work and I will keep the bread'. `Profiteer', shouted the cow. `Capitalist', screamed the pig. `Equal rights', yelled the duck. `Where is the workers' share?' cried the horse. And they painted picket signs and paraded around the little hen singing, `We shall overcome.'

And they did. For when the farmer came to investigate the commotion he said, `You must not be greedy, little red hen. Look at the underprivileged duck, the pig, the cow and the horse. You are guilty of making second-class citizens of them'. `But I produced the bread myself'. `Exactly', said the farmer. `That is the way the free market enterprise system works. You are free to work as hard as you like. If you are on a socialist farm you would have to give all the bread up. Here, you can keep one loaf and share the rest among your needy neighbours'. They all lived happily every after, including the little red hen. But her neighbours wondered why she never baked any bread any more.

That is how the country people are thinking about this Keating Labor government. I wonder how many farmers think that way today. I wonder how many people who pay taxes which they get no benefit from are saying `All those regressive taxes we have are slamming us back into mediocrity. Australia is not competing with the rest of the world.' I leave you with that thought. I congratulate Senator Short on bringing up this motion. The Labor Party government and, in particular, Mr Keating as the former Treasurer and as the current Prime Minister, have driven us into a tax situation where we have no future under the government that is in power. The quicker it gets out of office the better. The quicker we get proper tax reform in Australia the better off we will all be.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Capital and External Territories Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Senator Schacht:

TALK.START.PARA: —When this report was presented I did not get an opportunity to speak to it. I shall not take up much time dealing with it now other than to say that I was pleased that the government accepted the recommendations of the committee. The King George V Memorial originally was in front of the old Parliament House and many years ago was moved to the Senate side, in front of the building. It has had scaffolding and things like that around it now for some time because of the poor condition it is in, caused mainly by the growth of tree roots nearby. It clearly needs to be repaired.

PARA.TAB: The government has agreed with our recommendations that the two poplar trees causing the problem should be removed, that the memorial should be repaired and that it should remain where it is. We were not specifically asked, I think, to talk about its siting but we were very conscious at the time of the inquiry that there was talk about it being moved. Our representation is that it remain on the site that it is on and where it has been for most of its time.

The government put in the reservation about repairing it subject to cost and availability of money. I understand that, but would hope that the restoration of the statue be given a high priority with the funds available for work in the parliamentary triangle. As it is at present, with scaffolding and fencing around it, it really does detract from the parliamentary building down there. The sooner it is restored, the sooner the parliamentary triangle will look less like a work site and more like it ought to look. I speak only to say that I am pleased with the government's response to the report. I hope it can have a reasonable priority within the general maintenance of the parliamentary triangle.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Senator Panizza:
That the Senate take note of the report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report entitled Regulation of Computer On-Line Services: Part 1, which was tabled in the Senate last Tuesday. The report deals with what used to be called bulletin board services or what are now called on-line services. The fact of the change of the name is one indication of a field that is changing with incredible speed.

PARA.TAB: The report has in its title `part 1'. The reason for this is that we are developing in our country a huge problem on the dark side of the information superhighway, which is going to develop very rapidly over the rest of this decade. The committee is proposing at this stage to keep a watching brief on what is happening. So this report is only part 1 of what we see as a series. Indeed, the committee agreed in the last week or so to move to part 2, which will be a more wide-ranging inquiry than the subject of this report, which is a one-day seminar we held in Canberra to inform the committee on the various issues that are coming out of the development of on-line services.

The development is an offshoot of the Internet and it is something which, broadly, has tremendous benefits for the future development of our society. You will find with many of these on-line services that there are things such as parent interest groups for ailing children with leukaemia. There are historical societies or common groups who want to look at countries such as Ireland and share their common cultural heritage. There are poetry clubs. There are information exchanges on a whole range of various interest groups. There is product information. There is also the possibility of the selling of information.

I noted that, on radio this morning, the Labor Party have a page on this on-line service. They thought this was a marvellous thing. Of course, the Liberal Party also have a site on the Internet and people can access that as well. So there are all sorts of interesting things that are available on the Internet. These are good for community and for commerce.

These sorts of services are growing incredibly rapidly. There are 50 million users worldwide of Internet services at the moment—750,000 people in Australia, which is the fourth highest in the world. There is an ability to move across the world at the speed of light with these services, jumping from site to site. The rate of growth of home pages—that is, people who are actually locating themselves, their organisation or their particular service on the Internet—is growing at 20 per cent a month. Let me repeat that: 20 per cent a month.

What we have here is an exploding situation and one that has enormous implications for our society. People can access a very wide range of information—calling down whole libraries of information from around the world. Entertainment and movies are possible through this medium. You can study for a degree in Boston. You can extend the range of educational services. Even the simple, humble letter becomes so much more accessible on services like the E-mail. All this is absolutely terrific, and this is the light side of the net.

But there is a dark side of the Internet. On the same online services you can find hard core pornography that is far worse than anything you can find in a sex shop. I am sure senators will remember the case from the newspapers that dealt with instructions on how to conduct a rape. There are lessons on how to construct bombs. Paedophilia rings have sprung up. There was a case at the University of Birmingham, which was the main source of this information, and there were arrests there.

All these things that I have just mentioned are illegal activities in our society. However, we have this new medium which puts a whole new dimension on this old range of activities. One of the great problems that we face is that the sources are not necessarily in Australia. It is a world-wide problem. Children sitting in their bedrooms can access material out of the centre of China, Russia, the United States or the Bahamas. There is an international casino out of the Bahamas where people can use their credit cards to gamble away as much money as they like.

We are moving into a totally new era of international commerce where the old boundaries are not applicable any more. Geoffrey Huston, Secretary of the Internet Society of Virginia USA, spoke at a Canberra seminar about the problem of much of the material from overseas. He warned about the inadequacy of Australia's regulatory framework to control this problem. The sinister misuse of Internet resources was reported by Reuters newsagency on 13 September 1995 where professor Harold Thimbley, a computer expert, likened the Internet to an electronic red district distributing violent pornography and helping the organisation of paedophile rings.
As legislators we have to grapple with this issue. It is probably one of the most difficult issues we will ever have to grapple with because of our lack of control over what is happening.

The Community Standards Committee first came across this problem when we were looking into video games. We spoke to children at high school and we started to learn about how they were accessing material from the Internet. We learned of the difficulties that it was creating for parents in the supervision of that sort of activity. The committee decided to have a closer look at this matter this year and, in particular, to look at what governments are doing about it.

It was a federal-state effort and the Attorneys-General came up with an options paper in August last year which set out five options: the first was to do nothing; the second was to apply the full classification system of the OFLC; the third was to develop and adopt the guidelines of the online services community; the fourth was partial classification on bulletin boards; and the fifth option was an extension of that classification to include legal obligations to take reasonable steps with restricted category material under the OFLC level of classification.

That seemed to be the preferable option and that is the way that the government initially seemed to be going. Unfortunately, when they brought down their next report in July 1995, following considerable criticism from the industry which basically wanted to be left alone, they came down more on a self-regulatory proposal with some educational back-up and with some legal sanctions which one would suspect are already there through the criminal code. It is incredibly difficult to undertake any effective education that will stop children accessing and looking at this material. Legal sanctions are very difficult to enforce. We also have this self-regulatory scheme which is an extension of the OFLC's other work on film and video.

We are in a different area. We are in an area that is far more complex and difficult to control than videos and film. The committee is having some doubts about the likely effectiveness of the government's approach. That is why we have decided to have a wider inquiry—to try to find out in particular what international controls can be put in place. The United States—the site of a lot of this material—has already moved a lot further than Australia in this area.

There is also the possibility of technological controls. There are ways of putting systems into computer software which screen out words and certain material. We need a combination of those things. We need education; we need technological controls over the material; we need international regulations. I believe what we need is probably a much stronger code. I would advocate to the government at this point that it should go back to its original option and try to come up with a tougher system. We will be observing what governments do over the next few years. We will bring forward to this Senate further recommendations on what they should do with the dark side of the net.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to report to the Senate on my protest against French nuclear testing in Mururoa and my consequent arrest by the French authorities on that atoll. I want to say right at the outset that I consider myself to have been very fortunate to be the federal parliamentarian who was chosen by Greenpeace to be able to take my protest into the 12-mile zone at Mururoa and onto the atoll. There are a large number of parliamentarians in Australia who would have been very happy to do exactly the same thing that I did.

PARA.TAB: One of the best things that came out of all this was the enormous unity across this country from parliamentarians of all political parties against the actions of the French in Mururoa. I would particularly like to mention the member for Adelaide, Trish Worth, who guaranteed to the organising committee for the protest at Papeete that there would be bipartisan support. She has held to that agreement all the way through. She has been able to get strong support and acquiescence from her leader and also from the spokesman for foreign affairs. That has to be appreciated by all of the people who are involved in the protest.

I am also particularly grateful to Greenpeace. It was only their organisation and the resources which they were able to put at our disposal which allowed the nine parliamentarians to board the transfer vessel in Papeete and make the four-day trip to the 12-mile zone around Mururoa and to eventually board the vessel in which we were able to penetrate the 12-mile zone and make our protest.

I would also like tonight to briefly set the record straight on some of the lies which the French have been telling about our mission and protest. It was not true that, at the time we were arrested, the eight parliamentarians—the two Australians, two Italians, the Japanese, the Luxembourger and the lady from Sweden—were in any way sick. We were in extremely good spirits and health. We had been through a very difficult and arduous voyage to get to Mururoa. We had spent four days sailing just to get to the 12-mile zone. Once we got there, we had to endure a force 10 gale for 12 hours before conditions moderated sufficiently for us to transfer to another boat and get into the 12-mile zone. But, at the time we were picked up, we were all in extremely good health and spirits. It is just a function of the French propaganda machine to suggest that we were in any other state or that they in any other way rescued us.

We did not appreciate after our interrogation that the purpose for their taking us to a military hospital was purely propaganda. We believed at the time that it was a convenient place to put us under guard and store us for the night. Again, I have to nail a lie there.

It is also not true, as the French authorities have tried to pretend, that the parliamentarians were not charged. What really happened is that, once we were transferred to Mururoa atoll by the French frigate, we were taken immediately to the central military police station, where we were interrogated for about five hours. We were each given statements to sign in which we admitted that we had broken French law and various other things. For my part, I certainly signed my statement because there was absolutely no point in denying that the very purpose I had gone to Mururoa was to break the 12-mile zone. I could not see any point in arguing about that.

But, at the same time as the French seek to say that no legal action is being taken against us, the French ambassador to Italy has said about my two Italian colleagues on that boat that, first of all, they put themselves in great physical danger and, secondly, that they put themselves in great legal danger. It is the case that the Italian press is now running a story that the court case will be brought on in about a month. Both versions of the events cannot be true. I put it to the Senate that it is the French propaganda machine which is spreading these stories.

Another untruth was told to me by Colonel Gallandt, who is in charge of the French legionnaires that form the main military presence at Mururoa. He said to me and the journalists who were present while we were at the atoll that the two Greenpeace activists who preceded us into the 12-mile zone by a matter of a couple of days were sitting next to him at the time of the first test observing the event. The truth of the matter is that they were both in separate gaol cells. They had not been told that the test was about to occur, which meant that they were thrown from their beds in the gaol cells with the seismic reaction that followed.

It is also not true, as the French would have the world believe, that Greenpeace is about to fold and that it is incapable of continuing its very effective protest at the 12-mile zone. Greenpeace had another four boats join the peace flotilla while we were at the atoll. They now have in place their supply lines, which will enable them to continue the protest for as long as the French insist upon this madness of nuclear testing. The world owes Greenpeace a considerable degree of gratitude for the resources, time and bravery that they have demonstrated in maintaining this protest.

In fact, if there was a danger to the parliamentarians, it really came at the hands of the French themselves. They chose to transfer us from the boat upon which we were arrested and seized to the French warship Tapageuse in extremely rough seas. It is an absolute miracle that nobody was hurt in the transfer between those two vessels. Inflatable craft like Zodiacs move very quickly in a heavy sea. They can move, as I observed, 10 metres at the drop of a hat when people are trying to grab on to rope ladders and so on to get aboard a mother ship. That was the real risk as far as the parliamentarians were concerned. The French are lucky that no-one was really hurt.

In closing, many very positive outcomes have come from the action which I was privileged to participate in. I have said elsewhere, and I will say it again, that I believe the government is doing all it can in the normal diplomatic international channels to press the case against the French. What we were able to do as parliamentarians demonstrates that there is still scope for personal action. It is still possible for parliamentarians, particularly given their position and status within the domestic and international communities, to take personal actions which make a difference and go beyond the power of any individual country, however small or large it may be. In that respect, it was particularly significant that two Japanese parliamentarians were prepared to come into the 12-mile zone with us.

As far as I am aware, it has never been the case that Japanese parliamentarians have participated in a protest like this outside Japan. I think it is significant for all the countries of the Pacific who lack the enormous economic power of the Japanese. I am particularly grateful to my Japanese colleagues. It is also a first for Greenpeace to facilitate a protest like this by parliamentarians. I emphasise that Greenpeace put no preconditions whatever on our participation and had no role whatever in the joint statements that we made. We were free to carry on our project as we saw fit. Again, I think that was a worthwhile thing.

As a result of our protest and as a result of the very hard work put in by other parliamentarians who went to Papeete, an international organisation of parliamentarians for a nuclear free world will be formed. I think that sort of cooperation is an important thing in this world. It shows that, despite the things which may bitterly divide us in this place and in other parliaments around the world, we can come together on something which is clearly for the benefit of future generations and beyond the normal forms of ideological argument.

I also think that the protest which we were able to mount was a useful signal, if not to the pigheadedness of the Chirac government, at least to other countries around the world—China, India, Pakistan, Iraq and other countries which are thought to be possessing nuclear weapons and may seek to test them. I think it has been made very clear by the international condemnation that that sort of activity is absolutely unacceptable. I believe we are having a great impact upon the French, nevertheless. I saw President Jacques Chirac on French television once I returned to Papeete. He spent 15 minutes of his interview criticising the Australian and the New Zealand actions in the South Pacific. Given our relative size to France and given that he seeks to talk about France as an imperial and world power, it must be clear that for him to spend so much time criticising us, we must be doing something right.

I will say in closing that what we have been able to demonstrate is that a new principle is about in leadership in the world. These days people are looking for leadership in the form of ideas and in the form of determination to see those ideas through for the benefit of the people that parliamentarians represent. They are not looking for leadership by force and they are not looking for leadership by aggression, which is what the French are demonstrating. I believe they will continue to be criticised for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —North Forest Products has announced with great fanfare that it is seeking a licence to export an extra 450,000 tonnes of woodchips annually from northern Tasmania. No doubt realising the very high level of community opposition to mining our native forests for woodchips, North Forest Products has tried to legitimise the application with a number of claims asserting that the proposal is good for the economy. The Australian Democrats are dismayed at this application and we oppose it for economic as well as environmental reasons. North Forest Products is claiming that the proposal will signal a massive boost for the Burnie region in the form of $40 million of new investment and 450 jobs.

PARA.TAB: A few days ago the World Bank announced that each Australian is a millionaire. This is a figure which is derived from the estimated total value—the capital value—of our resources. It is the value of the farm which some would want to sell. It is precisely because our forests have intrinsic economic value that we need to be very careful in our assessment as to whether the claim to $27 million in annual economic benefit to be derived from the conversion of native forest trees to newsprint is economically sensible. In making such an assessment, we must ensure that we factor in the timber value—both current and forgone—of the myrtle and other minor species furniture timbers that will inevitably be chipped if the practices of the present are followed.

I have asked questions about the mechanisms in place which monitor the quality of the timber sent to the chipper. The answer has given me no confidence that the kind of practices that I have photographic evidence about are not standard practice. A letter I received only a couple of days ago from a small sawmill in Tasmania again raises complaints about the prevalence of pulping valuable timber. This is timber which could be used in Queensland tourist developments, for example, to replace timber that is currently being imported from Germany.

We also need to ensure that the financing costs are properly included in the assessment. Strange as it may sound, it seems that we really do not know the true net income from woodchipping. Some time ago in this place, I asked the minister some questions about this in the hope that he would be able to demonstrate that in economic terms the costs and benefits of woodchip exports have really been properly analysed. I asked the minister what was the total value of capital equipment imported and used in the export woodchipping industry. The answer was that we don't even compile the data. I also asked the cost of overseas borrowing to finance the purchase of capital equipment used in the industry. That data is not collected either.

In other words, no-one has thought it necessary to analyse the cost to the nation of the imported log trucks and equipment used, against the income derived. Yet we are constantly told by the industry, by such companies as North Forest Products, that woodchipping has an economic benefit. In this case we are fed the precise figure of $27 million, but nobody knows how to calculate it. According to North's proposal the plan is to clearfell—how much land is not stated—but enough on which to plant 5.5 million trees each year on its freehold land.

There are two questions to be considered here. Irrespective of the fact that the trees are owned by the company, is the claimed annual income of $27 million enough for the resource which will be used? Or are our forests still one of the five great giveaways referred to so colourfully by my predecessor Senator Sanders in his first speech as the first environmentalist elected to an Australian parliament? Furthermore, is this income enough to offset the environmental costs to the community of water run-off problems, loss of species habitat, and the forgone value to tourism and other nature based activities, not to mention other non-wood forest products?

The longer term objective of North Forest Products' proposal is to replace native forest with a massive plantation producing wood fibre for a `world class' pulp mill. Such a proposal is insane. The economic logic of plantations to produce pulp is based on concepts of industrial forestry; of planting single species, single aged blocks of trees for mechanical clearfelling and extraction. This would ignore the emerging facts that such operations are in no way consistent with principles of ecological sustainability. They are not even economically sustainable, because successive crops tend to produce reducing yields. Industrial forestry is merely an extension of conveyor belt mechanisation. There certainly can be no guarantee of long-term employment.

The Senate will know that I have kept a close eye on the National Registration Authority for agricultural and veterinary chemicals, and the use of chemicals more generally. It is ironic that one of the chemicals selected by the National Registration Authority for review this year is atrazine. This has occurred precisely because a significant number of people in Tasmania have been adversely affected by atrazine run-off and they have told the National Registration Authority about this.

As senators may know, atrazine is used in industrial forestry plantations to control weeds. But when it leaches into the creeks that provide drinking water for milk producing cattle, for example, we have to ask whether this is the inevitable end result of following the simple economic imperative of engaging in industrial wood fibre production to feed `world class' pulp mills; of government representatives being so intimidated by big companies and big log trucks that they dutifully grant export woodchip licences and, if so, whether the loss of exports of agricultural produce has been considered in the economic equation.

But why does Tasmania need or want to be locked into a so-called `world class pulp mill' anyway? The logic of such a development is that once the mill is established, Tasmania is locked into providing the feedstock for the life of the mill. More trees are needed. Not just plantation trees, but inevitably as plantations fail from disease or overcropping or any of the other typical problems of monoculture, I predict that the mill owners will threaten that unless a new source of native forest trees is provided, jobs will be lost. That is the typical threat, that is the one I predict and I guarantee that it will happen.

Is that the future we want, a future of pine, plastic, pulp and plantations, as put a couple of years ago in the Wilderness News by a couple of members of Greening Australia—a future dependent upon the needs and demands of so-called world-class mills? We need to stand up for ourselves—to refuse to play the world-class game. In this country we have unique resources in our native forests. They should be protected, nurtured and valued as perpetual and necessary inputs to the life of our planet. To cut them down to be replaced with plantations of any type is sacrilege, and it is about time this government recognised it as such.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not listed to speak on the adjournment and I will be very brief.
—Don't tell me I provoked you.

—No, I would not answer that contribution of yours, because it was very misleading. I was prompted to say a few words by Senator Wheelwright's contribution when he referred to who is doing what in protesting against the French. I put on the record, as the current chairman of the France-Australia parliamentary friendship group, as Senator Burns would know, even though the membership has waned—there have been resignations from quite a few members in protest against the French attitude in Mururoa—that we have been active.

PARA.TAB: I wrote to my counterpart in the French National Assembly, M. Cornillet, and in the French Senate, Senator Pierre Vallon, when it became known that the French were intending to hold nuclear tests at Mururoa. These letters were vetted by all the government agencies. It goes without saying that I have not received responses to either of those letters.At a recent meeting of our France-Australia friendship group, Senator Campbell and Mr Les Scott were instrumental in drafting a motion which was attached to another letter that I have sent to the same people, decrying the fact that France has begun its nuclear test program.

Also, I report to the Senate that on Sunday week I will be attending the International Parliamentary Union Conference in Bucharest, accompanied by the Speaker, Steve Martin, Leo McLeay, Senator Woods and Senator Denman. We know that New Zealand is proposing a motion of condemnation of the French over their nuclear testing. We intend to support that motion. I look forward to participating in the debate.

I wanted to report to the Senate tonight the actions that I have taken as chairman of the France-Australia friendship group, and our activities. I hope that, further down the track, when France comes to its senses—perhaps not this year, perhaps next year—when we need to start rebuilding bridges with France again, the France-Australia friendship group will still be in existence, and that the members who are part of that group will be responsible for building bridges again with our counterparts in the French parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative
