TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications and the Arts, upon notice, on 28 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer given to question on notice number 2048 (Senate Hansard, 29 May 1995, page 499).
(1)(a) How has Telstra calculated the $1.5 million inflated value of the `exploitative' lease agreements;
(b) what were the:
(i) model numbers,
(ii) monthly or quarterly repayments
(iii) rental periods of the machines provided by Canon and Xerox; and

(c) have total repayments on the equipment supplied by Canon and/or Xerox been compared to total repayments on the same or equivalent models under contemporaneous or even 1993 Department of Administrative Service contracts; if so, what were the price comparisons; if not, why not, and will Telstra supply these comparisons.
(2) Which officers within Telstra approved these `exploitative' contracts.
(3) (a) when did Mr Charles Mauro commence employment with Telstra;
(b) in what position did he work; and
(c) did he approve any of the `exploitative' contracts.

(4) With reference to Telstra's referral of certain matters to the Victorian Police, is Telstra aware of similar `exploitative' lease arrangements entered into with Xerox and Canon in New South Wales during the period in question; if so:
(a) what were the circumstances;
(b) what action has Telstra taken in relation to these matters; and
(c) does the figure of $1.5 million in `exploitative' leases include arrangements entered into in New South Wales.

(5) Did the contracts with Xerox and Canon include a sum for toner included in the cost per copy charge; if so, what was the calculation for the cost of the toner; and, in either case, what were the names of all companies from which the toner was sourced.
(6) Of the $1.3 million in `favourable adjustments' made to equipment leases, what amount was made to leases with:
(a) Xerox;
(b) Canon;
(c) Inchape respectively.
(7) What were the:
(a) dates;
(b) agenda;
(c) decisions/outcomes of all Telstra's meeting with the senior management of Xerox and/or Canon.
(8) What Telstra officers attended these meetings.
(9) Did Telstra's executive council approve a mandatory agreement with Xerox and Canon; if so:
(a) on what date; and
(b) who attended this meeting.
(10) What precise roles did Mr Mauro have in relation to the tendering and evaluation of tenders for supply of photocopiers and facsimile machines in 1993.
(11) Did the companies chosen as a result of this tender process submit the cheapest prices; if not:
(a) which companies submitted cheaper tenders;
(b) how much cheaper were their indicative prices; and
(c) why were they not chosen.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Telstra has advised that:

(1)(a) By comparing prices available at the time on Purchasing Australia and State Government contracts, reviewing individual rental agreements to identify any free products that did not provide value to Telstra and calculating the extra financing associated with the extended rental period.
(b)(i) All models of the respective suppliers range.
(ii) Repayment rates varied from deal to deal based on the type of equipment purchased.
(iii) Rental periods varied from three to five years.

(c) Yes. Price comparisons were made in order to determine the level of `exploitative' pricing charged. Prices charged varied depending on the range of bundled or free product. On those products where `exploitative' pricing occurred, the price charged was, on average, 6% above that available on Purchasing Australia contracts.

(2) There were no Telstra contracts in place with any photocopier or facsimile supplier. Any `exploitative' arrangements were applied on individual rental agreements. Two hundred and three staff were identified as signing the individual agreements.
(3)(a) Mr Mauro was never employed by Telstra as a member of its staff.

(b) and (c) He was engaged as a consultant to assist Telstra in preparing a tender document for supply of photocopier and facsimile machines and to advise Telstra on relevant technical data contained in responses to the tender. He was not involved in the selection or decision process.
(4) Yes.
(a) The `exploitative' lease arrangements were similar to those identified in Victoria but not as extensive.
(b) The Victorian and New South Wales matters were handled together. No matters were identified in NSW that needed referring to the police.
(c) Yes.

(5) No specific maintenance contracts were in place with Fuji Xerox Australia or Canon Australia. Maintenance agreements were usually arranged on an individual machine basis at the time of purchasing or renting a machine. The terms of the agreement determined whether the cost of the toner was to be either included or excluded in the copy cost charged.

It is difficult for Telstra to provide details of all the companies from whom toner would have been sourced during the period. Most of the suppliers and their respective dealer networks and service points could have supplied toner, along with non associated companies. Due to the numerous country locations many Telstra locations would have had local arrangements in place covering toner and service requirements.
(7)(a)(b) and (c) Canon Australia. 4 June 1993, 17 June 1993, 23 June 1993, 12 August 1993, 26 August 1993.
Fuji Xerox Australia. 21 May 1993, 25 June 1993, 12 August 1993, 28 September 1993, 7 October 1993, 9 November 1993.
The meetings progressed on the following basis:
(i) Advising the suppliers of Telstra's dissatisfaction with the charged prices, charging methods and use of incentive products.
(ii) Providing details of Telstra's review of the acquisitions of photocopier and facsimile machines.
(iii) Obtaining feedback from the suppliers of their review of the matters raised by Telstra.
(iv) Providing further information to the suppliers and the suppliers providing further feedback.
(v) Discussion of settlement options.
(vi) Agreement to terms of settlement.
(vii) Review of the implementation of the terms of settlement.
(8) General Manager, Supply Fleet and Distribution; National Manager, Material Management; National Manager, Corporate Sourcing; and Charles Mauro, Consultant to Telstra

(9) No. The Group Managing Director, Network and Technology Group of Telstra, as delegate, approved non exclusive Product Sourcing Agreements with Canon Australia and Fuji Xerox Australia on 14 October 1993. Whilst the arrangements with the companies are non exclusive Telstra's Executive Council issued a mandate in July 1993 that purchase of photocopier and facsimile machines must be made through a Telstra contract. The objective of the arrangement was to improve the standard of the purchasing process and achieve substantial cost savings for Telstra. In October 1994 Telstra's Executive Council issued a further mandate to cover all national sourcing contracts for commercially available products and services.
(10) Refer to the response to part 3(b) of this question.

(11)(a),(b) and (c). In order to evaluate tender responses machines were divided into eleven categories based on rated monthly output capabilities and similarly optioned to ensure a true comparison. In six categories there were instances where other companies offered comparable machines at lower prices (these included machines from such companies as Lanier, Mita, Alcatel Datakey, Remington, Konica and Inchcape). Percentage variations between the lowest price and the selected supplier where in the range 0.3% to 14.6%.
In assessing which tenderers offered the best value for money, Telstra's objectives included minimising the total number of suppliers, in order to:
standardise the operating platform,
overcome control weaknesses, and
minimise administration costs associated with multiple suppliers.

Therefore, the total range of products and configurations available from each tenderer was a key element in the selection criteria. Canon Australia and Fuji Xerox Australia were able to offer the full range of machines required and were assessed as being at the leading edge of the technology. They also had extensive maintenance strengths including their own employees, proven distribution networks and are considered market leaders across this range of products. None of the lower priced tenderers were considered able to match Canon Australia or Fuji Xerox Australia in any of these aspects. Final contract prices received from Fuji Xerox Australia and Canon Australia reduced the percentage variance shown above.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the President of the Senate, upon notice, on 19 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) How many, and which, Members and Senators (including Ministers) currently have access to the Internet through their Parliament House offices.
(2)(a) What is the current timetable for providing all Members and Senators with access to Internet through their Parliament House offices;
(b) Can a guarantee be given that such access will be provided by the time Parliament resumes in August 1995; and
(c) Can a guarantee be given that it will be provided by the end of the current parliamentary session in December 1995.
(3) Who is responsible for installing the necessary physical links in order to provide Members and Senators with access to the Internet in their Parliament House off ices.

(4) Do a number of Ministers currently have access to the Internet through their Parliament House offices; if so, how did they obtain such access and what is preventing other Members and Senators from receiving a similar service.
(5) When was the issue of providing access to the Internet through Members' and Senators' Parliament House offices first raised with the Joint House Department.
(6) What are the current impediments preventing Members and Senators from being provided with access to the Internet through their Parliament House offices.
(7) What would be the estimated installation and recurrent costs entailed in providing such access.
(8) Can a copy of any internal reports or consultant's reports commissioned by the Parliamentary Information Systems Office (PISO) in relation to this issue be provided.

(9) Has PISO held any briefings with Microsoft or any other Organisation about installing On Australia as part of the parliamentary network; if so, what, if any, commitments have been made regarding the use of On Australia.

(10) As there are 750 000 Internet subscribers in Australia (a figure estimated to double in the next 12 months) does the Joint House Department consider that providing Members and Senators with access to Internet is a matter of priority; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No Members' or Senators' Parliament House offices have been provided with direct suite-based access to the Internet. I am not aware of the situation in respect of Ministers.

(2) (a) No timetable has been set. The Speaker and myself will shortly be provided with advice on this issue from the five parliamentary departments, following examination of the technical aspects involved and also consideration of the issue by the Presiding Officers' Information Technology Advisory Group, on which all parties in the Parliament are represented.
(b) No.
(c) No.
(3) The Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, through its Parliamentary Information Systems Office.

(4) I am unaware of any Ministers having access to the Internet through their Parliament House offices. The provision of information technology services to Ministers is normally undertaken by the Minister's Department not a parliamentary department.

(5) Joint House Department has no responsibility for this issue. Since February 1990 the Parliamentary Information Systems Office has been a division of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff (DPRS). DPRS received informal requests in mid-1994.
(6) Security of the parliamentary network and capital and recurrent funding are the two major issues.

(7) The costs of providing suite-based access to the Internet for Senators, Members, and a limited number of staff of the parliamentary departments are estimated at approximately $450,000 for the first year (including one-off capital costs) and recurrent costs of around $230,000 a year thereafter, although this figure is very tentative and will be significantly altered by high usage levels.
(8) A report prepared by an interdepartmental Working Group will be provided.

(10) Senators and Members have had access to the Internet for some time. The Department of the Parliamentary Library has provided Internet access in Parliament House since 1993. More recently, the Department of the Senate has provided access for Senators from two PC workstations, and the Department of the House of Representatives is arranging PC workstations to provide access for Members. The PC workstations providing Internet access in Parliament are not connected to the Parliamentary network.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Australian Defence Force (ADF) discussed the availability of Harpoon missiles with the United States (US) Department of Defense; if so (a) What was the status of the negotiations; and (b) was it an inquiry about the availability of the weapons or did the ADF seek permission to purchase these missiles from the US.
(2) Which officials in Australia and the US have been involved in the negotiations to purchase Harpoon missiles.
(3) Why did the US Congress proceed with the clearance of the sale of these weapons if it was only an inquiry as to their availability.
(4) What reasons can be given for the apparent misunderstanding between the Australian and US officials over the ADF's intentions with respect to Harpoon missiles.
(5) What action has been taken to ensure that similar misunderstandings between Australian and US officials are avoided in the future.
(6) What are the ADF's future requirements for Harpoon missiles.
(7) When does the ADF propose to purchase more Harpoon missiles.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department of Defence regularly discusses the availability of Harpoon missiles with the US Department of Defense. At the time of the Pentagon press release, an offer for a life of type buy made by the US Department of Defense was being considered by the ADF. This offer was made after an earlier proposal for the supply of Harpoon missiles was not taken up and had expired in May 1995. That earlier offer had been made in response to a request for price and availability information.
(2) Australian officials involved in negotiations to purchase Harpoon missiles were from the Navy Materiel Division and the Australian Embassy, Washington D.C.
US officers involved were from International Programs and Foreign Military Sales Offices.

(3) If a sale were to be made US Congressional clearance of the sale would be necessary because of the size of the Harpoon offer. This clearance was routinely sought by the US Navy International Programs Office to enable the offer to be taken up by the ADF, if desired, before it expired.

(4) There was no misunderstanding over ADF intentions between the US and Australian officials directly involved. The offer remained open for the ADF to accept or decline until the end of August 1995. The Pentagon press release following US Congressional clearance presumed that the offer would be accepted.

(5) Those officials directly involved on both sides understand that, of approximately 250 formal requests for pricing and advice on releasibility lodged annually by the Australian Embassy in Washington, only about 140 result in Government to Government contracts. Action to advise other than those with whom Australian officials are involved directly is not appropriate.
(6) The ADF requirement for the acquisition of Harpoon missiles is to sustain the ADF practice firing program.
(7) The ADF proposes to purchase more Harpoon missiles as follows:
(a) Joint Project 1 Phase M with a year of decision of 1995/96 for procurement of practice missiles for RAN and RAAF practice/surveillance firings; and

(b) Joint Project 1 Phase N with a year of decision of 1998/99 for procurement of a life of type supply, before the US ceases production of Harpoon missiles, in order to meet the RAN and RAAF practice firing program.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 10 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that the Commonwealth-funded Home and Community Care (HACC) Specific Home Care Program differs greatly in its operation from one local area to another.

(2) Why is it that some services funded by the Commonwealth are able to refuse to provide the following services for children with a disability through the HACC Specific Home Care Program: overnight in home respite care, home care workers who administer medication, home care workers who will accompany children out of home to recreation or development activities, emergency contact numbers, smooth transition to general home care provision and consistency in caring staff.
(3) Does the Commonwealth have guidelines that ensure consistency in service provision for the HACC Specific Home Care Program.

(4) Is it a fact that the HACC Specific Home Care Program is a fully subsidised program, yet some local governments in Victoria charge a fee for this service which is designed to recover more than the costs of administering the program.
(5) What accountability mechanisms does the Commonwealth have in place to ensure Commonwealth funds are used to meet the desired outcomes of the HACC Specific Home Care Program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Home and Community Care (HACC) Program is jointly funded by the Commonwealth and State/Territory governments, with Commonwealth providing about 60% of the funding. The Commonwealth shares responsibility for planning, community consultation, accountability and resource allocation arrangements. However, responsibility for day-to-day management of the Program rests with State/Territory governments who are the primary point of contact with service providers.

HACC funded Specific Home Care (SHC) are auspiced in Victoria, mainly by local governments. It is recognised that there may be variation in the distribution of SHC services across local government areas.

While a standard set of operational guidelines apply across the Program in the State, variations in administration in an area may occur as a result of differences in demography, needs-based planning, local government priorities and priority of access to services based on the relative need of consumers.

(2) The provision of services through SHC is based on the assessed relative needs of clients. Any limitations on service provision are therefore linked to prioritised level of need and the service's ability to meet these needs within resources available.

The HACC Program was established to provide basic maintenance and support services for frail aged and other people with a disability, and their carers. Overnight in-home respite care is a resource-intensive service which many services find difficult to provide because of the cost and the need for workers to have special qualifications for administering medication.
HACC services providing respite care are encouraged to respond flexibly in meeting client needs, including accompanying a person with a disability to recreational or development activities.

Service providers are encouraged to arrange for a consumer to have services delivered by the same person whenever possible. This is not always possible due to the hours individual staff members are employed, the time of demand and rostering difficulties.

(3) HACC National Guidelines set broad parameters for the operation of the Program nationally. Each State/Territory is responsible for developing guidelines for the Program in their State/Territory. In Victoria guidelines have been developed for each service type which provide a basis for consistent service provision and outcomes for clients. Service providers are required to comply with these guidelines in the provision of care and with the National Service Standards which set national guidelines for consistency in service quality and provision to consumers.

(4) The HACC Program provides a subsidy for the provision of SHC services. Where a local government charges a fee, it is expected that this fee will be used for the extension and expansion of the service. Where fees are charged by an organisation, they should be sought only from consumers who have the capacity to pay and waived for any service where the client is assessed as not having that capacity.

(5) Under current program arrangements all HACC funded services are required to enter into an agreement specifying service delivery details with the State/Territory administering departments. These services are also required to submit an annual audited statement of expenditure to the State/Territory department.
Part of State/Territory administrative responsibility is on-going monitoring and the regular conduct of services reviews to ensure compliance with the service agreement and HACC Service Standards.

A joint Commonwealth/State review of the Program has recently been completed and the Health and Community Services Ministerial Council has agreed to its recommendations with some minor amendments. One of the areas of reform flowing from the review will be a move to funding services for the care provided to HACC consumers, rather than for service inputs, such as salaries and administrative costs. Consequent to this move will be the implementation of accountability measures that will report program outputs on a regional basis.

This refocusing of the Program's funding on outputs and outcomes for clients and the associated accountability measures, will ensure that Commonwealth funds are focused on outcomes for all HACC services including Specific Home Care services in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 23 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What has been the total cost to the Commonwealth of casemix development and implementation since its inception.
(2) Does the Commonwealth have an estimate of the costs to the States.
(3) When will it be known whether casemix has led to high quality and efficient health care services

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Since its inception in 1988-89 the Casemix Development Program has expended $39m.

(2) A large proportion ($22m) of Casemix Development Program funds have been allocated to the States for expenditure on State projects. The Commonwealth does not have an estimate of what States have spent on casemix development from their own funds.

(3) The primary aim of casemix funding is to improve the efficiency of hospitals. Casemix information will assist in tasks associated with measuring quality, but cannot, of itself, change the quality of health services. As the States progressively implement casemix measures it will be possible to assess the impact on quality and efficiency, though allowance must be made for concurrent changes in health services delivery. An assessment of the implementation of casemix in Victoria in 1993-94 found considerable efficiency gains and no decline in quality attributable to the casemix funding system. An assessment of the introduction of casemix in South Australia in 1994-95 will be undertaken by the Commonwealth late 1996. Many hospital clinicians are using casemix information, among other measures, in order to assist in improving their approach to patient care.

The Commonwealth is working with the States to develop nationally consistent measures that will permit a better assessment of changes in quality over time. Consumer perceptions of quality are to be considered as part of this process. It is likely that improvements in quality will be linked to future funding agreements with the States.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What arrangements for consultancies were made with the Insolvency Practitioners Association of Australia prior to and after the drafting of the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill 1995.
(2) Can details and minutes of any such consultations be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Prior to the drafting of the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 (BLAB), copies of three discussion papers on Bankruptcy Reform were sent to a wide range of persons and organisations practising in or involved with personal insolvency, including the Insolvency Practitioners Association of Australia (IPAA) in the period from September to October 1993. Written submissions in connection with those discussion papers were made subsequently by the IPAA, and others.

In addition, members of the IPAA and others attended formal meetings in November and December 1993 held in all mainland capital cities to discuss issues contained in the three discussion papers. (There was also an informal meeting held with insolvency practitioners in Hobart). Those formal meetings were conducted by the A/g Adviser, Insolvency Law from the Insolvency and Trustee Service, Australia (ITSA), Mr Michael Bersten. Mr Bersten made handwritten notes of matters discussed at the meetings and, other than in respect of the Melbourne meeting, they were typed up subsequently and were used to assist him to prepare relevant submissions to the Government.

In addition, the President and the National Secretary of the IPAA attended a meeting with the Minister for Justice and senior ITSA officers in December 1993 in Canberra to discuss the proposed amendments. No notes were taken of that meeting.

Following tabling of the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 (BLAB) on 8 March 1995, a meeting was held in Canberra on 8 May 1995 at which Mr John D Adams, National President of the IPAA and Mr Tim Jonas from the IPAA's National Bankruptcy Sub-Committee attended to discuss the IPAA's comments on the BLAB and related matters. A written submission from the IPAA was subsequently received. That submission reiterated most of the points raised by the IPAA in the meeting and which had been discussed at length.

While formal consultation with the IPAA on the BLAB has occurred primarily at the national level, there have also been a number of meetings between senior ITSA officers and State IPAA representatives at which aspects of the BLAB have been explained and discussed. Ordinarily those meetings have been a part of the regular regional liaison meetings between ITSA and the IPAA. Where relevant to the BLAB, those meetings usually concentrate on operational issues likely to arise from the proposed amendments, such as information and training sessions from ITSA for registered trustees and their staff, the operation of proposed debt agreements, or the operational arrangements being proposed for the One Stop Service. No formal notes or minutes are ordinarily made of those discussions.

(2) A list of the 1993 meetings about the contents of the discussion papers, and copies of the notes made by Mr Bersten of matters discussed at the meetings, and of the meeting in Canberra on 8 May 1995, have been tabled.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 28 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, are companies which mine and crush limestone for the production of agricultural lime, eligible to claim the diesel fuel rebate for tax paid on diesel fuel used in mining, crushing and production processes.

(2) Is the companies' eligibility for the diesel fuel rebate the same now as it was on 11 August 1995; if not: (a) what was the advice of the Australian Customs Service (ACS) at that time; and (b) why has the position of the ACS changed.
(3) When did the ACS decide and publicly advise the eligibility of these companies under the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Under the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1995, the definition of "minerals" for the purposes of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme has been clarified to specifically exclude sand, sandstone, soil, slate, clay (other than bentonite or kaolin), basalt, granite, gravel, limestone or water. The amended definition currently applies to diesel fuel purchased on or after 1 August 1986. The Government has already introduced the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995 to amend the operative date to 1 July 1995 (except in relation to water), to accord with the will of the Senate.

Under the amended definition of "minerals", diesel fuel purchased for use to extract limestone per se is not rebatable as limestone is not recognised as a mineral in its own right. But diesel fuel purchased for use to extract or crush limestone as an ore with a view to recovering from it a particular mineral or particular minerals will continue to be rebatable.

(2) The Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 as amended passed both the Senate and the House of Representatives on 30 June 1995 and received Royal Assent on 1 July 1995. The ACS is obliged to administer the law in accordance with the new provision.

The date of 11 August 1995 has no particular significance. That day was a normal working day during which a range of decisions in respect of eligibility of claims were made, as such decisions are made each working day. ACS records show that on that particular day advice was supplied to a company on the issue of the eligibility of limestone extraction for rebate.

The ACS did not change its position in respect of the eligibility for rebate of diesel fuel used in the extraction of limestone on that day. The law had changed to the extent that rebate was no longer payable on diesel fuel used to extract limestone. As mentioned in (1) above legislation has been introduced to amend the operative date of this change to 1 July 1995.

(3) Following the introduction of the original Bill into the House of Representatives in May 1995, the Opposition clearly indicated its intention to seek to amend the Bill once it reached the Senate and the records reflect that, during the course of the Second Reading Debate in the Senate, 52 amendments were moved by the Opposition, Democrat and Green Senators in addition to the 28 amendments moved by the Government.

Because of the likelihood of amendments, it was impossible for the ACS to advise claimants with any degree of certainty about the foreshadowed changes to the law. There are in excess of 150,000 claimants.

Following passage of the Bill by Parliament, the ACS immediately proceeded to organise dispatches to individual claimants to advise them of the changes that were made to the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme. The dispatches were carried out by a contractor and the records indicate that claimants in the category of mining operations were advised of the changes in writing on or about 24 July 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 30 August 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to order number L13/95 titled, Export of sheep to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, produced pursuant to section 16H of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977:
(1) How does this order affect live sheep exports to countries other than Saudi Arabia.
(2) Will this order remain in force indefinitely until it is repealed, amended or superseded by another order.

(3) Is it a fact that under this order sheep can still be exported to Saudi Arabia following approval from the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation (AMLC); if so, what criteria will need to be met before the AMLC will give approval.
(4) Have any estimates been made as to the number of live sheep expected to be exported from Australia to all countries in the 1995-96 financial year

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) This order, which was made by the AMLC pursuant to section 16H of the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977, is country specific, and does not affect live sheep exports to other countries.
(2) This order will remain in force until it is repealed, amended or superseded by another order made by the AMLC.
(3) The order, L13/95, remains active, and does therefore allow licensed exporters to make application to the AMLC for approval to export to Saudi Arabia.

No applications have been considered or approved by the AMLC since my announcement in the Parliament on 29 May that a Working Group on live sheep would be established to thoroughly review all of the factors that lead to the first shipment being diverted to Aqaba. The terms of reference for the Working Group were also announced at that time.

The Working Group, which includes representatives from industry, AMLC and Government, is currently preparing a report for my consideration. On receipt of that report, and after due study, a decision will be taken as to whether any further shipments will be made to Saudi Arabia, and if so, what criteria will need to be met.

(4) I am advised by the AMLC that the estimated number of live sheep exports to all destinations in 1995-96 is expected to be approximately 6.2 million head, up 3% on the 6.015 million head exported in 1994-95.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 6 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) How much veal is produced in Australia each year.
(2) How much of this veal is produced by confining calves individually in pens or crates for all or most of their lives.
(3) Is there a standard code of practice across Australia relating to the welfare of veal calves.
(4) What action, if any, is the Federal government taking to ensure that veal is produced in a humane manner throughout Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Total veal production in 1994/95 was 37,616 tonnes carcase weight equivalent.
(2) Some calves for veal production are housed individually for up to 9 weeks. Calves are then normally group-housed until they reach approximately 6 months of age.

(3) & (4) The Australian Agricultural Council, which preceded the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand, endorsed a model code of practice for cattle in February 1991. Section 3 of the code provides for the artificial rearing of calves and includes detailed conditions for feeding and housing the calves. The code provides that where individual calf pens are used these should be so made and located to allow each calf to see and hear other cattle and have sufficient space to permit self-grooming and prevent overcrowding.
State and Territory Governments in Australia have primary responsibility for animal welfare matters through their prevention of cruelty to animals legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 6 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that the Amberley division of Asset Services has made a profit over the last few years and is one of the most efficient 3 depots in Australia.
(2) What is the rationale for the dismissal of staff at the depot.
(3) What was the length of time given to consideration of these staff cuts.
(4) Who made the decision to cut staff at Asset Services' Amberley division.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.

(2) The sales performance of the Amberley Operations Centre has decreased from $13.6M in 1991-92 to $6.8M in 1994-95. While it did make a profit in 1994-95 of $133,000 or 1.9% of turnover, staffing projections must be commercially based on projected sales. The Operations Centre's business plan for 1995-96 projects sales of $3.0M. Since the untying of its customers in 1991 sales have progressively decreased and staffing numbers have had to be adjusted accordingly.
(3) The staffing numbers are based on projected sales and are the result of an extensive and exhaustive process of budget reviews and business plan

ANSWER.PARA: ning assessments by the Operations Centre. The need for possible staffing reductions has been identified and openly considered since early in 1994. The likely scale of the reductions was advised to unions and employees earlier this year.

PARA.TAB: (4) The Amberley Operations Centre is a separate profit centre within Asset Services. The Operations Centre is required to produce a business plan and to achieve viable levels of performance. The business plan was prepared by a cross section of its staff and approved by both the Queensland State Manager and General Manager, Asset Services. The current downsizing reflects the projected sales in this year's business plan.
